name: Anonymous
com:
We encourage you to have a look around the catalog first to see what we’re all about before posting your first thread. Topics typically posted here include:
>Outdoor recreational activities (Hiking, trail running, bushwhacking, camping, spelunking, geocaching, orienteering, expeditions, urban exploration, backpacking, etc.)
>Gardening, farming and related activities
>Hunting and fishing, and other activities involving the stalking or taking of game (including bird-watching)
>Outdoor survival, bushcraft, foraging, self-sustenance in nature, train-hopping, hoboism, etc.
>Outdoor destinations and exploration (specific trails, parks, regions, etc.)
>Water-related activities (boats, diving, etc.)
>Outdoor philosophy (conservation, Leave No Trace, protectionism, etc.)
>Outdoor building and living (cabins, huts, treehouses, etc.)
>Outdoor social activities and organizations (meet-ups, Scouts, NOLS, etc.)
>Gear related to any of the above topics

Most topics related to the outdoors are fine. Write properly, behave politely, encourage a respectful community, and most importantly, GO OUTSIDE!!

com: I'd second spending time in the Black Hills. It's pegmatitic granite mostly, very cool rock. Definitely drive the Needles Highway and hike black elk or through the cathedral spires (spires are cooler imho). Do some cliff jumping at Pactola if you're into that sort of thing. There's also plenty of climbing out there. The northern Black Hills in Wyoming are also cool, Devils Tower is a great day/weekend trip. If you're traveling on Rt. 90 there's a great Indian food place at the exit going to Deadwood right before Spearfish

com:
>What Does 'Speak Now or Forever Hold Your Peace' Mean?

If you want to get technical, the full sentence is a variation of: "Should anyone present know of any reason that this couple should not be joined in holy matrimony, speak now or forever hold your peace."

Wedding expert Heather Jones explains the phrasing translates to a question posed toward the audience. More or less, it's asking if anyone is opposed to the couple's marriage. "In tradition, this would be the time to speak your mind if you disagreed with the relationship, but 'holding your peace' would mean that you're choosing to accept the couple's future together," she explains.
>Why is 'Speak Now or Forever Hold Your Peace' Said at Weddings?

Wilson puts it best when she says humans are creatures of habit, and we thrive with tradition. Since historically, weddings have taken place in religious institutions, most couples follow what rules set forth from previous generations. In fact, Wilson says up until recently, most couples chose to honor their parents and grandparents by holding their wedding ceremony at a church. With input from a best friend, an uncle, an expert, and even the internet, most duos decide to do what's best for them instead. This makes the phrase less prominent. Also, when the congregation is encouraged to 'speak now or forever hold their peace' — it's not taken literally, according to wedding expert Kevin Dennis.

how did you build the interior? how much did it cost?

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2008945
I built it myself, mostly from baltic birch plywood. Just sketched up a design and then learned enough woodworking (cutting dados, cabinet making, templating) to build it. Insulation is mostly polyiso for the large panels, with some thinsulate for the corners and hard to reach areas.

All in, it probably cost around 5k-6k, but I didn't track expenses very carefully. That includes the solar, DC-DC charging, portapotty, usb outlets, lights, plumbing system, fans, etc...

com:
Geocaching used to be fun because you had to:
1. Spend time googling around and doing research to find an interesting cache (or anything at all).
2. Program your GPS (not your phone)
3. Use your land nav skills and your GPS
4. Put away your GPS once you got close enough and spend time searching

Now, there's apps that just show you caches around you. It is insanely retarded how "gamey" this whole thing has. I imagine the people who geocache now are the same faggots who use AllTrails.

I think the dildo idea is pretty funny.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2002229
what do you mean “alaskan wildlife ranger” there are park ranger jobs with nps, forest service, and fish and wildlife in ak but nothing called “wildlife ranger” afaik even at a wildlife refuge its still just park ranger unless you really mean something like game warden.
there are wildlife studying positions but those are biotechs not rangers.

assuming you mean park ranger while i have not worked in ak ive worked as a ranger in multiple other places and to answer your other things >>2002265
yes if its an LE position there is serious background checks (regular for non LE) but what they are really looking for is whether you hide something or lie to them. most rangers in ak also have to be able to carry a firearm because bears.
if its any kind of position in a remote place (think gates of the arctic where there is nothing but the park and you get supplies by plane) there is also a psych eval to make sure you can handle living out there.
>competing with police and former military
competing with police isnt the issue, its the veterans that get magical priority in hiring. you will get emails back about jobs you applied for that say “because enough qualified veterans applied you were not considered”

otherwise the best advice is to get as much experience as you can, even if its volunteer. you need to get past the first hr hurdles in hiring to get forwarded to the specific park which means being able to say you have experience in every thing in the questionnaire.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2002320
interp jobs are a good way to get some starter experience, thats what i did. but you are in a big city with a city parks system so surely you can find a way to work or volunteer with them? i actually recently turned down an offer with peoria parks and rec.

for the hr hurdles, basically find the job posting of what you want and go through the questionnaire, its basically a list if exp requirements. if it asks if you have exp handling money, get exp handling money.
the way usajobs hiring works is all applicants initially go to federal hr people (who have zero knowledge of the specific jobs) who just look to see if your resume matches the experience you claimed in the questionnaire. this is why a usajobs resume is entirely different, and usually pages longer than, a private resume. if you dont directly say on your resume that you did x at a job, you did not do x at a job.
they then filter out all the apps of less qualified based on point score. if you were able to answer the “i am an expert” option to each question you get the highest score. dont outright lie, but if you did x on a job on your own, you wanna say youre an expert.
once you clear that, hr forwards on to the actual hiring location, and those people actually look at your resume like humans and make interviews and all that.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2003127
Check the rating to see if it's 'comfortable' or 'lower limit' and decide from there. Most bags list lower limit, which is generally to cold for comfortable with just base layers and possibly more on. Do you often go out in -10C? Then your bag or system should be comfortable at that temperature. If that's on the lower side of what you generally do, you might consider a slightly warmer weather bag and get a summer quilt or bag liner that you can layer to achieve comfort on the fewer cold nights that your out.

name: Anonymous
com: City slicker/fatherless father here, I am looking for decent fishing rods for my 8 year old son and I to use. Pls no bully

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2005280
https://fishingbooker.com/blog/types-of-fishing-reels/

When I was a kid, I learned how to fish using spincasting reels with worms and bobbers... (you can use small lures with them too, though it's not great) They aren't exactly exciting, but they are pretty simple and easy to handle.
Now though, in my 30s, I own several spinning reels. This type is tricky to learn though and would probably NOT be appropriate for kid-size fingers (unless you can maybe find a kid-size version). If you watch some YT videos demonstrating how they work, you'll see what I mean.
(I've never used a Baitcasting reel)

I don't really know what exactly to recommend though. If you're both new, maybe start with some cheap spincasters (a Bass Pro or whatever should have cheap rod/reel combos available). If it turns out you love fishing, look into getting and learning how to use spinning reels later, as he gets older, as they provide much more control over how you cast, which is really important for fishing with lures.

For your first experience, if you're looking for the most action (and with an 8yo, you probably are), actually get 3 or 4 rod/reels. Use two for fishing with small lures (cast them out, slowly reel back in, cast again... until a fish bites) and use the other(s) for setting worms/minnows and bobbers at the same time.

You're probably going to want to watch some YT videos to learn how to effectively fish with lures vs bobber, etc.

name: Anonymous

pretty much everywhere you go other people have been, especially if you are on trails, so you can always find previously used campsites. or you are in a national park or something that already has designated backcountry sites.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2006069
Look for:
-possible falling objects, especially dead branches in trees
-dead standing trees possibly falling over in high wind
-proper water drainage and no signs of pooling
-wind break
-sun shade
-human&animal traffic, trails, runs, nests
-insect nests especially ground wasps
-proximity to water

name: Anonymous
com: Where does a city slicker get started? Planning to start hiking as soon as weather gets better. Anything I should know?

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2006786
Learn how to walk

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2006786
Unironically: use alltrails.com to find some parkland near you with trails. For your first trip, aim for something rated easy/moderate that's about 3-4 hours long, and nothing too mountainous (unless you're already super /fit/). Check to see if the park is free, or if you need to pre-buy a pass online or pay when you get there. Try to look at pictures of the trail on Google Maps to see if you'll need boots (if it's rocky/rough) or if sneakers will work. If you need boots, buy some and wear them around town for a few days to break them in. Pack a snack and a lot of water (24oz or more). Check the weather to see how warm you need to dress, or if you'll need rain gear, or if you'll need sunscreen. Arrive early (before 8AM) in case it gets busy, and so you'll have time to get back before dusk (in case you run into major problems). Don't listen to music, just watch your step and look around.

Under Creative Commons License: Attribution

"Bella Twin, an Indian girl, and her friend Dave Auger were hunting grouse near Lesser Slave Lake in northern Alberta. The only gun they had was Bella's single-shot bolt-action .22 Rimfire rifle. They were walking a cutline that had been made for oil exploration when they saw a large grizzly following the same survey line toward them. If they ran, the bear would probably notice them and might chase, so they quietly sat down on a brush pile and hoped that the bear would pass by without trouble. But the bear
came much too close, and when the big boar was only a few yards away, Bella Twin shot him in the side of the head with a .22 Long cartridge. The bear dropped, kicked and then lay still. Taking no chances, Bella went up close and fired all of the cartridges she had, seven or eight .22 Longs, into the bear's head. That bear, killed in 1953, was the world-record grizzly for several years and is still high in the records today."

name: Anonymous
com:
Went walking on a frozen lake this past weekend, just for the day.
10km out the ice broke through and I fell in.
Luckily I was near the shore, flopped out like a fish very quickly.
I had thick wool baselayers, hardshell jacket+pants, and a huge extra puffy with suspenders on my back as extra, it was -18c but pure sun so the walk back wasn't bad.
Would've been worried if I was in the wilderness on an overnighter only because my boots and gloves+mitts were absolutely soaked, but I had a place to warm up.
I mean, it's been a pretty mild winter this year so the lake was sketchy to begin with, but it was weird because there were skidoos all over the lake and people ice fishing, didn't think I'd actually break through the ice....
We stuck to shore on purpose because there was lots of snow on the lake and it insulates the ice from freezing properly, so I knew it was a risk and was prepared for it.
Shoulda had snowshoes on I guess?

Overall, it was pretty cool to experience all that in a safe situation though.

com:
13 Frontier 4x4 with an ARE DCU cap. Building out an 80/20 bed using 2020 series aluminum in the back. That's aluminum drip edging for the bed slats because it's a third the prince of 80/20. The table is a triple threat: The table leg will drop down to form the middle of the bed and then swing out to form an outside table or to the side to form an inside table.

Next steps: waiting on bolts to bolt down the slates. Cut the table top and trim the leg to the correct height, make magnetic "pull off" panels to trim out the underneath bed sides, do a (short) pull out table under the main 3" wide bed, and put up some window screens on the windorrs. I'm leaning towards magnetic, but may cave and do cheapo velcro screens to hold them on.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1989260
Get a chalk bag if you ever plan to go outside or your gym has tall walls. Otherwise, liquid chalk will work for most routes. Get a harness that's comfortable ASAP. You don't have to worry about weight until you're climbing real shit, so go get a Petzl somethingrather.
Kind-of subjective, but I've heard bad things about Mad Rock shoes. When you hit 5.10/5.11 you may want to upgrade to a better brand like La sportiva/five ten/scarpa. Not that shoes or gear are what's holding you back. I saw a guy climb 5.13s in my gym in converses, so every time I get frustrated with my shoes I remind myself that it's my technique, not the rubber, that's inadequate.
Make sure you take your rest days seriously, but it sounds like you're taking to it well. Good luck.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1989260
Start bouldering. It should take about 2-4 weeks to send a V2 indoors, and by that point you'll be able to climb every 5.9 in the gym. Bouldering is what builds strength and technique the fastest imo
>>1991495
Unless your shoes do not fit. I brought my friend to boulder with me once and his heel and big toe were moving around in those big ass shoes - he was a size over where he should've been. At lower grades it shouldn't matter, but after V3 indoors (or V1 outdoors), you need precision of the foot.

name: Anonymous
com: Any remedies for torn forearm tendons?

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1998401
Plenty people do. I did. Just read books and watch tutorials. Practice placements at ground level and weight test them. Practice making anchors until you're efficient in a range of methods you may utilize outside. Learn the most common knots and how/when to use them. Throw in some self rescue, escaping belays, lowering 2nds safely, rope management, safe descending techniques and probably a few other things and you'll be set.

Start with climbs well within your comfort level. Practice systems in the real world. But most importantly, get some mileage under your belt and it'll all start coming together.

I absolutely ate shit and SLAMMED against the wall, legs hitting multiple holds and leaving nasty bruises. Any advice to not do that? Brace yourself with your legs and arms?

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2004057
Yeah, try to land like a cat with 4 points of springy contact to absorb the impact. Grabbing the rope can unbalance you and mess up your landing so try to avoid doing that. Something novice belayers will sometimes do is take hard before you fall, this will make you crash harder into the wall so make sure they don't do that. Fall down and then swing in to the wall.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2005021
>>2005024
yeah gumbies gonna gumby
ATC Pilot is assisted braking like the grigri, and imo if all you're doing is basic single-pitch climbing/belaying then the Pilot or the Mammut Smart is all you need. Grigris are grigreat, nothing against them, but they really shine for working on rope, ascending/descending, progress capture, etc. SPend your money as you see fit.

I tried setting it to normal mode and couldn't see anything live, nearly a 10 second delay between moving my lure and being able to see that movement on the screen because the water depth numbers were in the way. I used my buddies unit once that had a very similar layout, it was just vertical instead of circular. It also had a "normal" screen next to the vertical flasher and I wound up looking at the vertical flasher most of the time. I know it's a meme, I think my settings were just fucky. It doesn't help that I have the wrong kind of transducer, it's the stock one that you're supposed to strap to a trolling motor or boat hull. >>2008720
>>2008877
Haven’t gotten alligator gar, but spotted or florida gar, was going to mention they’re hard to hook. They like to swim real shallow at dusk in the summer and snap at shit near the top. You have to play with them a bit to get a bite, and baits with lots of treble hooks have a better shot of landing them. Stupid fuckers will snap at spinnerbaits a bunch some days.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2009241
I've gotten them on a couple of different things, including artificial worms. The old redneck trick is to get a length of old gnarled rope, and tie some bait to the end. Their teeth will get tangled in the rope and you can pull them in. That seems a little heartless though, so I'll stick with hooks. They are the best freshwater fight I have found. Little to medium ones especially will greyhound all over the surface when hooked.

Not that anon but do yourself a favor and get some Columbia lightweight pants. I wear them on summer trips along with a long sleeve saltwater fishing shirt and a big white camo boonie hat. I spray it all down with permethrin ahead of time.

>>2006966
Don't listen to those "experts." You can find endless experts for any subject that disagree.

This is an anecdotal example, I go running in 10lb forest fire boots and heavy blue jeans. I run with friends who all wear proper running attire. We all run the same pace. We do a few miles around a 6 minute pace. The thing is, any time I put on my running shoes and a pair of jorts, I absolutely smoke them. I start getting near 5 minutes flat on my mile. Sure it's hard, people would call it dumb. But wearing boots and jeans every day of my life and doing hard things while wearing them absolutely puts me far ahead of basically anybody that isn't a gifted athlete.

I don't even understand why people would practice things with the most efficient and easiest stuff. All you've done is create a factor that you can't improve on. All I have to do it switch shoes and pants and it's a new ball game. I like that.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2007419
>Why do people put all their gear on the outside of their bags?
California played such a heavy influence in backpacking during the 1980’s that it persists to this day. That part of the country is a literal desert, or a forest that goes through a very defined drought/rain cycle. So we had
>exterior frame packs
>very few affordable down bags
>almost no inflatable mattresses
>no rain 8 months out of the year
>all media regarding the subject based in California

The 1980’s image of a California hiker still persists in the common milieu to this day. I while understand the pragmatism of a ccf pad on the outside of a pack on the East Coast, what I don’t get is why no one has ever bothered to sell rain covers for them.

name: Anonymous
com:
I need help setting up my pack. I'm gathering wool clothing now and I'll be making my own MRE's soon so none of those in the pack yet.

I have 2 tarps. A blue standard duty 10x12 and a camo medium duty 10x12. With these I have 8 tent spikes and 2 75' 5/32 paracord. I took these out last year and found the tarps are too big for me unless I can somehow get my dog in there with me instead of standing guard outside.

I have a 30' tie out rope for the dog. I won't get rid of it so don't tell me to.

I have the cheapest cookware set from walmart and a small fold up camp stove with fuel cubes. It worked well enough with a can of beans, but I doubt it will work for an actual meal. I have a few lighters, matches, and dryer lint to help with any fires. I plan on getting a cheap and light single action 22 for hunting and shooting.

For water I have a sawyer mini and a 32 oz water bottle that you always see at the gym.

I'd like to bring my camera along to not be bored. Last (only really) time I went out I just hiked to a spot, set up camp, slept, and hiked back. The cards are also something to play with.

I've got a couple small toothpaste packets and a travel brush with floss for dental hygiene.

I have a small fishing kit with line, hooks, and fake bait. Nothing special and little room lost.

Finally I have a cheap 40F sleeping bag and walmart mat. I plan on adding a wool blanket. I slept in my clothes only last time and regretted that.

What do I need to finish out my pack?

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2007419
>Why do people put all their gear on the outside of their bags?
NZ anon here.
I put it down to US movies/TV honestly.
Here our packs don’t even accomodate anything on the outside except a couple of side pockets at the base - usually tent poles or fuel bottle one side, drink bottle the other (tents are rare here because huts), 1or2 ice axe loops, and a crampon pad - bungees most commonly used to hold your jacket because the weather can never make up its mind.
A sleeping bag outside your pack here is asking for disaster, and pots n pans outside will be laughed at. Only acceptable gear outside is what I mentioned above, plus rope and hardware if climbing- if you HAVE TO.
Noisy rattly shit. Clip both ends on to compression straps.

com: What's a good machete to buy?

name: Anonymous
com: Tramontina

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1999315

Seconded for the price. They only shape the secondary grind, so if you want it to be "sharp", you need to grind that down some or put another bevel on it.

I use a ceramic stone and put a small bevel on it at about 15 degrees per side, and it works well enough. Takes about 10 minutes to do it. I also complete the "tips" by extending their secondary grind to the tip, as they tend to keep them thick at the tip; that takes longer.

Condor are alright and have sharpened edges, though not great. Same with Ontario and Cold Steel.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1999307
Some hardware store one.
Around here they are 6€ each, made locally by the same guys who did my 5€ hatchet.
As such it's a cheap and wonky machete that manages to do it's job, just like the hatchet.
It's a tool, not a piece of jewellery.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2000734
>Don't overthink machetes. You shouldn't spend more than $25 for one.

Yes. Thin stock of 1055/1070 spring steel is cheap, and work hours are all that will boost the cost, hence why they usually have shaped edges rather than an apex. The soft spring steel is so easy to grind, that it's no bother.

It takes me 10 minutes to make a razor sharp bevel on any Tramontina that will process wood and slice through brush like it's not there.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2001294
>It takes me 10 minutes to make a razor sharp bevel on any Tramontina that will process wood and slice through brush like it's not there.

120-200 grit ceramic or diamond are what I use there. Slicing aggression is very high off the low grits, which is what you want.

name: --Chicharron--
com:
>>1999307
My 2 cents.

Born and raised in the Caribbean Island and lived in the mountains, machetes are the main tool for any fieldwork.


Which one to pick?
That will depend on what kind of environment you will be using the tool. It is Pacific Northwest kinda terrain, I will recommend either a 14"=16" Panga. They are sturdy and somehow front-heavy and it will do the job. Another one I will recommend it will be the Kukri style machete. I have at least 3 of them and I used them for everything.

Southwest dry low / high desert any commercial machete will do since the vegetation is dry and easy to deal with.

THE brands I chose were Cold Steel, Gerber and Imacasa.


Good luck

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2000895
I've had two Kuks now. One Nepalese thick boi from Kukri house, and now I have a becker BK21 Reinhardt Kukri.

I've used machetes too, a couple of different ones. Bolo, and latin machetes.

The Kukri is a survival tool, it can chop, hack, smash (if well made), feather stick, baton, you name it. It is not ideal for swinging around all day as a brush clearing tool; its rather heavy. \

A traditional machete is a one trick pony. Really just good for clearing brush.

name: Anonymous
com:
Machetes are supposed to be long and have flex in them. If your machete is stiff or short, it's not a machete and you should just get a parang or an axe. Buy a blade for the type of foliage in your area. Sometimes a a saw and an axe can get you farther if you live in an area with thick logs. Trying to cut thick wood with a stiff machete is just going to get you hurt.
>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XlNSRQtm8eM

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1999307
Looks like Sting from LotR

I have a Gerber machete ($20 or so I think), and it fucking sucks. It feels great, the sheath is useful and durable, but the actual blade strength isn't the best. Any branch you may encounter thicker in diameter than your pinky will ding the blade, and any sort of woodworking (e.g.: feathering) will dull it quickly. I like multipurpose tools- and Gerber ain't it.

name: Anonymous

>>2008009
Who's your favourite? I like Du Fu but my taiwanese thesis supervisor reckons none of the translations come close to the original.

My fav chinese nature poem is this one by Tao Qian, last line sums up a lot of my feelings about the /out/doors. I like that he was an alcoholic NEET from 16 centuries ago too

I made my home amidst this human bustle,
Yet I hear no clamour from the carts and horses.
My friend, you ask me how this can be so?
A distant heart will tend towards like places.
From the eastern hedge, I pluck chrysanthemum flowers,
And idly look towards the southern hills.
The mountain air is beautiful day and night,
The birds fly back to roost with one another.
I know that this must have some deeper meaning,
I try to explain, but cannot find the words.

My sister got me a book of early arabic poetry which is pretty /out/ too. I think the bedouins who wrote a lot of it were very superficially islamized at that point so heaps of it is about the beauty of the desert, sneaking into enemy tent camps to fuck women and getting blind drunk with friends

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2008259
Not him, but Tao Yuanming/Tao Qian is based.
Xuyun/Empty Cloud is also one of my favorites.

>Can joy be found in the mountains?
>Let me tell you. There’s more joy in the mountains Than anywhere else.
>Pines and bamboos perform sacred chants.
>The songs of Sheng flutes are played by birds.
>In the trees, monkeys climb for fruit.
>In the ponds, ducks cavort with lotus lilies.
>This escape from the ordinary world
>Month by month and year by year
>Eliminates the hindrances to Enlightenment.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2008259
Nice, yes definitely all of the classic T'ang and Song poets are great. That Tao Qian poem is lovely, i like their style is calm and domestic in some ways. more a farms and gardens poetry than crazy mountains and river wilds.
My first introduction to wilderness poetry was Han Shan and i think they will always remain my favourite that i judge others by

I settled at Cold Mountain long ago,
Already it seems like years and years.
Freely drifting, I prowl the woods and streams
And linger watching things themselves.
Men don't get this far into the mountains,
White clouds gather and billow.
Thin grass does for a mattress,
The blue sky makes a good quilt.
Happy with a stone under head
Let heaven and earth go about their changes.

Theres a definite thread that runs through all mystic poetry of this sort through the mountains of asia into india and onwards into the middle east

John Vaillant writes incredibly interesting nonfiction accounts of the conflicts between people and the natural world in specific places. I absolutely recommend both of pic related books of his to anyone.
> The Tiger
about tigers, poaching, and human conflict in russia's far eat Amur River area
> Golden Spruce
conflict between enviros, natives, and loggers in Queen Charlotte Islands

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2009045
Also, anything by Jim Corbett. He was an army officer in British India tasked with tracking and shooting tigers and leopards who became man-eaters. Some of the tigers he was sent after had killed hundreds of people. He's not some trigger-happy big game hunter either—he has a deep respect for the animals he has to kill and writes about the tragedy of conflict between man and animal that led these creatures to become man eaters and need to be shot. He was a big advocate for conservation and protection of tigers. Pic related is a favorite of mine but anything by him is absolutely gold.
I like books about tigers.

name: Anonymous
com:

Another favorite is pic related. A relatively impartial account of three in-the field debates between people with very different views of how natural resources should be used. Whether you're a bleeding heart, chain-yourself-to-a-tree lib or an advocate of the extractive industries, this book will have a lot you agree with and a lot challenges your views

name: Anonymous
com:
Retards in this thread.
Not all combat boots are created equal. Pick militaries from nations with a lot of mountains and snow for good hiking boots; e.g Norway, Sweden. Don't buy used or surplus. Use good insoles. Wear thin liner socks (not too tight) under thicker woollen socks. Make sure the leather is full grain, no gore-tex. Treat with a few coats of leather cream or wax; mix a bit of pine tar with the cream before applying for more waterproofing (if you don't mind the smell).
My boots have served me extremely well for the past 2.5 years, walking through streams (the tongue is sewn and sealed to the boot upper so it's technically waterproof halfway up the shin) and snow and even days as warm as 20 Celsius without problems--except once during a very wet hike when I hadn't bothered to re-apply wax for some time.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1993146
You gotta read past the marketing bullshit. If it says oil/fat/grease, it will nourish the leather. If it says wax and only wax (like sno seal), it will impregnate your boots but not nourish the leather. (But wax will keep water out and oil in, which is pretty good too.) Good general purpose leather care products contain both. Also you have to be careful with the oil, because too much too often will soften the leather and make it spongy. Altberg explains it pretty well.
https://www.altberg.co.uk/bootcare/bootcare-advice

>>1990531
It all depends on their quality. That can vary significantly, there are some shitty shoes out there and there are some very good ones.
Usually government ordered mass produced stuff is pretty bad due to corruption, poor quality control and user feedback being ignored by powers that be.
On the other hand smaller batches ordered for elite/specialised units like paras or mountain troops have a better chance of turning out OK since end user opinion caries more weight in those circumstances.
Then there's civilian mil style shoes, again some better some worse, some cheaper some expensive, some somewhere in the middle. Quality of those in principle tend to be dependent on price but usually are much more comfortable even without the breaking in period then their mil standard counterpart.
I have worn out 3-4 pairs of standard mil each lasting 2-3 yrs depending on abuse inflicted. They were chaffing in the same places every time when new to a point where I've been putting plasters on my feet in those places as a prevention (surprisingly it did work) and the first few weeks they were creaking with every step. After that they were fine, fit for purpose, relatively cheap and easily available. (pic related)
Once I could afford it I got some better ones and never looked back ;P

I highly recommend milsurp boots for LARP and communist beating purposes, but apparent from this they are pretty useless.
>very very heavy
>difficult to dry
>likely to chafe badly, seeing as you didn't wear them in and sizing is tough
>don't ventilate particularly well
>time consuming to take on and off
On the basis of cost you might use then as work boots, but frankly they are usually overpriced- they do last forever because the uppers are leather and they can be re-soled.

I was one of those people who for years insisted on hiking in army boots, and all I achieved was getting foot rot twice and carrying a pound of rubber tied to me feet halfway around the world.

Depending on the climate and conditions many army canvas boots are great however, being light, easy to dry and relatively durable.
They make a good spare pair because they are light but can also be hiked in if required.

name: Anonymous
com:
I posted this in another thread, I'll leave it here.

Ohiofag here, from the SW area.

Over by Yellowsprings there's a giant area of parks connected, Glen Helen Preserve, John Bryan State Park, and Clifton Gorge. Incredible trails and a fairly large area all together. If you park at Glen Helen it has good access to the towns but a $5 fee. Don't park at any of the Clifton entrances or your car will be broken into.

Germantown Metropark and Twin Creek Metropark over by Kettering is really pleasant with some terrain that doesn't even really feel like Ohio in some spots. There's a connector trail between the two of them that connects them all together called the Twin Valley Trail that's a total of 22 miles. It's got a lot of steepness for Ohio, a lot of it situated on an Indian fort.

Caeser Creek Statepark is nice for fucking off in a random direction. There's a big loop at the bottom around the lake that's flanked by some pretty big unmarked sections that are reserved for hunters, but you can just slip in and disappear in the off-season.

Wayne NF is a blast. National Forests have much more relaxed rules than parks, so if you're into bushcrafty shit, it's a good time. Just make sure to take your shit down when you're done.

Zaleski SF is similarly lax. Really good destination for backpacking, cheap and good backcountry sites and a lot of trails. Also has a couple of historical sites if you're into that, there's an old iron forge and a few pieces of related abandoned infrastructure in the area.

If you're looking for a drive, Red River Gorge remains the top of my recommendations. It's in Kentucky, so a bit out of your way, but it's a must for any hiker in range. Massive sandstone cliffs and seriously challenging trails.

Another anon mentioned Hocking Hills, I'll second that. It's a great place to hike more technically challenging trails if that's your thing. Lots of unique and technical rocky trails.

name: Anonymous

>>2006921
Most of the parks I listed have trails short enough that I doesn't really matter which particular one you take, most will be similar.

For some of the bigger ones, I recommend the Twin Valley Trail at Germantown/Twin Creek Metropark, Backpacker Trail at Zaleski, Main Corridor Trail at Wayne, and the Perimeter Trail at Caeser.

RRG is considerably larger than all the other parks I listed, so for that, I'd really recommend section hiking the Sheltowee Trace. The full trail is just over 300 miles total, if that's your deal. My most recent trip took me through Bison Way, up to the Staircase and down across the River into a loop at the base of several trails. It was a 3-day weekend trip and very pleasant with a lot of scenery and fairly challenging hiking packed into a shorter trip. I can do a full write up on it, if you want.

Our main problem is the type of building there is to settle into. It works in Spain because there's a ton of abandoned villages that were built in feudal eras out of good hard stone and are still standing after being abandoned for decades. In America the equivalent town was made completely out of wood and has totally caved in.

I think the best plan is to find places that are just mostly abandoned: poor, destitute, etc, but enough people that the buildings are still intact. Bring a bandwagon of your own guys with your own industry and take over.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2003858
I wasn't all that into the scouting part of it at the time. I just really enjoyed camping with the other guys. We were a really tight knit group, 6-7 of us total (of those 15 and older). Keep in mind we did all car camping. On winter campouts, we'd set up two tents: a smaller one for our backpacks and a big one that we'd all sleep in together. The tent would get so warm from our body heat that we'd sleep in our base layers.
At one of the places we went, there was a huge pond that froze over in the winter, so we cleared out a strip of snow on it, got a few big container lids, and used them to slide across the ice.
Summer camp was a week long every year, and it included a few merit badge classes every day. We'd all sign up for the same badges so we could hang out all day. Then we'd head down to the shower house and dick around there and on the way.
When there was downtime at camp, especially when we were the only ones at that particular park or reservation, we'd all go "exploring," as in, hiking without any direction, just to find the weird plants or structures around the park.
I really miss those times.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2008308
Only warning about letting herbs and spices flower is that it effects the flavor. For example, basil gets pretty bitter after flowering.

Just food for thought.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2008351
>What are some novice mistakes I should avoid?
Do not overwater. I repeat, do NOT OVERWATER. Quite possibly the most common beginner's mistake of all time. Some plants of course require water more frequently/constantly than others, but the general rule of thumb is always allow the top to dry out before watering agin. If you press your finger down into the soil and it comes out moist, then there is water.

Additionally, if it's brand new soil, don't give in to the urge to give it even more fertilizer. That will oversaturate the plant, and for more tender ones, kill them.

All in all, simply allow the plant to grow, and react to its needs. The vast majority of the time, it will signal when something is wrong or missing. Know what the most common things are, such as NPK deficiencies, or over/underwatering, and respond accordingly.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2002975
Works well for the price. It's the baseline go-to fixed blade knife. It's not the most durable or best feeling but for the average person that just needs a tool to cut things there's no reason to spend more than $15 and get a mora. If you do more "survival-esque" outings you might find you want something a bit studier, but I think most people find it handles well enough and they won't need to spend more to upgrade.

>>2008314
Buy the metal cut proof gloves.
I wear my thick work cowhide gloves and a sharp knife will go through it like it was aluminum foil.
Also a good thing is learning how to make cuts and be held and slices.
I years ago, tend to have alot of strength and when the cut I was making slipped or broke through it would jam into my hand or fingers.
Take it easy and take the time to gain some feel for your tools and how whatever material you are carving reacts.
Learn patience in the beginning and as you get faster you will enjoy making things look easy.

name: Anonymous
com:
You need a knife.
Beyond that, progressively smaller tools for progressively smaller jobs. A saw, followed by a hatchet, maybe a chisel/gouge, a straight knife, maybe hook knife, then sandpaper.
Work out how big your finished product will be, add 1cm, cut. Trace an outline, cut. Trace details, cut.

If you're not working at a bench, don't bother with chisels and palm knives. You can't secure the work well enough to use them effectively or safely.

Check out a company called kuiu. Weird name good clothing.

This year I've been wearing an icebreaker merino wool base layer top and leggings, eastern mountain sports hiking pants and a tech t, a patagonia synchila fleece hoodie and a lands end down vest I've had kicking around for years. On the feet I've been using smart wool socks and a pair of asolo drifters that have to be going on ten years old. Great boots. Also, smart wool beanie, gloves and your standard buff. Super comfy. Almost forgot, I have a montbell rain shell too if needed. There's lots of good clothing out there. Don't focus too much on the brand. Just go with what's comfortable for you. Try to go to an outfitter if possible so you can try different things on. Online shopping can be a bit hit or miss as far as fit and sizing. Hope this helps fren.

Personally? I have expensive ass clothing gear, mainly, Terramar base layers and a $30 poncho. Works.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2004413
These will probably never turn anyone into a junkie. However, if you want to try some of the hallucinogenic amanitas, I'll give you a few pointers, just to lessen the potential damage, as these can be very unpredictable.

First of all, gather a bunch of them, preferably A. muscaria, as like you said, they are a bit weaker than the pantherinas. What you're going to do, is to familiarize yourself with the effects. Basically, start with microscopic doses and work your way up over a few weeks or months until you get the effects you're looking for.

With larger doses, it's generally safer to split the dose into smaller doses that you take over the course of an evening.

Whatever you do, make sure you cure them properly. Drying them the right way is crucial in order to make them less toxic. Also don't consume any carbonated drinks once you've ingested the fungi. Although they are considered toxic, they're not very potently so. At least not when compared to other members of the Amanita genus. So long as you pace yourself, and don't scarf down 2lbs of the fucking things like a retard, you'll be fine.

I've never really gotten any hallucinations from them except one very brief second when the wall wobbled kind of like the paintings in Super Mario 64. The effects I get from them are mainly physical, and they don't really feel like anything else. I guess the best way I can explain it is that it's a mix between a mild ethanol buzz and a cannabis high. It's honestly great for when you just want to watch movies and play games.

>consume half of medium sized hat, raw

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2004436
No problem. One last thing, I'll just go over the basic chemistry behind it, as it is kind of important.
These amanitas contain two main compounds, ibotenic acid and muscimol. They're both hallucinogenic, but the ibotenic acid is more... sickening, I guess you could say, than the muscimol.
What happens when you dry the fungi, is that you basically remove one carboxyl group from the ibotenic acid molecule, and turns it into carbon dioxide and muscimol. In other words, it becomes a bit more potent and less toxic at the same time. It's also why you shouldn't drink carbonated beverages with it, as the carbon dioxide present in those will bind with the muscimol and turn it back into ibotenic acid, which will mainly make you vomit and sweat like a pig. You're probably aware of this, but I'll just post it in case someone else wanted to know.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2004413
Great haul last year, can't wait for next season. In order from left to right

>Morels, Morchella conica
Found a 4lb batch growing in an urban flower allotment. First time ever finding morels as they are super rare here so i decided to risk the dog shit, cleaned them well and dried. Amazing taste/texture, definitely on my top 3. Made some ramen and calzone from these.

>Porcini/Cep, Boletus edulis
Best year for these by far, i must have picked around 15-20 lbs. Dried these as well since im not so fond of the texture when cooked fresh. They give great flavour tho especially in soups and stews.

>Matsutake, Tricholoma matsutake
This was an interesting one. I was hiking with my father and i happened upon these beautiful specimens which i immediately recognized as matsutake. This would be grade A in Japan, small, firm caps that have yet to open. Sadly since we were out in the middle of nowhere with no internet we couldn't risk a potential missidentification. Later at home i did some research and boy do i regret not biting the bullet and trying these. Turns out there are a couple closely related species in the genus Tricholoma that are sold as "Matsutake" but Finland is the only place where you can find the exact same species as in Japan which is the mushroom pictured here. A lot of "matsutake" is imported to Japan from mainland asia but that is actually a different species. I hope to find these again

>Funnel Chantarelle, Craterellus tubaeformis
These have been my bread and butter ever since i started foraging as a kid, great yield, flavor and ease of use. This year i only picked 8-10 lbs or so, i often freeze these but now i dried them. I like to keep these whole and use in sauces or fried in a pan.

Apart from these i also found some Lactifluus volemus (a type of milk-cap[?]) which is also pretty rare and delicious. Some say it tastes faintly like lobster or crayfish, with some dill and cream added i can almost say the same. No picture for these sadly.

>>2005914
F. betulina is actually a medicinal fungus. It wreaks havoc on intestinal parasites. It's also mildly antiseptic, so if you're ever caught with an open wound and no first aid kit, you can slice off a piece of F. betulina and slap it on the wound like a compress.
Aside from that, you can use its leathery surface to strop your edged tools.
All in all, not very good eatin', but still very useful.
>I think A. velosa is only a west coast US guy
Yeah, that's what I found out. I'm thousands of miles away from the west coast of the US, lol.

name: Anonymous
com:
Save as much money as you can

Don’t carry tons of cash. Camping around rail yards/bridges will cause a lot of run in with aggressive junkies who’ll shake you down and threaten to stab you to get their next hit. Showing you only have $10-$20 in your wallet and giving it to them to fuck off is recommended.

Buy a membership for one of the large gym chains. It’ll give you shower/bathroom access in most cities.

Train hopping is too slow and dangerous. Hitchhiking is very safe (far safer than train hopping) and it’s far quicker. Don’t hitchhike at night. Have your witts about you. Plus in some states the worst punishment you’ll get for hitchhiking would likely be a slap in the wrist and the police telling you to fuck off. Meanwhile getting buses by train yard bulls could land you in prison for a few days and/or fines ranging between $250 and $2000

It's a shitty life anon.
Maybe it's better than where you're at, that's your call.
Not only are you venerable, you don't have a safety net either.
People just assume you're drifting because you've committed a crime somewhere, take drugs or are otherwise the architect of your own suffering.
If a drug addict randomly assaults you, don't expect anyone to care- they just assume you were somehow at fault.
If someone steals or damages your equipment, nobody is going to care- they just assume you were somehow at fault.
If you can't meet the administrative requirements of the system any more, for instance you don't have a postal address, can't make bail, can't provide a residential adress, don't have a working/charged phone, aren't clean to go into a office- the system sees fit to fuck you unapologetically.

It's not just people "on the street" who are going to be a problem for you, ordinary folk will as well.
You might get charged extra at a shop 'for being dirty', you might do work for someone and them refuse to pay you, you might get kicked out of somewhere you had permission to stay in the middle of the night, you are going to get moved on from a public place you've got every right to be in, while doing something you have every right to do.
If you don't accept that and fight back, you're going to get arrested and dumped in the middle of nowhere without your equipment.

2/10 would not recommend

name: Anonymous
com:
Basic List of Essentials for Homeless Life (in America)

Shelter: Depends on your surroundings. Tent for cold and wet areas, hammock for warm and dry areas.

Tent: lightweight, enclosed, hold heat well, easy to use. Only need a tent big enough to lay down and stretch your legs. Smaller the tent the better, especially for heat. Bulky, can be hard to carry effectively and troublesome to camouflage. Need clear level ground to deploy.

Hammock: easy to carry, comfortable, versatile. the go-to to for sleeping anywhere. Trivial to camouflage. Takes a certain degree of skill to use effectively, troublesome to shield from the elements. Use tarp and p-cord to provide cover from rain. Need two anchor points close to each other to deploy.

Keep your camp hidden and move often. If you need to build a fire, place campfire beneath a big tree or build a dakota fire hole.

Buy region specific colored tarp, p-cord, knife, machete, garden shovel, backpack, few metal clothes hangers or metal stakes, lighters, zipties, plastic bags, multivitamins, baby wipes, pen and paper, duct tape, hygiene supplies and a five gallon bucket. Off ya go then.

Transportation: Highly recommended to give a vehicle. Vehicles arent cheap to maintain but the benefits far outweigh the costs, main one being storage and emergency shelter. Otherwise invest in a bicycle you can ride.

Food: choices are to live near town with soup kitchens at least a day a week and ample opportunities for work and dumpster diving, or live out in the wilderness with the skills necessary to live off the land. The amount of knowledge and experience required for the latter is beyond the scope of this post.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1990655
Panhandling: best ways to earn are sign flying and performing.
Sign flyers need mobility to maximize profits, operate in high traffic intersections or interstate rest stops. Protip: if cops
Performance or busting can be dance, singing, rapping, playing an instrument etc. Ability to play an instrument helps alot. If you cant play an instrument to save your life, buy a harmonica. Selling items can land you in hot water without permits.
Find a church and go at least once a month, even if you arent religious. You need a community outside of your homeless community.

Safety & Defense: Always have a smartphone on you with at least 50% charge. Even if you have no intention of buying service, you can still dial 911 and absolutely should take advantage if your in a dire situation.
On your journey it is inevitable you will run into law enforcement. Cops can be your best friend or worst enemy. Try to make them your best friend.
Avoid fights at all cost. This isnt the movies, this is real life. Fights out here are dirty and unfair. Death is a very real possibility.
If your assailant is alone and you are not ambushed, draw your machete. A machete is great for intimidation but cumbersome in a fight with anything other than an unarmed bum. If faced with multiple assailants, escape. If mugged, give them what they want. Your life is more important that your gear.
Even in America you will not be able to carry around a firearm without being properly established. Even if you can, employ the same principles. Self-defense should always be a last resort. You will always receive less trouble if your attacker is alive rather than dead.

Hygiene & Laundry: 24 he gyms and laundromats or a 5 gallon bucket and a water source. The more buckets you have, the better.

These are just basics. Everyone's situation is different and it is up to you to adapt and overcome. Find out what works for you and most importantly just dont die lmao.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1980736
I enjoyed it, but I was doing it for fun not because I had to, and I knew it would be temporary. I'm also not addicted to anything besides caffeine and nicotine, so being able to keep my wits about me was helpful. Best part was not having to worry about being on anyone else's schedule, worst part was long stretches between water. Probably worth noting though that I have some pretty decent survival skills, and spent most of my time between towns rather than in them. No idea what it would be like to be homeless in a city for more than an afternoon.

I did this after getting waiting 2 months for the results of a biopsy that ended up showing a lump as benign. For two months I was at a loss, and it culminated in my quitting my job and hoofing around while I was young. I was 22 when I set out from small town to small town with a 50lbs pack on, walking rail tracks and roads and camping innawoods along the way. It was lonely, at times scary, people were curious but not impressed when they asked me what I was doing which hurt. I wanted to be interesting, but this is now how it was perceived. The loneliness was the worst part. It was horrible. I went further into a depression and it was very hard to pull myself out. The loss a working year made it so ai had to start at the bottom at a new job unrelated to my education because I had several interviews that left me feeling embarrassed when they brought up my hiatus. None liked the sound of hiring a hobo, I could tell. I never recovered to the point at which I'd be now if I didn't do it, and I gained nothing from it. The only way I'd recommend it is if you know you don't want to go back to an average life afterwards but would instead like to be a hobo forever or kill yourself when you're done walking. The hobos I met were always creeps abd disgusting. There is no glamor nor glory, and I truly believe no benefits at all from pursuing this to advance your self or state of mind. It is only for people running away from responsibilities and from socialization

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1991426
>any of y'all got advice
What do you want to do? You said 'hobo'. That typically means 'working traveler'. Finding work in small tourist towns is probably going to be easiest, especially at hotels and hostels where you can take part of your pay as room and board, because you'll need a reliable place to shower and shave first and foremost. I've also had a lot of people offer me work while hitching rides in and out of places, especially farm work where they expect to be providing those utilities to transient workers anyway. As far as encouragement, it's definitely possible, but probably harder work than you'd find wherever you're already at, just with the freedom of it usually being pretty temporary.

>>1991478
>Im afraid to throw it all away to fly halfway around the world with nothing to chase the dream of a child.
That seems a bit extreme. I failed and had to come back and reevaluate more times than I know, because it does require a lot of practiced skills. It seems to me that what you'd probably enjoy most would be buying some land as a personal occasional retreat and keeping your life in the order that you're accustomed to otherwise. That way, you wouldn't be risking giving everything up, but could still do the things you want to do whenever the desire strikes, without committing to it as an entire lifestyle.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1991596
>if i was to be there forever my clothes would wear out.
All gear does, and you need a plan to replace things periodically, which means either working or panhandling, even if it's only occasionally. As far as returning to society goes, that's a definite risk, but you are young enough to pull off the 'I wanted to travel Europe before settling into a career' excuse. My biggest concern for you is that you mentioned that your mental health is 'pure shite'; if you mean that you're disenchanted with society and progress and feel more comfortable with living life at your own pace, then you're probably in the same position as myself, where you'd find you need that freedom. If you mean that you have a clinical mental problem, I'd recommend seeking help to work through those issues and maybe get something to level you out, because if you have those types of difficulties, they won't just magically go away if you run from them. You have to be pretty introspective and self-critical here, because if you do it for the wrong reasons, it won't go well. If you can normally handle weeks in the wilderness, you're probably better equipped than most, but again, be critical, it's not an easy life. Also, I'm not familiar with UK law, so you need to do your own research regarding what kinds of difficulties you'd face in that regard; in the US, there's pretty much just a 16 day limit before I have to move again, which I find to be about the right amount of time to stay in one place anyway.

What's with all you faggots that think /out/ is just for the weekend?

I hitchhiked around Australia for a few years. Bathed regularly at truck stops, universities, beaches and rivers. Washed my clothes in beaches, rivers and buckets. Slept on beaches, in the bush, in the city and on rooftops. Ate out of bakery and supermarket dumpsters because I never learned to hunt and forage. It gets lonely after a while but it's a fair price to have all of your time to yourself. Don't know why everyone is conflating someone on /out/ with the mentally ill/drug addicts that aren't homeless by preference. Nor why anybody would think at all to be anywhere near them. They're fucking retarded and will bring you nothing but trouble. They might be homeless but they're not good at it.

Do have some cash before you head off though. It's always handy for getting out of the city and when shit happens (like being in the city). Sometimes the dumpsters are empty/locked, your shit gets wet and you need to go to a laundromat and sometimes shit just doesn't go your way and it's nice to have a good meal. And if you've never felt the generosity of strangers, damn is it a good feeling.

Look up volunteering for hostels. Very easy way to get poon too. I had gf's everytime I was doing it, but if I was single back then I could have fucked a lot. You can also volunteer on farms with helpx, etc. Just get a good deal that is no more than 20 hours of easy work per week for accomodation and food. Best volunteering experience I had was in Dublin where I did less than 16 hours weekly, mostly buying milk or cleaning out empty parts of building on my own and in my own pace. On farmsteads, etc. the accomodation is most often private room or even a seperate house, but in hostels it's typically shared. Benefit with hostels is that they're in relevant cities and it is easy to stay at a hostel, work part time there and do something like waiting tables somewhere else part time for cash-in hand to save up. Ignore all the tards saying you shouldn't do this because you'll somehow magically wind up being a homeless bum. Be a drifter, not a random bum. Look into getting a good backpack. This website is useful if you ever hitchhike (safe thing to do, fuck trainhoppign unless you really want the experience):
https://hitchwiki.org/en/Main_Page
There's loads of ways to travel with very little and to enjoy yourself. Hope you are still around to read this, but don't give up on life just because you're in a shit spot. Go and do what you want to.

I bring a single titanium pot that nests with my metal nalgene. Its the perfect size for me, and anything that wouldn't fit (like large cuts of meat) can just be spitroasted over the fire anyways. Only weighs around 100g and takes next to no space. I can't see myself switching to something much heavier and bulkier anytime soon. Maybe if you're cooking for multiple people or doing historical reenactment cast iron would be best, but otherwise it just makes sense to stick with newer options.

name: Anonymous

>>2009049
Not him, but sun protection is the obvious one.

Really it’s specific to certain environments, but it excels in those areas. A rain jacket is pretty universal, but in the Gulf South it’s just too warm for any kind of jacket most of the year. The type of rain we get in late spring through the summer is usually caused from moist air from the Gulf of Mexico creating sporadic, scattered showers with little or no wind, followed by periods of sunshine. Typical tropical/subtropical patterns. A jacket or poncho is absolute hell in those conditions.

In more temperate areas and deserts the shade is a no-brainer. And again if it’s brief periods of rain without much wind an umbrella is much more handy than a jacket.

com:

name: Anonymous
com:
Wool + canvas is the way to go if you plan on staying outdoors for long. Things are going to get damp,things are going to get wet, and things are going to get abrasive. Down, synethtics, are just not up to the task. They're great for a short term camp, holiday, etc. But if you plan on sticking it out there for long, you better carry wool and canvas. It don't take much to tear up a fancy modern sleeping bag, or inflatable mat. But canvas and wool will last you a lifetime. I speak from experience.
The old ways are the ways. I pack my blanket, and all my clothing and shelter equipment inside a canvas tarp. The other items I need immediate access to go on the outside, like a hatchet, my knife on my belt, cup tied to the pack, and cooking set on my belt in a canvas belt pack.

com: I do carry some modern stuff. A british mil rip stop nylon tarp barely weights a thing and doesnt adsorb water. A mylar foam mat that weights less than a dime as well. These are not long lasting items, but they help a lot.

com: Of course I use paracord for tying the pack down, and nylon backpack straps as well.

It will feel awkward at first. Being experienced can make it feel strange learning a new skill. Revel in the noobishness, you can only learn something for the first time once
>>1985260
Not a larp, I literally heard someone on the lift say "Holy shit, look at that!" don't know if they were talking about me but it felt bretty good

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1985324
remember how much you sucked as a beginner? a big part of the problem people have going switch is that they have the option to avoid it so they do. force yourself to ride only switch at least one day a week, start on stuff that's more mellow than you think you can handle, take the falls. just as important imo is to get really comfortable coming in fakie. pipe is good for practicing that but if you have any kind of hips wallrides etc that'll work too. fakie tailpress is helpful as well

in your free time, practice jumping down/over/on things in switch stance. try to find a balance beam or even better a slack line and get used to jumping into switch 50. once that's comfortable, start adding spins

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1991924
yea no problem, and yes while you can use any ski for "open ski" groomed trails, there is a maximum width that will fit into the channels at nordic centers/other skiers ski track. Most nordic centers that groom will have a wide lane of groomers with a lane for skate, the channels for classic/nordic and then usually some room left over for other use.

Most classic/nordic skis are the very skinny kind you usually see at nordic centers, these struggle anywhere but on groomed trails. I have two pairs of XC skis, one is a rossignol OT 65 and the other is the rossignol BC 80. The offtrack 65 has fish scales underfoot (as opposed to waxing your skis with grippy wax) and is skinny enough to fit into classic tracks but is a little wider to handle a couple inches of powder. My BC 80's are way too wide for nordic centers but have more float for powder and also a full metal edge, so they're a lot better in the backcountry. The wider ski also doesn't track as straight nor is as fast as a super skinny XC ski so there's trade offs. A lot of the fun of nordic skiing is zooming around and logging a lot of miles and if you live near to a nordic center or somewhere with lots of ski use (ie a ski track will be laid down in the snow) this could be a fun option. If you want a bit of both I'd recommend something like the Rossi OT 65 Evo, has a partial metal edge, can still use at nordic and is pretty quick too. That being said I use my BC 80's more because they're more versatile, I took them out for ~15 mile BC tour in RMNP yesterday.

I don't mind answering any other questions you have, its all a bit confusing at first. Also depends largely on what you want to do, but try not to balk at the price tag and kind accept that having a quiver of skis/boots is a good thing, down the line.

backcountry skiing /out/doorsmen, my bad.

>>1995692
there are 3 parts to this question, skis, bindings, boots.
>skis
buy new skis, they're worth the money as you'll get way more mileage out of them than buying a used pair. BUT DONT BUY THIS SEASONS SKIS. Any big ski shop will have pairs of brand new skis in plastic that were made last season or the season before, buy these save several hundred. If you're really new, there's 3 main characteristics to worry about.
Length, shorter means tighter turns more manuverable, longer means better at handling rough terrain. Generic is right around your height
Width, mostly for surface area of your ski, bigger skis mean you float more in powder, but make it much harder to get up on edge quickly and hold it in icy conditions, as the edge is no longer located under your footprint.
Camber, effects the same things as width (floating and edging) but in a different way, read an article about it.
>Bindings
Someone out there will tell me I'm stupid but I've skied for ~20 years and have never had bindings change the way I ski. Find the cheapest pair you can at a thrift store that don't look like total shit and have DIN's high enough for you level of skiing, might have to buy them attached to an old shitty pair of skis (viola, you also have rock skis for early season) and have them mounted to your shiny new skis when you buy them.
>boots
Spend some money and time cause these will make or break a day, trip, season. Go find a big ski store very close to a mountain and see if you can demo multiple boots in a day. Spend an hour or 2 in them on the slopes, less if they feel like shit, then swap them out for a better pair. The guys in the shop will know what they are doing. At a place like big 5, REI, cabelas, ect. where skiing is just a part of the store it can be really hit or miss if the guys are top notch or not so i generally steer away from those places. buy the boots you like or try to find them cheaper online

>>1995788
I’m the same height and weight and have the same skis (carbon version) as my main midwinter setup. When avy danger is high, like it will be here in SLC for the whole winter probably, I usually ski spots that are 25-30 degrees that I jnow I can get to without crossing under dangerous slopes. 25 degrees should be plenty to link turns on even in deep powder. I bring an inclinometer when going to a new spot to make sure that I’m staying in safe terrain. Taking aaire 1 will help you to better understand avalanches and how to travel in the backcountry if you haven’t already don the course. I would also recommend reading Staying Alive in Avalanche Terrain whether you have taken the course or not. I’ve only skied the Sierras in spring/winter but I hear the snow tends to be quite a bit heavier than in the rockies so skinnier skis might help but most likely you just need to adjust your technique and terrain.

Stowe is now a whopping 120+ bucks per day....so I would save my cash and hit up Bolton, mondays are 39 and weekdays are 59....no night skiing on mondays but rest of week your day pass is good till 10 pm.

Everything Stowe has can be found at Bolton but at half the price. Stowe has the Gondola and makes itself seem larger with a side mtn that takes up the opposite ridge, but they were bought by Vail and are bombing out hard as is Sugarbush, as they just shitcanned their 25 yr veteran for a good laugh.

Bolton's Best in order from Number One to OK

Adam's Solitude (woods)
Lost Boys (woods)
Devil's Playground (woods) / Preacher (approach trail)
Vista Glades (woods)
Vermont 200 (trail)
Spellbinder (trail)

Get your tickets ahead of time as they are selling out fast there this year

I've even seen lakes still having ice at the end of August. Can you believe that? Much higher altitude, but it still surprised me.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2009011
It always blows my mind too, although it makes perfect sense. I live next to Alps on Piemontese side, and even in summer the highest peaks still have ice and frost. Even a difference between a small peak that is 800 meters tall is noticeable; while there is no snow around here at the moment, up there is certaintly good skiing and snowboarding right now.
I'd be tempted to take a freezing dip in that lake btw.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2009099
Yeah, it makes sense when you think about it. That little lake is in a position where it only gets sunlight in the morning and evening, so it will be much colder throughout the day than nearby areas. If the winter is very snowy and the summer not too hot, the snow cover will protect the ice far into July and the meter thick ice will then take a long time to melt. Winter can return to the mountains already in September, so that ice and snow might not have melted at all that year.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2009077
Use google maps, look at the satellite view, and turn on street view. Look at the largest area's on the map that have none of the blue road or picture markers. Look for an area you like and do a closer search for an area that you want to stay at, also looking to avoid smaller roads that you can see with the areal view but that aren't marked.

Use this in conjunction with the National Forest service map to see if there are hiking trails or whatnot in or around the area. This map will also let you see streams and creeks and can offer Intel on other stuff you may want to know.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1987180
It's way easier than you think it might be. I biked from Denver to New York City a couple years ago and it's really amazing how easy it was.

-That said, invest in a high-quality cycling bib with chamois. Like, go to a specialty store and spend $100 on it. You will thank me. I used one pair during my entire 2-month trip and not ONCE did I ever experience a sore on my perineum.
-You don't need fancy-ass cycling shoes and lock-in pedals. A pair of comfortable shoes will suffice, but DO get straps for your pedals. Makes a huge difference in how much energy you use while cycling.
-Bring a small cleaning kit and give your gears/chain a light cleaning at least twice a week. You're putting a lot of miles on a bike compared to any riding you do for fun in the city.
-Get a high-quality pair of tires for the bike if it doesn't already have one. For comparison, the stock tires on my bike lasted 900 miles before practically disintegrating whereas a new pair from Giant were hardly worn when I finished 1100 miles later. Needing a new innertube on the road is no big deal. Needing a new tire can be a trip-ender. One of the stock tires broke while I was in small-town Missouri, and the closest shop that carried 700c tires was 94 miles away, and I had to spend an entire day looking for a ride. If I hadn't met a nice church pastor, I might have had to do dark shit to get a ride.
-Get a small bike computer, even a cheap one from Walmart. The odometer is extremely useful for navigation, and the speedometer really helps you find your most efficient gearing, as well as also aiding in navigation.
-Other than that it's not much different from a hiking trip, and the gear you bring is almost identical.

name: Anonymous
com:

based. I've only done 100 miles in 1 day but it was surprisingly easy. once I left the city.

>high-quality cycling bib with chamois
could be useful for extreme distances where you can't just pedal standing up for a bit or take a break to smoke a joint.

>DO get straps for your pedals. Makes a huge difference in how much energy you use while cycling
besides front handlebars, this is one other accessory I could see being useful. using regular pedals put unnecessary stress on my outer calves because of the "pulling up" motion.

>high-quality pair of tires for the bike
only gatorskins here, lasted an estimated 5000 miles (I've only had to replace one so far). I should also mention quality brake pads: continental salmons. the bike itself can be cheap bike boom surplus, but the rubbers gotta be top quality.

>small bike computer
meme

one other thing to mention: disassemble your bike one part at a time. disassemble each part completely and polish it with blue magic/#0000 steel wool. submerge the disassembled metal parts in a cast iron full of mineral oil and bake at 300F for 1 hr. wipe clean and reassemble. your bike is now so buttery smooth that it anticipates your slightest intentions

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1992722
>small bike computer
>meme
It's very useful for navigation, because when you're mapping out your route you can mark your turns based on mileage, which is displayed on the computer. The speedometer is useful for the reason I mentioned. It's difficult to tell a difference of +/-1mph, but the computer knows, and you can adjust your gearing on the fly for the best speed. Doesn't sound like much but that is potentially 8-10 miles per day lost, and over the course of a month it's fucking huge.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1992971
>How many did you buy for your trip? A pair, switching every day?
I only had one bib, but I hung it dry at the end of every day and put a small amount of baby powder on it to kill and bacteria etc. If I had more money I would have bought two, but it wasn't necessary.
>How many clothes did you have and how did you manage the cleaning/drying part?
I had two pairs of clothes: Cycling and resting. My cycling clothes were the bib and a long-sleeve sport shirt. Resting clothes were shorts and a comfy t-shirt, and two pairs of underwear. And a hat for sun protection. I washed them as often as I could when stopping in small towns and using the local laundromat or the motel's facilities while I was there.
>Also how long did your Denver->NYC trip took and did you sleep outside all the time?
It took 58 days, which included an occasional day of rest. I slept outside most of the time but I stayed in cheap motels a couple times a week. Usually I slept in local parks, churchyards after getting permission from the leader, friendly strangers' backyards, behind abandoned buildings in ghost towns, and local campgrounds. If I didn't see anything obvious on Google maps I talked to people in gas stations, churches, local bars to find spots.
>Thoughts on tubeless tires?
Complete meme. They're heavy as fuck compared to air tubes and they sag way more, so the overall ground resistance is massive in comparison. You'll travel much slower, traveling shorter distances, and being more tired at the end of the day. I tested out a pair while training and it was insane how crap they are.
>>1992989

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1992989
>Also, forgot to ask what kind of bike you used for your trip
I rode a used Schwinn Trailway I paid $130 for from some local bike mechanic on Craigslist. Dude was an autistic tinkerer who got divorced by the love of his life and has since dedicated his life to doing nothing but purchasing old bikes and fixing them up for sale in his sub-level apartment. He basically did what >>1992722 was talking about with disassembling the entire bike, adjusting every part, and polishing/lubing every surface before putting it back together. I've ridden $500+ new bikes that haven't been as smooth.
>and what kind of terrain you were riding on.
I rode on roads all the way until Pittsburgh, after which I took the Great Allegheny Passage/C&O Canal Trail for about 200 miles to Hagerstown, MD, which was a fucking BLAST and I highly recommend doing it. It was dirt trail until Cumberland, MD, but after that it was fucking muddy and boggy wetlands for like 80 miles. I'm talking like 3-6inches of soaking mud and water. Every "dry" section was a godsend. It was hilarious though, because I kept passing all these guys riding $1000+ off-road bikes with specialty handlebars and super-wide tires, while I'm flying through on a $130 Schwinn with hybrid road tires and 40lbs of gear over my rear tire. I had to learn to let the bike drift and slide through mud and just gently guide it, but I never fell over or had to put my foot down once. The only problem I encountered was that my pedal crankset rusted and broke, which basically rendered my bike unusable. But by sheer luck, it broke not even 100 yards from a bike shop located just off-trail as it passed through a small town, and I got it replaced for like $40. Also before going on the trail I had to fashion a set of mudguards from carboard, duct tape, and zip ties, so I would recommend getting real ones instead.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1993661
>Regarding tubeless tires, I think your opinion on them might come from the fact that you were riding on roads.
Possibly, yeah. I've never ridden tubeless off-road so I can't attest to how they handle compared to air tubes.
>Speaking of which, how the hell did you manage riding on american roads for so long?
There's hardly any traffic on state highways and back roads, especially compared to interstate highways, and you have an open view for miles and miles. I usually rode on the oncoming side of the road so I could see when the next car was. Then when I saw one, I'd switch to the other side of the road until it passed, then switched back. Makes it so you never have to worry about cars behind you.
>Even in Europe I would get pretty nervous so I imagine that could become a nightmare in the US.
The US is practically a wasteland west of the eastern seaboard in comparison to the population density of Europe. The country is still wild in a lot of parts, man.
>Btw, how was your bag setup? I'd love to see pictures of your setup and trip if you got any, you could make an imgur album.
Unfortunately I don't have any pictures available at the moment, but I can tell you about my setup. I had a cheap rear rack that I mounted cheap saddle bags and a top bag to, all told was about 50L of space. I had a large triangle bag in the frame where I kept my tools and spare parts, and then a handlebar bag where I kept my important personal belongings and snacks for the day. And on top of the handlebars I tied a sleeping bag to. Really simple setup, cost me less than $200 total.
