Bikepacking community is culty. It's all about selling you the latest gear/bikes (this is literally what bikepacking.com does), when in reality, you can use whatever bike you have laying around in the shed and some cheap bags off amazon or panniers.

There are also some really cool people I've met bikepacking who see through the culty gearfagging shit that is bikepacking.com and see bikepacking for what it really is. Which is simply riding a bike for whatever reason you desire.

If you wanna go ride the GDMBR (tour divide), then go do it. Just don't buy into the idea that you need thousands of dollars of gear and a drop bar carbon fibre gravel bike.

Out of all my years of touring, the dopest people I met are usually the ones who just said fuckit and left on the beater bike that they already had. People who aren't out there for instagram likes or clout, but for their own reasons--to see the world, to meet new people, etc..

I can only speak for a 100-mile ride in familiar territory. the only time I needed a map was leaving the god-forsaken city (irregular triangle intersections next to public commons that lead to rotaries with exits onto one-way streets going the wrong way)

after that it was a straight line for 90 miles, a left turn onto the only possible road (route 6A), and another straight line for 10 more miles.

I did buy a really bright front light for the trip, which I obviously never need in the city, and I'm glad I did.

a cycle computer would be useful and less distracting/douchey than a smartphone mount for longer trips. but the only bike accessory I would consider mandatory is a rearview mirror. more important than a helmet IMO.

if you want good info from someone who did take a longer trip (Denver --> NYC) and used a cycle computer to good effect, read >>1992616 and followups.

A lot of touring bikes use drop bars on them for some insane reason. That's why they all look like road bikes. I usually use flat or a riser bar on mine. One hipster was asking about my road bike and I told him tightly if you look a little more carefully to see it's actually a Touring bike with just flat bar on it. Mine is gorgeous one made by Naked Bike from Quadra Island. It has S&S torque coupler so you can break it down with the wrench into a 26 by 26 by 10 inch suitcase for travel.


Mine only cost me $1,100. The hundred bucks off the price because somehow he lost the special wrench for the torque couplers. It's quite nice, it has a custom flowered paint job with the under colour is some sort of orange bronze with a bit of glitter in it. Lots of rack mounts in Fender mounts plus it has the heavier tubing and Fork meant for loaded touring.

I like the fact that it has a standard rear axle spacing of 135 mm oh, I have found a bob trailer that I can take on it.

name: Anonymous

>>2009150
Moustache bars. I wouldn't necessarily recommend them, they are actually more racy than I expected. But I got the super short n tall step so it works out. Also those are friction bar end shifters

I think kick stands are not needed 90% of the time but a touring bike is where they are actually useful. You can't always just lay down a bike when it's got 50lbs of gear bags strapped on wherever. I think the best kickstands ar the ones that have two legs and prop up the rear wheel so you can do basic maintenance. At least in theory, I actually haven't taken this bike >30 miles yet (gay snow and work)

Btw a big back pack (or even a duffle bag) strapped to a cheap rack will work fantastic for short trips and still have great capacity. Bike bags are just a bit nicer, good for long trips.
Protip for poorfag waterproofing, just put a garbage bag inside your regular bag.

Aluminum doesn't leach into food at any reasonable quality at common cooking temperatures.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2002864
>Those men really were tougher back then
They really weren't. The concept here is to use the best gear that's available. Since the quality of gear inproved steadily over the decades, it made things easier, but that doesn't make people in the past in any way tougher.
Consider this:
Reaching the peak of Mont Blanc was a big achievement in 1800 and considered a perilous journey that required a group of almost 100 people to put a single person on the peak, +20 people for each additional guy reaching the summit.
By 1900, it was a good training exercise for seasoned alpinists, required a crew of 20 people.
By 1930s, it was a non-challenge for alpinists and first tourists were pulling this off
By 1980s, it became something a random schmuck could do on a weekend with minimal prep (assuming he wasn't obese)

So by your logic, people were actually weak as fuck back in the day. After all, if they were all so damn tough, we should see that climb to be an easy feat for everyone and their dog, like it is today.

name: ScubaAnon

Previous thread: >>1824459

SCUBA = Self-Contained Underwater Breathing Apparatus

Share your most memorable dives here, good and bad.
Post pictures, videos, and memes.
Brag about certs, experience, and achievements.
Discuss/recommend equipment, techniques, and otherwise share your love for diving in general,
Divers of all levels welcome, as well as people thinking about diving.

Guide:
https://github.com/ScubaAnon/scuba-diving-general/blob/master/sdg.md
Feel free to contribute to it either directly or indirectly through the thread.

name: ScubaAnon
com:
FAQ:
>Why bother?
It's a pretty based hobby if you like getting wet. Staying and breathing underwater for longer periods of time exposes you to a completely different world and experience. You should at least try this once in your lifetime. Also, there's no talking underwater (except occasional hand signals), so you won't have to deal with nagging from other people except for a short period on the surface.
>Is it expensive?
Any hobby has its expenses. If you choose to own your own gear instead of renting it you'll quickly drive up quite a hefty cost. However, if you turn out to be an active diver the initial investment is usually worth it over time.
>Isn't SCUBA diving dangerous?
Yes, you could die with very little effort (hold your breath and ascend: boom, you're dead). You should keep this in mind every time you dive. The risk is worth it though, and quite low when it comes to recreational diving between or shallower than 18-20 meters.
>Can I dive alone?
Only if you accept x2 the risk of dying.

name: ScubaAnon
com:
>>1914692
FAQ (continued):
>Where do I start?
Get certified (beware Koh Tao in Thailand though). There are many organizations who certify divers, notable among them PADI, SSI, GUE, CMAS. PADI is probably the largest organization, but is usually a little more expensive than alternatives. Before even getting certified though practice only breathing through your mouth.
>Why learn breathing only through your mouth?
Besides likely getting water in your mask while diving at some point, there's mask flooding and mask off exercises in the course. You don't want to bolt to the surface in a panic because you suddenly snorted some water. To practice this skill, try snorkeling with swimming goggles (which won't cover your nose).
>Where to dive?
The guide is sparse for now, but if you can't find anything there then ask ITT.
>Best way to log dives?
Subsurface is free as in freedom software for logging and planning dives, and it's quite possibly the best software out there. A physical logbook is also fine and should probably be used in conjunction with it.

name: Anonymous
com:
Some of the best dives I've had :
- in the Andaman Islands(specifically from Nicobar island) you used to have dives that went out to Barren Island, one the most pristine diving sites I've had the privilege of seeing, I'm talking field's of corals going out around as far as you can see with a sheer rock wall on your one side with 60-50 meters of clarity.
- did several diving safaris in Sinai that were always fun as hell that also included great clarity and beats colors, a huge biosphere of different corals and fish
- amazing night dives in Eilat, but its basically the less awesome version of Sinai cause its the tip of the red sea and its a tourist city so the reef is pretty beat up there.

I used to work as a dive instructor from early 2016 till late 2018 in Eilat(yea I'm a shekel chasing jew), started out as an assistant instructor(SDI), did my PADI instructor course at Koh Tao late 2017 and spent a couple of months on the island, came back, crossovered to SDI instructor and did my final season teaching courses. Had to leave because my ears couldn't handle the workload anymore and I was spent mentally and physically. If anyone is thinking about this as a profession I highly recommend it. The path is hard but it forces you out of your shell and develop social skills and by God you just feel cool doing it, plus your out and moving and seeing beautiful nature all day.

If anyone has questions I'll try and answer as best as I can. Maybe write a more comprehensive thread going in a bit more detail about the workings of things.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1934960
How much did you make? How skilled were you when you became an instructor? I am new to diving but I am seriously considering going the same route, become an instructor on an island resort.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1934960
Ever sign off on people who shouldnt have passed?

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1935056
I made about 8-8.5 thousand(thousand) on a regular month, as in at least 4 days off and not working from 8 in the morning till 18-19. But, depending where you find yourself working, during what times of the year, and what position you are in theres always the potential to make more. For example this summer, even with covid and the death blow it had for international tourism my friends working in Eilat made Bank, one guy earned about 16k during August(always the busiest month of the year). Mind you this was with no days off, no breaks, first dive at 8 in the morning last dive at 18-19. Its taxxing as fuck and the nitrogen in your system makes you tired as hell. Take into consideration that this is a place where you only shore dive so you have a much fuller work day since your not sailing out and doing only 4 dives the whole day like in most island resorts. The island resort path is not a bad one but from what I've heard you eat shit in the beginning there and kind of work for your training and internship and this can drag on for a while. Skill wise I would say I was really good, technical skills(proper controlled buoyancy, underwater navigation and orientation, planning the dive etc') become second nature since you dive so much(i think I finished with above 4k dives if I'm being conservative) but the real is dealing with people, learning how to teach them, control and lead a group underwater while navigating and remembering to do all the exercises in the proper order with each diver and getting them to do it well as well as remembering your on a schedule and have other dives to get to. Giving lessons in a classroom is also something you learn, how to keep people interested and pass along the information easily and uncomplicated. Regarding working on an island i know from a friend that worked in the Maldives that the dream is to find a resort and become either part of a very small team that works there or be The Guy that does diving courses exclusively

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1935110
Probably a few, less then 4. These are people that on paper might have done everything the need to pass according to what the organization demands of them to pass but who i wouldn't trust to dive with just their buddy. Most times my boss would push me to sign off on these people. It a strange thing because on the one hand some of those people I know will never come back to diving and are just doing it for doing it, some people I know for sure will never dive without hiring an instructor to guide so at least they'll always have some sort of overwatch,for example a 61 year old gal in a private OW course that was the single most hardest and frustrating student i ever had. But she reached a level where she could swim level and straight(which was a huge win) could control her buoyancy okish and didn't spit her regulator out everytime we practiced mask emptying. I know she'll never go diving on her own since I drilled that into her head that she should always take an instructor as well as to her husband that she's a bit of a danger. Her saving grace was that she was very sweet and totally committed to the student role, and man at that age doing the course ain't easy and didn't give up. Plus got a fat tip at the end

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1935110
But usually the people that shouldn't pass don't pass because they quit. Like I wouldn't string somebody on for 5 days and not at least let him know there's some issues we need to work out or he's not getting his license. Sometimes it extra dives when I was done with my dives for the day, sometimes its doing it as a private(1 on 1) course, sometimes just giving that person more attention and positive reinforcement.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1935384
Starting with good technical skills is a great advantage. Regarding Thailand, I would recommend you look up yourself what your options are. Koh Tao specifically is the place to be if you just want bulk work since its jam packed with tourists, you can get plenty of experience and make a humble pay that covers the basics(housing, food, booze, weed). The thing there is that there's a crazy amount of dive shops there and they all have the option of you coming, doing all your advanced courses to become eligible to work(rescue, divemaster, assistant instructor, instructor) over time, be it a month or several. Thing is in the beginning you work for free. Remember everything costs money, every cert is a blow to your bank account because PADI loves overcharging you, so don't get there without nothing in the hold. I would recommend you just look up which dive shops give you the option to that "path" of starting your way to work there for what price and how much time it would take to reach instructor and just blast off an email just to get an idea and some details. You've got every variety there, from giant conglomerates that have a crazy turnover of courses a week(Bans) to smaller, more personal places. If you have another language besides English thats a big plus, some clubs are clientele specific(Taco Divers for Spanish speaking, some German dive shop as well).

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1935434
I have savings from a "real" job that I can use to bankroll my path to instructor. Does it look better on the resume to get instructor certified in the USA than in Thailand?

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1935454
Honest opinion is that it doesn't truly truly matter where you got the cert. Most places just want to take people that work under the same organization and can bring good things to the table as in: good people skills, good work ethic, responsibility to the job, professionalism yadda yadda...
If you've got the opportunity to work in a place like Hawaii though then fucking go for it man, even California if that place won't burn down in the coming months. You've got a slew of countries in South America with diving in them that gave the same paths of starting out as a divemaster and gaining experience till the place decides they like you and want to keep you or on the other go independent and bring your own students and just rent the equipment(this would far into your career though). If your already in that part of the world I would seriously consider that, if only to take some time off, go do some courses and feel out the lifestyle to if it fits instead of flying to the other side of the planet. Take into account that jumping straight into leading courses is not the only option, I was an assistant instructor for 2 seasons before I did my instructor cert. I did introduction dives(taking someone with no certs for a 25-45 min dive while controlling their everything) guided dives(leading a group of certified divers to a site) or refresh dives(go over the basics of the theoretical material and do a check dive before they're allowed legally to dive without an instructor). I made great money and didn't have that heavy responsibility of leading groups, plus I got a lot from it people skills wise since every dive its a new person that you need to make comfortable in a situation that might be stressful for them

I am in no way implying that you'd get the best training you can in Koh Tao because the clubs there are the cream of the crop. Quite the opposite really, some the worst divers I've ever seen came from there and some of the most close minded, by the book PADI cucks worked there, with eurofags complaining about muh workload omg 3-4 dives im dyinggg. Jesus christ the horrors, destruction and sheer fucking hubris that I've seen...groups of Chinese divers of 10 clumped up like a big ball of destruction with empty BCDs basically walking on the seabed/reef sticking their cameras in every nook and cranny to snap a photo of some poor clownfish. No, the reason I WOULD recommend it though is because its cheap, accessible, has plenty of options and is generally a fun island to spend some time on, plus its like the PADI headquarters of southeast Asia so its not too difficultto pass(PADI loves moneyyy). The instructor course barley has any impact in your skill as an instructor, it gives you the cert and a rudimentary idea of what it would be like to lead a group and what kinda hoops your gonna have to jump through to certify people. You will unfortunately fuck up, flub your words or not notice someone struggling or veering off from the group or just doing the exercises poorly. Experience is the greatest teacher, finding your rhythm, and nailing down your best way of translating by speech and movement to your students how to dive. Again, I am speaking as someone that went through a different path than what instructors usually go through in places like America/Aus/Asia

I can give you part of the roadmap from my head. OW, then Nitrox, then AOW so you can use nitrox there, then rescue diver.

After that you have a choice of going the professional route, which might have some advantages. I'd consider wreck and cave diving though, the latter only after you have enough experience to have perfect buoyancy among other skills.

Finally, from there, if you still shun the professional route, I'd maybe do deep diver, and then move on into technical diving. Tec is a whole different world though, although I suppose you'll learn much of the mindset and stuff doing the cave cert.

name: Anonymous
com:
I was NAUI certified when I was 14yo for Skin Diving and something like Jr. SCUBA certified (the 70s)
Years later, when I was good, a friend had gotten into it. Diving buddies getting our limit in abalone. Back then it was 4 per diver (no scuba, only free diving)
We dove where the big and were here in Northern California. We would free-dive down to 50ft with enough bottom time to get an ab. Most ab divers have a mental block going deeper than 35ft. Most newbs won't do past 25ft. The big abs are beyond 40ft.
After our limit, we would pack up the abs in the car, get the SCUBA gear out and see what we missed while scanning for the next weekend's trip.
One time, I'm free-diving at 50ft and quickly find a nice ab (11") and as I pop it up, I see a bigger one several feet over. I attempt to pry it up, bit was a little slow. The ab clamped down bit I had the leverage and after a few seconds I got it.
In the way back up, I realized it was a big mistake to get two on a dive at this depth. When I got to the surface, I swore off getting two at a time.
We get to shore and ranger-rick, who had been watching us from the cliff, greeted us. He was going to inspect our haul. We were legal. The size limit was like 7" and our smallest one was like 9". When he saw my huge ab, he said he'd never seen one this big. I think it was between 13-14 inches. Among my group of veteran divers, that was our record. (Pure luck... not skill)
As far as SCUBA went, not much there other than spending 45 minutes at 50ft and decompressing at 15ft was weird to do. This was back when you had to hand calculate and use a watch
>pic unrelated

The guardian spirit of wellington harbour is a giant octopus who is also a powerful priest and sorcerer according to the legend...

name: ScubaAnon
com:
>>2002562
>EAN cert
EANx/Nitrox? It's really just theory anyway, so I don't really see the harm. There's not much practical to show anyway unless there's an instructor out there starting fires and explosions or something.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2002562
>>2005480
The PADI class at least is actually pretty disappointing and is just info on how not to immediately kill yourself with EAN. You could learn all of it in a 20 minute youtube session honestly.

That being said most places will require proof of cert, and it's worth it just for that.

As for legality, at least in the US , there are no laws requiring you to be certified to own, breathe, mix, etc. nitrox. That is solely a dive agency thing.

Officially PADI shops have to blackball you if you get caught but none of them will.

All of this being said, at the very minimum actually take the training, the material is important.
Also a cert will help if an accident does happen with a tank, investigators will start with you if you don't have one, and with equipment if you do.

Are there any good places to go /out/ this time of year that aren't below say -5°? I've been camping at Tyresta and Färnebofjärden national parks and at the latter especially it was far too cold for my decade old summer sleeping bag (cant afford any new gear).

Most of this country seems to be lakes surrounded by coniferous forest and being from England this was a change of scenery for me of course but I miss the open moor landscape of home so are their any places like this I can visit in Sweden?

I'm going to Gotland on Monday for 3 days, I'll be wild camping and was wondering what things I should do here and what the best /out/ spots were?

name: Anonymous
com:
>Feral hogs
I worked with a local charity that trapped and butchered feral hogs. My responsibility was to track sounders and recommend the most logical place to bait then construct a trap. Most run-ins are the same: see pigs, they smell or hear me, they run away, sometimes making a shit ton of noise.

I’ve been false-charged/bluff-charged a few times, which I didn’t know pigs did. Maybe they where real-charging and changed their mind like 25’ from me. Either way it was always the same; pig runs at me fast, stops, bobs her head a few times, trots back to the group, then runs and the group takes off.

>bear
Hiking in the Smokies
See bear for the first time
Stumbled upon it, it’s like 100’ away
Closer than I should be, think I might die
100% sure an attack is imminent
Turns it head, sees me, doesn’t care

Every bear encounter since has been pretty much the same, except for the bear who got spooked and took off into the woods, leaving her cuns behind.

>>2006441
You can see them on females if you get close enough, but yeah if you’re not specifically looking for them and they’re just hanging way out of their mouth it’s a male. Their canine teeth, which most mammals have.

Sounders are all female, led by a matriarch. The only time you’ll see a male in the group is if he’s young and hasn’t been driven off yet or a female is in heat he’s going after some sweet, sweet hog pussy. And that’s probably why a male in a group is perceived as more dangerous; they’ll run off competition when they’re trying to breed like any other mammal.

You’ll sometimes see small groups of just males as well. They’re not gay, they’re just bros.

I feel ya. Check out the Amboy Crater. It's one of the darkest spots in Southern California so the stargazing is amazing. There is a parking lot you can sleep overnight in. It's in the middle of nowhere so I'd be surprised if you even encountered anyone there

Check the moonphases before you go. You don't want to go on a night with a full moon as that'll ruin the stargazing. There is a new moon on Feb 11th which would be the darkest night but you can do up to 10%-20% illumination and be fine. Obviously make sure the weather is clear before going (probably will be since it's Cali)

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2005949

>sleeping in your car
>driving your car up to the campsite and then pitching your tent etc nearby
>driving your car to the trail head and then hiking into the camp area

The first two are both car camping. If you have immediate access to your car, it's car camping, makes no difference whether you put up a separate shelter or use the car for shelter.

The third one depends. If you hike far enough that you no longer have access to the car, e.g. as a place to store food overnight, you're just regular camping, even if it's just a mile or two away.

name: Anonymous
com:
LA really isn't that bad for nature if you're willing to drive a little. Angeles, San Bernardino, and Cleveland National forests are all very close and accessible. Fairly close to cities though, probably not great for stargazing. If you go a little further out there's Anza Borrego and Mojave National Preserve both of which are great for camping and generally remote (though AZB gets a lot of rich assholes in 4x4s).

In general you an camp anywhere (usually called dispersed or primitive camping) on almost any land managed by the forest service or BLM. Once you pick a general area check the website for the land agency and they'll usually have lists of good campsites, trails, etc and local regulations. Have fun anon <3

name: Anonymous
com: Car camping is nice. I highly recommend building a platform and using a thick mattress topper rather than just throwing everything in the back like OP pic. You can build a simple platform in a few hours, and then store all the crap underneath, including a fridge/cooler. Check out youtube, there's tons of projects, from simple to holy fuck excessive.

com:
Some national forests have campgrounds in them. The few I’ve been to are only like $2, and you pay on an honor system. Some have “unimproved” sites, ie sites with no electricity or water, and usually inaccessible by RV.

To really avoid the crowds, go during the week.

I used to live in San Diego and would go climbing/camping in Southern California. My version of car camping then was to either pitch a tent or throw down my crash pad and sleep under the stars. I did a lot of dispersed camping on BLM land like
>>2006773
said and that worked great. You can find the land on the BLM website, the interactive map. Did not have as good of luck on the national forests, which is a complete 180 from where I grew up, but the forests in so cal were cramped as fuck and I never felt like I could just drive down an old lumber road and be left alone. The best I found for national forests are Yellow Post sites, which are free, and are easily found on google (ie. “yellow post campsite San Bernardino”)

com:
Heart's Content National Scenic Area in PA is the biggest trees I have personally seen:

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/pennsylvania/hearts-content-national-scenic-area-trail

Bigggggg old hemlocks and some hardwoods saved from logging. It is hard to capture in pictures with my shitty iPhone camera.

I also have visited Cathedral State Park in WV which also has some big old trees. Not as impressive visually as Heart's Content but much better maintained, still beautiful with the headwaters of the Youghiogheny river running through (rhine creek) and easier to get around and good for little kids too!

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/west-virginia/cathedral-to-giant-hemlock-trail-loop

name: Anonymous
com: General Sherman, largest single stem tree. In Giant Sequioa NP off a short walking path. No picture you will see does it justice to see in person.

name: Anonymous
com: General Grant. Saw it on a foggy day, the top was obscured by the mist, and the park was empty. I took a nap on a rock that was up a hill and awoke to see the tree in it’s full glory.

name: Anonymous
com: I’ve seen quite a few of the other large Sequoias, let’s skip to Redwoods. The much denser understory of the Redwood Parks means that many of the trees are quite a challenge to get too. Here is the largest of the redwoods, Del Norte Titan. In 2018 there were some redwoods discovered that might eclipse this tree by volume.

name: Anonymous
com: Skipping to Douglas Firs, if you think the redwood understory is thick and impassable, holy shit does the understory in the rainforest of Washington state take the cake. I bushwhacked for hours to find these trees, at the end of the day I was covered in scratches. Some acres of Douglas fir forest also have the second most biomass after the redwood forest.

name: Anonymous
com: Western Red Cedar. It had more volume then the largest Douglas Fir. This tree I saw in its last year of its extraordinarily long life. It was a short trail on the north shore of Lake Quinault in WA state. A rainforest that received over 100 inches of rain a year. I took my roomates to it on horrendously cold and wet July day, we walked around the tree and looked up at it’s bleached bark. The next year, (2018) I took my girlfriend to it, as we were approaching I noticed an odd amount of light. The tree had fallen over , probably in a winter storm. The shattered pile of western red cedar wood that went off inter the flattened wood could have shingled hundreds of roofs, it was amazing.

name: Anonymous
com:
Surfside! It's 20 miles tops south of Galveston. Award winning beaches. The jetty can get a bit packed on weekends. Miles of inland lakes and surf though. It's just far enough from Angleton/Freeport to be a smaller community with a few decent fullservice restaurants , a liquor store, and a Bucky's. Check out Hookers bait shack, Jetty shack for damn good burger, make friends with them and they'll do you right.


As for crabbing, pick up a good net, a 5gal pail or extra cooler, some string, tie to a piece of pvc pipe or stick. Most people use chicken necks or legs, they're cheap and the crabs don't lose grip as easily because texture, squid is underrated too.
Hand toss your line into the water and reel back up. Theirs plenty of YT vids out there, no need for lessons.
Avoid the tourist crab piers unless you're just fishing for sport as most are too small (5in minimum last I checked) to keep (over-fished) and don't mind being interrupted or watched by strangers. Find a spot around the oyster bays or down from the kayak launch. High tides are best, you can check the reports on your phone, they'll go into feeding frenzy's on minnows and you can literally just scoop them up with a net. Not sure if that's legal, but of fucking course have your fishing license ready and keep an eye out for game wardens because they will be making rounds.

name: Anonymous
com: Port A is nice but crazy with tourists. Rockport you can pilgrimage to the “blue shed”. Corpus beaches have more space and less crazy compared to Port A. Further south you have the National Seashore which is great.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2007510
The best option is a “rustic” cabin kit. Tuff-Shed is a popular brand, and while it is cheaper to just buy the lumber yourself you’re really paying for the assembly (which is included in the price). They can be framed in a day with an experienced pair of guys. You can buy similar kits online, but the shipping might be costly and the assembly might be tough for one person with no experience.

They’re completely unfinished on the inside. It’s bare studs, no drywall or plaster, no kitchen to speak of, no interior doors (if it’s two rooms), no insulation, no electrical, no plumbing, and no HVAC. The outside is done though, as well as exterior windows and doors.

What your left with is a sturdy structure that will last a lot longer than a tent, and something future guests won’t mind staying in. The styling and outdoorsy feel then comes from decorations and finish work.

Because you’ll be doing a lot of the work yourself, you can customize the inside, and live in the structure while you complete it. Forget the tent; you could have the cabin framed in a weekend, put up a temporary electrical pole, run electrical, and insulate in a few days and be much more comfortable

name: Anonymous
com:
I know we all love LARPing on this board so this is a thread for exactly this.
If you decide one day to leave civilisation behind, where would you go, how would you live and how would you survive?
I live in Switzerland which is a very densely populated country, so escaping and living without being noticed by anyone doesn't sound like an easy task.
I'd go to the southern alps in Ticino though, there are some pretty empty valleys there and it's probably the least densely populated place in central Europe.
So, how would I live?
I'd take secluded shepherd trails to get into an empty side valley (already scouted out some). I'd probably build several semi-permanent shelters varying in height where i'd stay depending on the season. I'd stay higher up in summer and closer to the valley in the winter (in some valleys the people living there leave during the winter so they'd be empty).
How would I survive? I'd definitely try catching some fish in the plentiful rivers, there's also some small lakes as well, but I wouldn't rely on fishing to survive.
The Ticino area is blessed with masses of chestnut trees, so I'd try to collect as many as possible during fall and conserve them (I know how to do that).
Fall would definitely be an easy season, with all the stuff that's growing there. Hazelnuts, acorns, rosehip, sloe...I could even collect and dry stinging nettle seeds, those are very nutritious as well.
Mushrooms as well, those aren't very calorie-dense though.
If I can preserve enough food I should be able to make it through the winter and hopefully into late spring as well. I would eat the bulbs of wood garlic, the roots of dandelion and the rhizomes of cattail to get me through spring if I don't have anything left from fall.
Clean water wouldn't be an issue since the streams are very clean in the alps.
It honestly doesn't sound that hard to survive here. Places like Alaska would be much harder for example.
How would you do it?

But staying alive in the wilderness in Ticino? No way. It is nice in summer, but hell in winter. These nowadays uninhabited valleys were inhabited for a long time, but in the last 150 everybody left because it is hell to live there.
> Farming is almost impossible because it is only steep terrain.

To be fair, it would also be my unrealistic dream. But rather staying in a rustico and having some connection to civilization. Maybe even being a hut warden. You don't even need to go far or spend a lot of money for that.

My more realistic plans. Backcountry of Genova. Houses are dirt-cheap (30k for a useful one), weather is warm-ish all year.
You have some space for farming and livestock.
Some shitty mountain road connects the house to a village after a 2h drive in a shitty Fiat Panda 4x4 from 1985. And after a year the house is flooded away by rain.

But. I'd move into the Swedish forest, ideally with no other neighbors near. The ideal would be to be close to both the sea and some lakes, but a lake will do. I'd have a small cabin, heated by a wood stove which I'd also use for cooking. Built with modern techniques and materials, so it will be energy efficient, insulate well, etc. Have a terrace or two. A wood-fired sauna as well. I'd get water from a well. Electricity would probably be via cable unless there are good solar solutions.

I'd clear out a garden around the cabin, and grow some vegetables. In summer, I'd fell some trees, and chop them into wood for the winter. I'd swim in a nearby lake. In fall I'd forage for mushrooms and berries, and make jam. In winter, I'd use my sauna, I'd heat the cabin with wood, I'd go skiing in the forest, or spend time inside being protected from the elements. In spring I'd prepare the garden.

I'd probably have to wait until retirement for this, since you can't make money from living in the woods (unless you become a sellout youtuber).

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1996371

Natives and early Pioneers in general did not live in Northern Ontario permanently, and did not usually overwinter unless you had a good reason.
Winters were worse and the summer season shorter a couple hundred years back. Natives would canoe up when weather permitted and spend the summer doing what they needed to do and get out before the worst of winter trapped them there. Anyone who had a good reason to be up there, like trappers, miners, explorers, etc, would have ideally have supplies enough to carry them through the winter and relied minimally on local food sources, although the opportunity to fish and hunt was there.

com:
How to make arrows
1. Steal bamboo sticks from local planters or nursery
2. Get spoon, chisel top off and flatten with a hammer, then angle grind into arrow shape
3. Collect tree sap and mix with ashes, get sinew from deer legs or bull pizzle
4. Glue head on with sap and wrap with sinew
5. Get feathers from dead birds or seagulls at the beach, this is the part where I fuck up does anyone know how to fletch properly easily?

A forward weighted arrow gets better results from good fletching. Say my 600gn bamboo rotates 40 times before striking target, settles in 20 feet. A 600gn carbon could rotate something like 50 times, settling in 15 feet.
At the same time, damaged fletching matters less on a center weight arrow.

I have and use bivys a good bit. I prefer waterproof ones. I like them because I just take it out and can go to bed with minimal effort. I have a waterproof one so if it rains overnight I can just stay in and not care. I also carry a poncho as my rain gear in the summer. This way if it rains and I need to stay put at camp I just put up the poncho as a tarp. I also have a waterproof bag and carry trash bags to put over my boots when I sleep in the bivy. In the summer I think it does get a little warm but I like bivys with the option for ventilation to help and a very light blanket if needed. I live in the north so in the summer it still gets hot but not like the south. If u want a lightweight option for the south do a hammock. Another advantage of a bivy is that it is a good 4 season option that works all year if u get a good one. Just like everything however it may not be for u especially if u r claustrophobic. The first time I used a bivy I felt a little cramped but now I am so used to it and like it now.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2002554
Pretty sure bivvys were originally made to be "sleep anywhere" quick shelters for people trekking mountains or rougher terrain. They were the option you took when a tent wouldn't be viable, or if you wanted something that was more ultralight. However, tents have gotten smaller and lighter since then, and most people will find the comfort of a single person tent worth the extra few ounces.

Bivvys exist to fill a niche. They're still good as emergency shelters that let you sleep anywhere, but they provide less protection from rain and the elements. Especially in wet and rainy weather, you'll want to pair most bivvys with an overhead tarp or rainfly of somekind (and for some people this defeats the purpose, as carrying a rainfly and bivvy can be close to the same size and weight as a tent). Otherwise its like sleeping pressed against the edge of your tent all night and you can expect to get wet. This isn't the case for all of them, and you'll have to do research for specific products, but most people recommend some kind of overhead protection nonetheless.

That also brings up the other main issue, which is breathability. Some come with nets to keep air through and bugs out but you can't always use it, and you'll find that breathing alone will moisten your entire sleep system.

I still think bivvys are decent and have some benefits. You have the option to have your sleep system in roll you can throw on the ground in no time if you don't want to keep everything in compression sacks. I also like knowing I'll never have to search hard for a place to sleep. And even though there are many high end/UL tents, bivvys are still the simpler and generally lighter option. Instead of bringing a separate rainfly, you can always find a poncho with grommets that can double as your overhead. Bring some rope and maybe stakes and you'll usually save weight by doubling a piece of gear.

Do your research before you buy. Hope this helps OP.

>>2003007
I pair my ultralight bivy with a tarp for all-weather sort of options. I like the airflow, the views and the simplicity. The bivy can help keep rain splashing from wetting the bag, things from crawling in, and generally keeps everything together. It also adds a little wind protection which is nice. i can't say i've ever had an issue with condensation that wasn't a) totally normal for the conditions, and b) doing something stupid like breathing into it all night. And depending on the condensation source, which is often the tarp, the bivy actually helps keep the gear dry from drips and rubbing against it. I went away from tent because of the different set-up options and the ability of the tarp/bivy to deal with bad terrain. As long as I can lay down I can manage some sort of shelter.

I carry a poncho with me and my bivy is waterproof. This way I can just set it up and sleep and if it rains I am fine. If I know it is going to rain for a long period of time I would set up my poncho as a tarp so I can get in and out of the bivy fine while it is raining. Poncho is already my rain gear in the summer so it adds no extra weight and it is usable as a tarp.

>>2007993

What do you think I do when it starts raining and I'm in my bivy then? Strip down and dance in the mud? If it's anything more than a light sprinkle I just accept that it's going to suck and I get going. This is because A: I can't go back to sleep already and B: I risk the rest of my gear getting wet and muddy if I decide to hide inside my bivy. I don't live in the PNW. If it starts raining where I live it usually rains very hard for a few hours then stops.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2002554
Haven’t read the whole thread.
Just my experience in NZ.
I have an alpine bag. Has a fold down hood, no frame.
It’s ok in the snow, works fine in the snow.
Best with a plain nylon bag.
Goretex inside goretex (whatever brands they actually are?) tends to ice up inside.
Lower altitude in rain, water will pool on top, you roll over, and it runs down your neck.
Fix? Sleep semi/sitting.
Not ideal, but if you’re using it in the first place, meh whatever.
Your pack better be waterproof, it’s staying outside unless it’s <40L.
Sucks to get changed in.
Adds a surprisingly large degree of Deg.c comfort.
Cooking sucks unless you’re in a shelter or snow cave.
TLDR they do their job but you won’t be comfortable overall.
Oh and boots in sleeping bag or they freeze. Wear or not, depends on how wet and what your feet can handle.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2008166
I always carry a cheap piece of plastic I put on the ground to protect my shit. I use that so I can take off my boots and have an area to stand without getting socks dirty or wet. I solo camp so privacy is not a problem. I just change clothes standing on that plastic. In the snow, I change fast so it is not a big deal. If it was rain I would hang a poncho if I had to change clothes. Getting in and out was pretty easy because the OR alpine bivy has a hood so you can lift it and get in pretty fast. No way to keep everything out but I have not had any problems. Again for rain, it would be poncho again. If raining when I need to get out I would make it quick and just deal with it.

Applicable milsurp
Wool blankets
Wool clothing
External frame packs
Svea stoves and Trangia stoves
Lanterns
Stick stoves
Full tang knives with bonus points for scandi grinds
Canvas anything
Tarp tent builds
And anything /out/ists can add

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1998381
>wool blankets. Do you still bring one?
When I'm 4x4 hunting from a truck I take a wool banket.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1998381

I've got two wool blankets, a US army one and one that is identical in design but brown with no logo or tag on it. They're the thinnest blankets I own, yet they're on par with my thickest blankets for warmth.

I've also got wool gloves, wool socks, a wool scarf, a wool M43 cap, and a wool greatcoat. All mil-surp from various countries. And wool pajamas I paid $5 for. I am a very firm believer in wool.

>external frame packs

After trying a variety of packs, I just use mil-surp ALICE packs. I've got a medium and a large, depending on how much shit I'm carrying.

>stoves

I've got propane stoves, but I typically an Esbit stove when camping solo. It gets the job done, fits inside my mess kit, and is versatile and lightweight.

>lanterns

In my cabin, I've got old-fashioned kerosene/oil lanterns in every room. For camping? Not since I was a kid. Too much hassle. I've got an old Coleman LED lantern, a USGI angle-head flashlight, and a headlamp.

>stick stoves

If I need a bigger fire than my Esbit stove, I just build an actual fucking fire.

>full tang knives

I've got a Nepalese kukri, a SOG Demo II, and some old Schrade hunting knife. And an Estwing hatchet.

>canvas

USGI canvas pup tent. It's heavy as fuck, but come winter and cold, rainy, shitty weather, it's worth it. Also have a canvas parka (Czech milsurp) and old-school canvas jungle boots for summer.

Other anons have said this but I always bring a dutch oven camping, and if I'm car camping, I bring a tripod. Chilis, stews, cornbreads, mountain man breakfast, breads. Absolutely based. I also bring a retardedly huge axe when possible because my friends and I don't bring firewood, we'll go hunt for downed trees and chop them up.
I'm a big blades guy in general, so I like to have at least a small knife, a hunting knife, and some hatchet or axe. If I'm feeling extra, and I know I'll need to clear brush, I'll bring my machete.

Bringing a chair is nice too. I have a small backpacking one. Sometimes there just isn't a stump or rock to sit on.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2006712
Some are pure wool, some are blends. Depends on the case what's better.
>save on heating at home
Don't go too low or you're inviting all sorts of problems.
As for living in a cool home, consider merino underwear and valenki. If you're using rib knit sweaters or something like that, add something somewhat windproof - I know it's not windy in your home, but the outer layer will help trap the air better. I made myself a rather light poncho from some leftover wool fabric on ebay, it's no hindrance at all when sitting and really keeps you warm better. If you're sitting for a long time, consider a cheap sleeping bag for your legs and lower torso.

>>1998381
Do you guys wash your wool gear when you buy it or is it gtg? I'm thinking I might wash my new sweaters by hand with a couple drops of dawn.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2006780
Nalgene bought out Guyot Designs. An overbuilt 32 and 40 oz stainless steel bottle. I use it over all the thin kleen lanterns, rusty hydro flask, and badly designed titanium bottles out there.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2007315
I don't usually unless it's used/thrifted. Up to you.
If you do wash it, don't use dawn.
Preferably use a dedicated wool wash - I have one by woolpower that works well, or I think nikwax makes one too, but these can be pricey.
Or use a pure castille soap - you should have some Dr. Bronners around as bio-degradable soap for your outings anyway. This is the cheapest method.
or something very gentile - Eucalan woks really good and is enriched with lanolin, doesn't need to be rinsed out if you prefer hand washing. This shit is pricey too but I've had good results using this on both my wool and down garments so I've just been keeping at it. Can usually find it cheaper at wool or sewing shops

>>2006712
Like everything, you can find pure wool or blends. Most of the stuff I get is 80/20 wool/nylon.
I have a couple thrifted sweaters that are 100% lambs wool, but I think I prefer the nylon blend for durability and it springs back to shape a bit better.
My base layers are always blends, at least 70% merino. Some have 2% elastane, some dont. I don't think it matters. The weave/knit matters more.

>>2006780
Nalgene is life. I know this thread is about vintage shit, but stainless is the way to go. Can use it on the fire, beat it up, etc. Copper is just a bitch to maintain and clean often.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1992387
Honestly, almost all trailers regardless of brand/model are built like shit. Electrical is scotch-lock'd together, interior's cheap laminate, plumbing needs to be babysat constantly or you're going to have leaks/problems.
They lighter-weight stuff that often advertises you can pull it behind a car/jeep/half-ton are particularly bad because they skimp on quality/durability to get the weight down. Also those weights are generally listed empty, so factor in the additional weight of water/gear/food/etc.

Campable trailers aren't too hard to put together, and if you've got some /diy/ skills you and a friend can build a way better camper than anything off the dealer's lot.

Don't forget about the tow vehicle either... getting everything moving is one thing, brakes are usually an afterthought. Low elevation flatland trailering is less of a problem than mountains. I had a half-ton, and my little 14ft trailer was pushing its limits. Moved up to a 3/4-ton and everything about towing is better. My next pickup's probably going to be a 4500 or 5500.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1992360
Jump on RV Trader and look around. Kids are usually cool with sleeping on a couch, so you don't really have to get a big one. Keep what >>1992409 said in mind. There are some great brands like Forest River, but if you had Forest River money, you wouldn't be here. I've been looking into them for a long time. My boss, who's owned like 4, told me to always buy the your first used. Get it inspected, do your homework, but don't buy new. They depreciate a lot right off the bat, so buying someones mistake for a deep discount might be worth it. You can work out the kinks that way and decide if that trailer really is right for you before you dump $20k into a $10k trailer. Ultimately, go to some dealerships and sit in them. Take notes of what you like, what would be nice to have, whatever. It's a big investment that tanks when you try and sell it, so unless you come across a banging deal, take your time. If you're just trying to get something you can sleep in when you're not exploring, you can find some cheap A-Frames or pop-ups like the ones listed above.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2000933
>Got any advice?

Size isn't the problem, the van is simply a place to sleep and chill. The problem is the platform your doing it on. These vans are 60 years old now and horrible. Electrical is shit, motors are shit, frame at this point is gonna be shit, etc. You'd be much happier buying a vehicle that is newer. Many people use trucks with canopies on the back, but from personal experience, its pretty unpleasant and trucks are not cheap now-a-days.

Since any van that is going to be in working order is going to cost nearly 20k+, I'd recommend buying something that would be a more reliable rig. I personally just got a brand new Subaru Impreza Hatchback that seems to be more than fine for car-camping/van life if needed. The good thing about the Subaru is, it only costed 23k new for a base. For AWD and a warranty, you cant beat that price.

If you want something that is going to have practical use and wont cost 3k-7k a year to own, I'd recommend checking these options. All new so warrenties and hassle free
- Subaru Impezza hatchback (AWD, 20k new Base Model) (Can sleep me and im 6 foot)
- Subaru Crosstrek (AWD, 23k base)
- Ford Transit Connect (27k net new)
- Ford Ranger (27k net new + Canopy/Camper 1k-5k)
You could always get these a few years older with warrantees too and save 2-5k. Subaru is very good at pre-owned cars

If you REALLY want to 'also learn mechanics', you cannot go wrong with a 22r or 22re toyota truck from 1980-1991. But to be honest, dealing with the rust, parts, boomer tutorials on youtube, etc, gets annoying. I had a 1991 Nissan D21 pickup and manNnnn, its a simple truck, but HOLY fuck was it annoying. Even my 15 year old Toyota Tacoma was shitting out to age.

I get that you have dreams and asperations of being a cool hippie and explore, but it comes with some serious problems. Not everything is like you see on youtube with #VanLife. Those people purposefully lie about how great it is to attract viewers in.

com:
The entire west coast is pretty great for /out/ if you can find a window where the weather is ok.

The coast is so jagged and indented that donegal alone has >2000km of coastline, dotted with thousands of beaches and coves. The same is true of every other west coastal area. Camping in these areas is pretty easy so long as you're careful and/or ask farmers for permission, and I've camped in a lot of national parks with absolutely no trouble all along the coast.

The mountain/hill trails not far from the coast are also a lot of fun, if a little short. You absolutely need to have some way to dry your clothes though, as you will get soaked from all the bogs you will have to walk through.

name: Anonymous

>>1997195

com:
Anywhere along the west coast is good. Best spots would be
Donegal. Some nice mountains and cliffs, some great beaches for surfing and wind surfing.
Galway/Claire is the best imo, where you have the Burren, which is pretty increadable and feels like another planet, the Aran Islands, which has Pol Na Bpeist which is my personal favorite place in the country. The Cliff of Moher. The Connemara hills. Aswell as some great caves along the edges of the Burren.
Kerry, which has the tallest mountains in Ireland (still pretty small) and the Dingle peninsula.
Inland theres fuck all in terms of out, you have a few nice walks along the rivers and what not, its a charming place, but very boring.
Along the east coast theres not much thats great. Theres the Moor mountains up north. Around Dublin you have the Wicklow mountains which are pretty shite, and some nice swimming spots in South Dublin.
Fishing is good everywhere.
The biggest problem the country has is a lack of forests and wildlife, we cut them all down for the potatoes unfortunately.

As much as I love this country if youre looking for out stuff to do around the north Atlantic Norway, Scotland, Faroe Islands and Iceland are all better.

What’s your plans for your land or when you buy land? I know a lot of us LARP on here but I’m months away from moving it all to the country.

Here’s my plan for Northern MN:

- Aquaponics with greens and Tilapia
- Wheat, alfalfa, and veggies
- Goats and chicken, mini donkeys to protect herd and farm chores
- Hoop barns
- Root cellar
- electric fence (pigs later?)
- make a handful of tent sites on back 40
- sauna
Pic related, steel frame house I got quota for under $100k

Idiots don’t want squash, and retard Americans have no idea what it’s even good for.

It’s excellent in pies, cakes, soups, stir frys, barbecue, ratatouille, cooked on a campfire (charred) roasted for seeds, pressed for oil. I’m sure there are more, but those are just the big ones, if you have 300 lbs of squash you’re not going to starve over the winter (it keeps for 6 months in a cool dry area).

The best part though is how naturalized most varieties are to the American continent, I can literally just throw a handful of seeds in scrubby ground and in 3 months I have more pumpkin than I can eat

I've got the land. 95 acres west of the DFW area. As of now I'm working on cleaning up the overgrown oak forests and clearing out as much mesquite as possible. Them I'm going to start planting other types of trees to make a more varied canopy. I'm talking Sweet Gums, Mexican Sycamore, things like that. I'm also working on attracting deer and other game animals to the land. First with corn and protein feeders, but I'm also getting a good sized natural food plot that will be surrounded by hog panels to keep the pigs out. I will eventually move out there, but that's my retirement plan which is about 25 years away. Until then I'll keep developing the woods and soil conditions. When I finally move out I plan on going full homestead. Chickens, goats and ducks for sure. Also I'll have fruit and nut orchards as well as an expansive garden. I'll put in a well and try to get my energy from win or solar power if feasible.

name: Anonymous
com:
Not a LARPer. Have a 40 acre plot (red) on a major river and access to my grandmother's 9 acres plot (blue). Only downfall is everything on the river side if the white line floods every year in the spring thaw for roughly 3 - 4 weeks. But it makes for beautiful soil on the river bank. We currently only garden in a plot near the house, expanded it to 16x50 for this coming spring.

Both lots have a lot of mature hardwood and soft wood. I currently supply all my own firewood off the 40 acres and if I do it sustainably it should do me a lifetime. Currently building a bandsaw mill to make use of the softwood on the property that is in desperate need of thinning out. Once the mill is finished I'm going to cut enough lumber for a 12x28 addition on the house and a good sized pole barn and workshop. Thinking at least 30x50. I want to get my tractors and equipment that currently sit outdoors undercover.

This past summer I cleared the field in (purple), formerly a christmas tree grow that was very overgrown. I'm going to fence it and finish cleaning it up summer 2021. Plan to use it for rotational grazing for a few pigs and eventually a cow.

Built an 8x12 chicken coop/shed in summer 2020. Going to throw a dozen each layers and meat kings in it come spring.

All among a million other small and big projects. Fixing the house up a lot in the middle of all this to keep wife happy as well as necessary repairs. Everything is DIY with a bit of help from a good carpenter friend in exchange for beer and trading labor.

You own land, money sharks will come for you from the surroundings, the cities, and family. I've seen it and had to move to avoid it myself. DON'T LET PEOPLE CAMP ON YOUR LAND!! Liability and lawyers will RUIN YOU if some kids or adults even try to sneak on your property and drink themselves into a hole in the ground. Just do NO CAMPING/OTHER TYPES OF SIGNS ANON. Accept money for something else legal, and never for camping. Check out the homesteader laws(some still apply/used). Also
-Goats(depends on if your land can contain them) Meat, Milk, wool, organic waste mastication
-Pigs(everything else, avoid Saprano's and the like) Bacon, porkchops, LARD
-Chickens(chicken breasts/legs/etc, EGGS(lots a day in even small setups) Rooster is Natural ALARM CLOCK/Guard dogs.

Cows only if you REALLY want them(average cow lasts less than 5-6 years Dairy(make friends with local farmers or no fertile bull to make calves and more milk for you)

Perennials are your FRIENDS ANON, fruit bearing trees, bushes, Asparagus around roads(Minnesota and road salt, no asparagus no grass(asparagus LIKES SALTY SOIL/FIXES IT IN PLACE) WHEAT!! Lots of fun small grinder stone setup.
Also Place windmill for water pump in windy spot and have water tower, your water pressure and such will thank you. Make sure your animals don't drain into THAT AQUIFER.

Survey your land, even rent some GPS survey equipment to do it yourself, take a couple small core samples to tell how your soil is for both growing, placement of your livestock, home, water, waste pond/septic and road. This alone will save you time, headache and lots of money.

Looking for 40-60 acres for my family of 4-5. The goal is to slowly reach self sufficiency before the browning of America is fully complete and our living conditions go Venezuela tier.

Current plans are building a modern walipini that will grow fruit types that dont usually grow on the lands hardiness zone, and some year round vegetables. In addition to that I'm planning 3 protein types - Egg layers, tilapia, and 2-3 free range cows for beef.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2003650
Funny you mention that I live in olive country in CA. Research the varieties you can grow in your area and if they are viable for oil. Next consider that oil is a very low yield process, meaning it take A LOT of olives to make a little oil. Then you need to look into the type and expense of a press. I’m not trying to discourage you but you should know that the path to olive oil is an arduous one. Olive trees are neat tho they live and produce forever and super ripe olives are fun to pelt people with (natures paint balls) overall I think right off the bat you might see more cash flow by going a brining route and doing table olives, not that this process is quick or easy necessarily, but the yields are 1:1, you process an olive you sell an olive.

On several acres in the north. My plans:

There is a little sweet spot with RVs though, around 7-10 years old, where a year or two older doesn't matter that much, if you find something for a good deal (maybe needing some repair) you can fix it and use it for a year or two then sell for a profit. Have done it a few times with various trailers and made out on top each time. You have to find just the right deal though. You can often get them for cheaper becasue when people fall on hard times the first thing they sell is their RV. Unless it's someone upgrading a lot of people are selling because they need to sell or want it off their driveway. The first time i did it i bought this tent camper off a single mother i was fucking on the side. she didn't think it worked so i got it for like 300$. Got it home and found out she was just missing some of the poles so I got some used ones and had a good condition camper. Camped it 2 years then sold for $2400

Since then i usually find a 20' trailer from someone who needs to sell like i said above, then jew them down on price, fix and clean it up a little bit, camp the shit out of it, then sell in a year or two. It's a good system as long as you don't get greedy

In principle you can do all mountain trails in winter as well if conditions are right(stable snowpack). Our mountain trails are marked blue-red-black with increasing difficulty fyi although in winter the actuall difficulty strongly depends on the conditions.
I dont know any easy 3hour walks but the following website is very handy for searching:

https://www.bergfex.com/sommer/oesterreich/touren/

make sure you set the "tour type" filter and set the "region" to tyrol.
and disregard the "technique" and "fitness" requirements because most entries are done by private people who often leave it on default. Check for yourself if you can do the elevation gains and distance indicated.
And just to reiterate: please check avalanche conditions if you venture into terrain where it becomes relevant.

>>1989536
>go to dollar store
>buy a pound of wasabi peas
Its really not worth your time to make them. As for favorite recipe I loved to dehydrate onions mushrooms vegies from my garden and steak strips. I throw some of each and throw them in a thermos full of boiling water and some barely. Nice hot tasty beef broth to sip all morning, and a good hardy meal for lunch. I work outside and this makes winter much more bearable and having various dried vegetables allows variety. As for specific recipies I'm very partial to drying strawberries sliced thin and dusted very lightly with cloves, sounds awful but is absolutely delicious. Another good recipie is to make tea eggs and dehydrate the whites (not a very big fan of dehydrated yolks).

name: Anonymous
com:
Pic related is the Lost Dutchman in the Superstitions

The location has the only remnants that were abandoned in the 1800s from an operation of 30 men that mined there.

They were massacred by their own men on their 3rd trip out of the valley on their way to Virginia

This being their own enterprise founded by JP Morgan and JD Rockefeller

They used the mines to fill their banks full of stolen gold from the region and funded the entire entourage of businesses that they used during WWI and WWII

This being also where Ford got his backing from back in the day when he was tinkering with a quadricycle....

yes i ve looked I think 3 times with local friends, twice by helicopter and once on foot. Its incredibly tough country to try and hike in, and weather can change without warning in those coast peaks.
We did find gold but not what was described by by the stories. mostly flower gold in small streams that appeared and disappeared at random with no real cause it seemed. I ve been to the approximate spot of Volcanic Browns camp but didnt find much there either. If the spot was a mine it has likely been wiped out by land slides or changing land features. The box canyon mentioned by Jaxon could match any number of locations up in those mountains. I do recall though we found a miners pick and a decomposed backpack, but that was from the late 60s not from the turn of the century.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2001890
10 dollar jigging rod and waxies/maggots on a little jig is a great panfish combo (but can be a hassle in deeper water), not so much the Tipup. A tipup will work best on aggressive predator fish like bass, northerns and walleye. Bait it with a circle hook or treble and a live minnow.

If your jigging rod is stiff, I'd advise putting a spring bobber on the tip, and if it's legal, I'd advise putting flies/bare hooks on the line a couple inches apart a couple inches above the jig you tie to the bottom, and bait them too. Bounce the jig off the bottom every now and again and alternate between leaving the jig lay on the bottom with just a tiny bit of slack in the line and leaving the jig suspend off the bottom just a couple inches.

name: Anonymous

>>2003217
Yeah, just get a clear float (to keep the rig upright) and a weight heavy enough to sink the float. I'd tie up a sabaki rig like this (bait with grocery store shrimp, fish, etc, or stuff you collect from the shoreline sand fleas, etc), and a mackerel rig (basically the same thing, but "baited" with triangles of mylar film packaging), and use those rigs to catch bait to live line or cut into chunks/strips in pursuit of bigger fish.

I'd rather do this with a pair of 3 or 4 piece rods (a 9 ft 3/8ths to 2 oz and a 12 foot 3-6 oz), but it should be doable hand lining if you've got deep enough water close enough to shore.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2004198
7wt and 8wt (most popular) are the norm for single handed steelhead fishing. Steelhead are really string so you wont be able to fight them effectively with a light rod. Its bad for you and for the fish. An 8wt can also be used for bass, pike, carp and many other desirable species. Fly fishing gear is a "buy once, cry once" kind of purchase. If you're really serious about fly fishing then buying a mid price (200-500$) rod and a decent reel (100-250$) is the best option. It will last you your whole life, if it doesn't it probably has a warranty, and you'll have no reason to upgrade in the future.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2006138
Most of those are "Don't Bother" tier.

Cheapest crap thing you should buy would be a Dock Demon (get the spinning reel version), but that gets you a crap reel and a short crap rod (can't cast as far or as precisely) with crap spine and crap sensitivity.

Next tier up is the Pflueger Trion or Shimano Sierra on a Eagle Claw Crafted Glass or Diamond Graphite rod. This is a $30 reel sold separately from a $20 rod, and gets you a lower quality reel with an acceptable quality drag and a rod that's not complete garbage, but isn't really the kind of rod you want to chase delicate bites or big fish with, because it's got a whippy tip and a soft backbone, which means that it doesn't do the best job transmitting the feel of the strike to your hand, but makes a great rod to keep behind the seat of a regular cab pickup to chase dink bass after work or toss bobbers at panfish to grab a fresh fish dinner after work.

The tier beyond that is things like the Cadence Amazon rods or no-name graphite rods, which are made with real rod features, but not real rod QC or quality, so you might get a good one and have it act like it's a decent rod but it'd be better to save a little more for something nicer, or buy name brand fiberglass or fiberglass/carbon composite rods, like the Ugly Stick or the Shimano Sojourn (get the Sojourn). You can put the same kind of cheap reels on these as the other units, but get something nicer, like a Catana, or two steps nicer like a Sedona or President.

Then you get into the decent graphite rods or specialty fiberglass poles, like the Quantum QX36. These are rods that have most of the good features, and are good quality materials, but check for assembly problems. I don't like to buy these online, because I want to check the spine of the rod before I buy it, if the spine and the eyelets are properly aligned and there's no defects in the construction, they are great. A QX36 with a Sedona is a better combo than most fishermen own.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2006173
whats even the difference, ancient niggas fished with a string a stick and bugs

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2006138
>>2006173
Past that you get into the nice rods and reels, like a Clarus or a Fenwick HMX and the entry level St Croix and Loomis rods.

My "sweet spot" for where I think that buying "nicer' starts to cost a shitload more money for not very big improvements is the St Croix Triumph and the Pflueger Supreme.

I've got a setup like that I really like, and as I wear out some of my other gear, I'll replace those combos with equivalent Triumph/Supreme combos.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2006177
Smoother drag, stronger parts, better feel, more sensitivity, more backbone, better casting distance, etc etc.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2006182
lol i just want to catch a fish nigger, I don't need to nut in my pants every time I cast a line

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2006183
Smoother drag lets you use lighter gear, lighter gear is more likely to fool a highly pressured fish in an area that sees a lot of other fishermen. Better feel and sensitivity lets to determine that you're getting a bite faster, giving you more time to set the hook before the fish spits your bait. Better casting distance lets you cover more water, which means you can find the fish faster or reach fish you otherwise could it.

Don't get me wrong, you can pick up a Disney Princess combo kit complete with the "hide a hook" no poke bobber and find a worm flipping rocks, and catch a fish in the runoff basin for the parking lot of the same walmart you bought the rod at, but you'll catch more, better fish with a little better gear.

There’s not much to tell, really. I was in Homochitto NF in Mississippi, hiking a 12 mile trail on a weekend. It’s rare to see anyone out there; MS has a low population and hiking isn’t exactly popular in that part of the country. The guy was in his late 20’s, no backpack, wearing casual clothes. He was barely off trail, and not being very conspicuous. Like, I was a good 100’ away when I saw him.

I just stopped and kind of hid behind a tree so he wouldn’t see me. Honestly I didn’t know what to do. Keep walking toward him? Call out and let my presence be known? I glanced over occasionally to see if the coast was clear. He moaned loudly when he was done, which I found odd. He walked the other way down the trail.

>gay fags blowing each other
This was at Clark Creek, a popular day hiking area near St. Francisville, LA. There are numerous waterfalls along a creek path, and a ~3 mile trail that meanders through very hilly mixed hardwoods and pine. No one bothers to hike that trail, as the waterfalls are the main attraction. The trail has a small shelter, about the size of a bus stop shelter, with a bench inside. It’s open on one side, facing away from the trail.

I was going up the hill and I saw someone kneeling in front of someone else. Like, it was obviously someone getting head. From the trail I could only see legs and feet. They heard me coming and stopped. They could have waited for me to pass or done the polite thing and asked me to join, but no, they left. It looked like a dad and his college-aged son.

My Bro, my Mate, and I spent a night camping on top of a mountain that turned out to be seriously cursed by maori spirits. I will be precise with my information, events, and facts, but will try not to sacrifice the telling of the story in doing so. As such, I reckon this will be a longer one.
I will tell most of the narrative in greentext, but there is a point in the events where things get too disjointed for greentext; I have tried but I can’t make it work. Other than that I will provide some basic information here at the beginning and again at the end, and other than that try not to break the greentext.
Basic info: This story took place in the summer of 2018 here in New Zealand, the mountain is question is Mt. Pohaturoa, located on the opposite bank of the Waikato River from State Highway 30, just outside of the hydro-dam town Atiamuri. If you are a kiwi and you have ever driven south from Tokoroa towards the western access road around Lake Taupo you will have seen this mountain.
I am a born and bred New Zealander and have spent most of my life /out/, this was the first and only outwardly spooky experience I have had, but it opened my eyes to many things that I would’ve unconsciously ignored before this night. Maori to this day act as if there are spirits and cursed / scared places that you just shouldn’t fuck with, and nowadays I’m inclined to think they are right.
This is the story of what happened when I spent a night in one of these places.

>be December 2018
>suggest to Bro that we do some camping before Christmas when we won’t be able to get away
>he agrees, and reckons that we should check out Mount Pohaturoa, which we are both familiar with as a backdrop on car rides but have never explored
>it’s settled, and we will take my Mate, who was only just getting into /out/ and desu after this ordeal surprised he still is

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1985115
>Bro does some research, turns out Pohaturoa is on land belonging to the local maori iwi (tribe), and is being leased out for forestry, so we will need be somewhat stealthy about getting in
>he also finds on an old forum info that there was at one time a trail that went up onto the peak, which is lucky because this mountain is sheer buttress on all sides around the flat peak
>pic rel, the old map
>set out one morning with very basic gear; tarps, mats, cookers, food, and machetes for cutting through the blackberries that will inevitably be choking the undergrowth of the pines growing on the lower slopes
>drive south a few hours, everyone is excited at the prospect of exploring a potentially lost trail, and the anticipated view from the top of the mountain down the Waikato River valley and towards the inland volcanic plateau
>come into the river valley, and see Pohaturoa looming out of the middle of the valley floor, looking like something out of an old Western
>have to drive around for a bit to find a safe place to park Bros Outback out of sight, fortunately no logging machinery around, so we park up at a logging trail at the foot of the mountain
>leave the Outback and orient ourselves, Bro has a Garmin watch or some shit with a map and is orienting it with the map I posted to try get us close to the old trail, fucked if I know how all that works
>tree-line is a wall of mature radiata pine and thick undergrowth, inside is very dark and it is very clear that no one goes in here any more
>above the trees we can see the sheer cliffs of the rock plug that was the core of the mountain before it all eroded away, but can see that there is a kind of gully in the side that we are facing, which looks to be the only way to the summit

name: Anonymous

>Mate finds it weird that there are no birds around, put it down to the forest being too monocultural, still strange though
>the pines are so old and so close together that we cannot see ahead to the cliffs, and hardly see the sky
>no sign of the old trail either
>stop to ask Bro if we are on the right bearing
>Bro: My watch hasn’t updated our position in the last couple hundred meters, idk if it’s because the trees are too thick or what. Just keep going uphill
>do so, and eventually run almost straight into a sheer cliff-face, with no sign of the trail or any way up
>reckon we drifted to the left, and cut back into the thick of the pines to loop right
>slope is so steep by this point that we are having to reach up and get a hold of pine trunks and branches to pull ourselves up
>realise that if this forest was meant to be harvested they’ve done a piss-poor job of managing it, wouldn’t be the first time forestry land was left to go to shit because the maori iwi owning the land flipped the table

>I can make out another one just above me
>inform the boys that we have found the trail
>follow the now constant trail of old retaining boards and find the pines growing thinner as we go higher
>come out at a scrubby little clearing at the base of a very steep vertical gully in the cliff faces, and see the remains of old wooden stairs set into the rock

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1985119
>thrilled that we found the way up, we start to climb
>the way is very steep, and at times very precarious, probably way too dangerous to be trusting a worn out decades old stair, but we are too exhilarated to be above the trees
>after a bit of climbing we emerge out onto the southern end of the flat summit, mostly native scrub-grass, tall enough that you can’t see over it into the interior, but we just spend a few minutes enjoying the view
>from up here we have total command of the valley, can see the Waikato River flowing from past the foot of Pohaturoa out along the valley towards the very very distant Mount Ruapehu, still gleaming a little with snow
>it was and still is one of the best views I’ve ever experienced
>decide to check out the interior and find a camp site

>take care when swinging machetes so as to not hit our little bros
