>find a great spot to camp at the edge of the clifftop with a view down the valley, clear out the scrub and pitch camp
>it is mid-afternoon by now, but we are all fairly hot and knackered so we pitch our tarps and take off our shoes and relax
>the fantails get more and more curious at this activity, and perch on the tarp-strings, and even sit in our boots to enjoy the warmth
>at this time I am starting to get a bit uneasy about staying up here, now knowing that this place is an historic site – maori iwi are notoriously possessive with their land, and if someone sees our car and figures that we are out here we might walk out of here in the morning to get jumped, esp. cus the nearby town is noted for gang activity
>on 1News tonight, a trio of far-right terrorists are apprehended by peaceful iwi members after desecrating tapu site
Small disclosure; tapu is a concept in maori culture that is kind of hard to put a finger on. Basically, all things have mana, a kind of spiritual honour / prestige. Mana can be gained in honourable actions or taken away through shame. If something has really powerful mana then it is tapu, and to degrade the tapu means that you make it lose mana, which will incur utu, or a vengeance to re-balance the scales. This can happen on a human scale, and also on a cosmic scale. My fear was that the iwi would perceive that we desecrated the tapu of the site and would incur utu on us. I gave no thought to there being an utu of the other kind.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1985124
>I kept my reservations to myself, as I had no intention of ruining the time for Bro and Mate with my paranoia
>plus, having a machete will make anyone feel gangsta
>we make dinner early to not interrupt the sunset, which looks like when it comes will be something special
>fuck yeah, roast chicken wraps
>sun begins to go down in the west, touching the hills on the side of the valley we are facing, and the sky immediately begins to go a very deep shade of red
>and I don’t mean normal sunset red, this was like someone painted the sky with red watercolours, it was deep and kind of smoky
>Bro: I didn’t think the Southern Lights came this far north
>theorise that maybe there was a big bushfire somewhere west
>at this point the sun is bisected by the hilltops, and in the redness of the sky rends of deep black are opening up to the night beyond
That was the last moment of cognisance I have of that night. What I am about to relate from here until I was standing back at the foot of the mountain the next morning I can only remember as if they were out-of-body experiences, or as if they were vivid dreams. I tried greentexting these bits but it was too confusing.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1985125
Below is what I remember. I will try not to colour it too much with any of my reflections, and just tell it as the images presented themselves.
From that moment I was looking out over the cliff at the sunset, the next I was looking down at myself from above. I remember seeing myself, my Bro, and Mate all sitting still with very stern expressions as we watched the sky. We were lit up red and gold with the light, and all over us were perched the fantails, more than there had been before, and all of them still and quiet, watching the sky just like we were. The scene then went dark as the sun vanished, and everything was cast in the deep red of the sky.
Next I was back in the perspective of my own body, but I do not recall being lucid in it, as it was like I was a passenger rather than driving. I have to emphasise how abstract and dreamy this all felt, things like perspective and geography were being warped for the sake of the images I was seeing.
I was again looking up at the sky, and the black rends that we had seen before were growing and merging until it split the sky, which exactly mirrored the black shape of the river below us. Out of that black river in the sky figures began to emerge, black silhouettes cast onto the red sky. They came out of the river and were at the banks.
Now the perspective shifted, and it’s like I was in the first person perspective of one of those people down on the river. We were on the banks looking up at Pohaturoa, pulling in canoes to the banks. The people looked like Maori, but they did not have facial tattoos, and their hair was dark red. I (or the body whose eyes I was seeing through) looked to where a large canoe was being pulled in, and a tall man who I knew was the chief of our people stepped out onto the bank and turned to a woman.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1985126
She was Maori, she had a ta-moko on her chin and green-stone earrings, and was beautiful in a way that I haven’t seen a woman look like in the real world. The Chief helped his wife from the canoe. The whole thing was very dignified.
Then I was again looking at the sky, and on the river were two groups of figures fighting.
Next I was again looking through that same figures eyes. I do not know how I know it was the same man. I could smell blood. There had been a battle on the river with people who were clearly Maori, and while the Maori had been defeated the tribe had also lost men. I was in a group of the red-headed tribesmen assembled at the house of the Chief, they were angry and gesturing to his Maori wife, who the Chief then relented and turned on. She looked very young then when the tribe of red-haired men came in on her.
Then the memories shift to being back looking at the sky. Now above the image of the river is the silhouette of Mount Pohaturoa, looking like a tombstone. And then from the
peripheries of the horizon blackness began to seep in in the shapes of hundreds of men with spears, and the smoky red sky surrounding the mountain was then alive like it was on fire. There was the sensation that everything was throbbing with the beat of drums.
Once again in the perspective of the tribesman, the drumming was as loud as if it was behind me, and I was climbing that steep gully up the side of the mountain just like I had before, only now my arms were brown and I was surrounded by other fleeing people all scrambling up the mountainside as something chased us. There was a heavy smell of smoke. Even recalling that memory my heart speeds up a bit.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1985127
When I saw the sky again it was as if the colours had been switched, the sky was black, and the river was red. There was no other image.
When I was looking again through the eyes of the tribesman it was totally dark, and my nose and mouth were filled with stagnant earth, but I could feel my hands breaking out into air. There was a distinct feeling that there was something coming up the mountain, that it would be there soon.
I was then looking down at myself as if from above again. Only now the night was dark, there was no light but from the moon and stars. Me, Bro, and Mate were all still sat there as still as before, but the fantail that sat on us were not. They were squeaking and shaking their tails where they stood, staring behind us into the long grass.
Through the tribesman’s eyes I could only smell the scent of decay. I looked through the long grass to the edge of the summit and saw myself, Bro, and Mate all sat as we were before, covered in fantails. The sensation that something was coming up the mountain was stronger than ever, and then I was overcome by a certainty that whatever it was had arrived on the summit.
Looking down on the three of us again, the grasses to our backs were thrashing like several large crawling things were moving around the clearing of our camp, but every time they came close the fantails, now flashing all around us, would dart towards the scrub and whatever was in there would turn back for a moment. Much like how I had felt through the tribesman that something had arrived on the summit, I now felt the same sensation as I looked down on our bodies. There was something coming this way, that had come up the mountain to find us.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1985128
And then I was back in my body. I was walking behind my Bro, my hand clenched on the shoulder of his shirt, and I could feel Mate’s on mine, like kids trying not to get lost in the dark. We were walking through the scrub one behind the other in darkness, surrounded still by fantails and the sound of crashing in the scrub all around us. My head was bent, and I had the very strong impulse in my head that I must not look at the faces of whatever was in the scrub.
That moment flashed to the next and were no longer on the summit, but on the lower slope of Pohaturoa, descending just as we had before with hands on shoulders, in the same dream-haze. Only now the night was quiet, and though the pines made the darkness near absolute my Bro walked on like he knew exactly where to go, and I could still feel the fantails perched on me, though they were now quiet. Around this time, awareness seemed to be returning a bit to us.
>Bro mutters: Nearly out...
>I mutter something to Mate, but hear nothing
>I reach my free hand across my body to tap Mate’s hand, only to freeze when I touch it
>my fingers met with something that feels smooth and bony
>I went to turn around when that impluse that I felt not to look before came back over me, only now it was soothing, as if explaining to a frightened child
>one of the bony fingers at my shoulder unfurls and strokes my still frozen hand, and I became calm
>a voice seemed to say in that movement ‘don’t worry, your friend is safe, he is just here behind me’
And the next thing I recall it was morning, and all three of us stood in a row facing away from the tree-line next to Bro’s car, with all our gear stacked neatly beside it. This is the first ‘real feeling’ memory I have where it actually feels like I was in full command of myself.

name: Anonymous
com:

>but Mate is open with his returning memories, he had almost exactly the same experience as me

>’What do you mean?’

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1987878
So I did a bunch of research into the area after the incident and turns out the area around Pohaturoa was settled by the first wave of polynesian settlers in the 1400s. For those who do not know the early polynesians in NZ at this time were nomadic, as they hunted the large native bird-fauna that had evolved here like Moa. The Moa Hunter cultures were defined by the fact that they were nomads, were far less material than later Maori culture, and they were far less violent. They had no reason to be with so much resources. When the moa began to die out the new waves of Polynesian settlers brought cultivated crops with them and started creating larger settled communities. With this settlement came competition for arable land and a more warlike culture.
I believe that the red-haired people I saw through the eyes of were the Moa Hunter tribe of that area, and that the Maori who came in were newcomers looking to gain influence in the area through a marriage of a chief's daughter to the chief of the Moa hunter tribe. And to back it up, I have the iwi's oral history that explains exactly that. This article goes into the local history and lines up with what I saw.
https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/pohaturoa-the-story-of-a-new-zealand-hill/SMUDRGLMU3HO6LWJJH6AMWWJHQ/
>Fletcher says they could barely be called a tribe to start with. More a collection of scattered families, they arrived in the area around 1400 and were known as the People of the Pumice Lands. Over the next 200 years, they lived in the area alongside the Ngati Hotu and Ngati Ruakopiri
>As with European monarchs, the hapu arranged a strategic alliance, marrying a chieftainess to a man of the Kahupungapunga for the sake of peace and access to the region's natural wealth. But the arrangement, it is said, turned sour

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1987880
This is where shit get really fucked. The Maori woman that I saw was obviously blamed for the attack by the moa hunters from what I had seen, and I figured she must've been killed, but the way that they did it was so horrible it makes me sick and angry. According to the legend (source: same article):
>People here saw her as imposing their [Whaita and Waerangi] mana on them. They could see a loss of the area with more people coming in. They murdered her and made it look like an accident
>But the woman, most commonly thought to be named Kiroukore, had a slave. He discovered Kahupungapunga's treachery and carried the news back to Kawhia. The Raukawa hapus were furious and, that same day, gathered together a war party 500 strong. The warriors moved across the land, conquering several pa as they went. Finally they met the Kahupungapunga in a battle called Taurianuku
It doesnt say how she died, but there's a bit later on that stirred my memory:
>The pursuers crossed the stream to Pohaturoa, each party fought valiantly, the Ngatiwairangi were several times repulsed but in the end they drove back the others and captured their great toa [fighting chief] Hikaraupi. The great stones on which the bodies were cooked can be seen still
The rock in question is pic rel. It has many legends to its name, but one is that it was used to cook alive a Maori Princess. When i touched her hand all the skin on her had been stripped away and her bones were shiny like they'd been boiled. Why they boiled her avile insteaad of outright killing her i dont know, but as far as I care those cunts got what they deserved for what they did to her.
I think that the things that were stalking us in the grass where the spirits of the Moa Hunters, and the spirt of the Princess had so much mana that they were afraid of her when she led us out.
Regarding the fantails, they are held by maori to be bodies that dead spirits can inhabit. I think they were dead maori spirits protecting us.

That's it really, unless there are questions.

Everything is dark, but I have good night vision. Get a good look at it for about a second before it notices me and makes a sudden movement

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1982424
After watching the movie Sauna every time I see a structure like this I wish it were a sauna so that I could use a sauna. It's also 30 below before windchill right now and the heat is out in my truck and I just had to drive around for work all day, so any sauna would be nice.

Something between a clack and a sniff. That's how I recall the noise right now.
When I heard it move, it sounded like a person taking a few steps--two--at a time. I actually thought I disturbed a neighbor and they were coming to see what was going on (I had my flashlight on) I 100% thought it was a human being until I heard the noise. Holy crap that noise was terrifying.
The noise sounded like a sniff, or I thought at first. Recalling it I know I am not remembering the noise 100% correctly but there was something strange to the noise as well, it wasn't like a dog sniff, but I could tell at the time it was a sniff, like an intake of air. Just not like any I've heard before.
I hid my phone light so I wouldn't be seen as easily hopefully (I couldn't see anything anyway, but I didn't want to make my position completely obvious) and to focus on the noise. It didn't stop or anything, right now and for the entire rest of the story, except for when I started running. So constantly I am now hearing these steps, or something disturbing the leaves on the ground, maybe 30-40 meters up the hill if videogame knowledge of distance is accurate. I mean, holy crap when I went outside to start with there was no noise at all, anywhere.
OK so now that I've gotten key details that were fresh in my memory at the time of writing let me go ahead and explain everything.
Basically, I've taken an interest in the outdoors, but now after this I'm wondering if I'm ngmi, but I think I have some reason to be as terrified as I am. When I first started, I had this big knife I was taking into the woods behind our house down to a little stream, I wanted to see if I could somehow learn to make a fire with just wood and ingenuity, (aided by Youtube) so I spent several days trying this, to no avail while I was waiting for matches to come in after ordering them online. Oh well, I had never actually started a fire before so it wasn't really a surprise, but practice didn't hurt I don't think.

>>2006308
Anyway, while this was going on near the stream, during about two days, I got the feeling I was being watched, yeah yeah. OK, so there might be an actual reason for this, I had read a 4chan story that was definitely fake about these murderous forest dwarves, and my imagination was running, so obviously I was probably just imagining it. Then I heard footsteps, and remembering this now sends chills up my spine, but down by the stream I begun hearing footsteps. I say footsteps because if it was a squirrel or something hopping around, why would it always be two crunches of leaves? Crunch, crunch. Stop. Later--crunch crunch again. If I was out in the woods walking, if I take a step, my other foot needs to move up as well to get anywhere. That was what it sounded like. Every now and then I'd stop working and listen and DEFINITELY NOT IMAGINING IT HEAR THIS NOISE. I wasn't too worried then because it was broad daylight, I had a big knife, and really during this entire time of the whole story I'm telling I wasn't not within a minute or two sprint from my house. Anyway, after hearing this noise twice, one day after the other, I stopped going even so far as the stream. It was a lot quieter over there and I had stopped feeling comfortable down there. So instead I started working at a halfway point between the house and the stream. A lot more comfortable, I didn't hear the noise at all then the few days I was out there.

>>2006309
A few days ago I had finally successfully managed to make my own fire, and I felt fairly proud of being able to do so, although it cost about 4 matches, which was disappointing that I messed up so many times, but I figured out how making a fire actually works and I was completely confident I could do it again with 1 match.
So today, I decided I wanted to sleep outside for the first time, but damn I probably did the stupidest stuff I could. My friends and I like to play videogames late, so I figured I'd just go outside (after all it's not even far from the house at all) and I didn't tell my parents or anyone what I was gonna do. So at 2 AM I go outside in the pitch dark with my stuff and my flashlights, and I head out into the dark. After all, what's going to happen? I'm going to be eaten by wolves? I was really stupid because it's honestly not outside of the realm of possibility that a bear was out there. We get bears out here. I'm a moron. Anyway, I just figure I'll be fine and start my fire quick enough and nothing will bother me and I'll go to sleep in my bag. Definitely not what happened. I get to where I have wood stored dry in case it had rained today (thank goodness it didn't) which also happens to be the site of where I am going to start a fire and unroll my sleepy bag. At this point, I'm already feeling weird because I was shining a light out here at 2 AM and I realized I could see lights from where my neighbors lived, so if any of them were outside they would see me and possibly not realize it was me and not an intruder or something. So I'm just like, "OK, if anyone starts coming to shoot a robber or something I'll yell and tell them it's me."

>>2006310
I get to my stash of dry wood and I start pulling of the stone slab bits covering it, and I kind of half-drop one and it smacks another loudly, and right after up the hill I hear a loud clack. "What was that? Oh, it was me dropping that and it created an echo. I'll try not to do that again." I thought. I lift literally one more and then dogs start barking. So I guess maybe that was my fault, but who knows because dogs bark at everything, and their barking was far off anyway, so it could have been anything. And then, as the dogs are barking I hear somebody walking towards me. I am thinking in this moment I actually disturbed a neighbor and feeling kind of bad about it, but amazed, because I went out there trying to be as quiet as possible. Then I heard that fucking noise from the same spot. Holy shit that noise. It instantaneously set me on edge, and I started thinking about the wendigo, and the murder dwarfs. OK, but to think logically for a moment, it obviously wasn't the murder dwarfs or there would be a lot more footsteps, and the murder dwarfs were from a fake story set in Alaska, OK, BUT IT OBVIOUSLY WASN'T A FUCKING NEIGHBOR. Whatever the fuck was out there was an animal, and I swear to fuck it was sniffing. Note that this doesn't rule out the wendigo, so that's what I'm thinking of right now. Remember, it's two crunches of leaves, and a sniff. I distinctly remember that happening in various orders. Crunch crunch, sniff. Sniff. Crunch crunch. Crunch crunch. Sniff. That's what it was like. Now as I am writing this story I am wondering what is the possibility this was just one of our cats, but that's the thing, I'm around cats a lot, THEY DON'T SNIFF LIKE THIS OR THAT LOUD. I mean, it didn't sound anything like a smol cat sniffy.

>>2006311
So I am hearing this, and the noise is specifically a bit to the right of between me and the house. I take out my knife, and realize if it came to fighting some sort of predator capable of harming me, the best I would be able to do is kill it as it killed me. Not exactly what I wanted. I don't have my light on right now, if I turn on my light it sees me, (I had turned it off when heard the stepping) and if I move it hears me, if I wait, it potentially comes close to me. Not desirable. What do? My first thoughts: getting on the phone and calling my dad who was probably still awake, or yelling loudly to hopefully scare off the thing. I realized in that moment my pride was deadly, because I would literally rather be killed by a wendigo than suffer the humiliation of calling my dad or waking the neighbors because I was being a scared pussy. So then I decided I would run for it, I would leave my sleeping bag and other stuff, most of which is out there protected from rain, so it should be fine, but I drew my knife and turned on my flashlight. It surely knew where I was anyway, so if it was actually something dangerous it was either escape or fight at that point.

>>2006312
I realized how long I had been just standing and remembered it would be best to do SOMETHING if I was actually in danger, so I said a quick prayer and forced myself to move. I chose escapefight and prepared to die fighting if it came to it while running away. I ran up the hill TOWARDS the noise, and passed what I am pretty sure was a squirrel which I shined my light on as I ran past and I think I said "Get out of here!" as it scuttered away. As a ran I wondered if the entire time I was being spooked by a fucking squirrel, and maybe the "sniff/clack" noise was it biting a nut or something. I'm not about to go outside before the sun is bright to find out though. Also, the squirrel was RIGHT on the edge of the path, which is closer, but not too far, from where I think the noise was. So you know, there's a good chance it was the damn squirrel and I'm just not gonna make it outdoors, but I also believe it might not have been. I still want to sleep outdoors, but I don't want to do it anywhere near my house though. Also I wonder if my gear is gonna be disturbed at all. I should probably just get a tent, a gun, and start the fire before it's dark.

So what was the dumbest thing I did? I think it was probably running uphill with a sharp knife in my hand, definitely pointed upwards. If I tripped I could have straight up killed myself.

It is a general offroad driving safety and technique book.
it discusses the different types of mechanisms on the car, and how to manipulate them to maximize traction, safety, maintainence, trail ettiquete, recovery, etc.
it is a very general book that could be halfway encyclopedia and halfway book.

it is tailored more towards drivers who are going to be hardcore, but it encompasses all drivers and conditions. It is a worth it buy if you just read the chapter about traction physics and optimization, and recovery.

as for groceries, first step would be to identify what grows well on the soil your land will have. not everything grows well everywhere, so that is a factor you need to account for. a single mature cherry tree is enough for my three person family to be eating cherry cakes and kompot for pretty much the whole year, so various foods have various yields. also - you need to look into preserving the food - pickling, making jams and such, storing potatoes in a cellar. otherwise a lot of your work will go to waste. sorry if im chaotic, but thats what you get when you ask for suggestions

oh nice! any tips on water management? where i live was getting severe spring droughts the last few years and could actually start becoming dryland in the next few decades. implemented a few of my own ideas but its always good to share

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2007747
There's a metric fuckton of info on the subject, but if you have an above ground water cistern do your best to keep the water that's going into it out of direct sunlight, mulch your plants with ramial wood chips as best you can, and generally just try and make your property work in a way that even the water you aren't catching off your roof is being slowed down, spread out, and sunk into your soil rather than speeding off in some channelized flow that takes your soil with it.

Brad Lancaster is a really solid source of information on the subject.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2007722

name: Anonymous

>>2007722

What would you plant on the ground that would grow well in the shade and also be good for the goats? It would also be an added benefit if it gives the chickens some good foraging opportunities.
As for what will grow on the land, I currently live in zone 9 but plan on moving to zone 7 so most staple veggies should be fine and I'm willing to put in the work to make the soil more hospitable to whatever I want to grow.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2007761
Look for headcuts on your property, places where the water gets moving fast enough that it actually carves out a small cliff/ waterfall in a rain event and dig out a round basin where the water splashes down, you could probably bury a barrel or just dig a hole and line it with rocks, but the idea is the water fills that basin and overflows out of it, essentially slowing down the chances of erosion while also spreading the flow and slowing it down.

Once the water starts seeping out of the hole you can further slow the water down by planting stuff on the downhill side or making something like a crescent moon out of rocks that the water has to flow through.

All of this stuff Brad Lancaster mentions btw.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2007765
if the wooded area is a part of your property, you could consider just cutting down some of the trees - more light means more vegetation, also goats love climbing.
about veggies: start small.theres a lot vaiables: maybe some kind of a pest will be present in your area that damages some of your plants, ot the soil will be polluted/otherwise unsuitable for some of the veggies. start with just a few types of veggies and expand with time, as you learn how your microecosystem works. besides, trying to manage too many different crops at once is a fucking nightmare, even if you respect the "good neighbours" thing

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1989314
It's super simple to be honest. The backpack holds my water bladder since I normally hike at least 4 miles over 5 hours of fishing. All the magic is in the shoulder strap pouch which is all I actually need and only carry that when I go along a road or not hiking far. I carry a small box of flies just for the day and a fishing license in the main pouch.

I have 2 of these. If you poke the holes front and back you can carry 2 lines per card. I carry 3 different length lines as well as tippet on the 2 cards.
https://dragontailtenkara.com/tenkara-line-cards-for-level-line/

Two of these zingers that connect to a pair of nippers and forceps. These tools fit nicely on the side pockets of the pouch.
https://www.tenkarabum.com/gear-keeper.html

There is a pocket in the back that I use to keep a small bottle of floatant for dry flies.
I'll post some pics shortly.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1996821
With less expensive gear, you’ll want about 50L for overnight trips. I ran a MeetUp group with >120 people, and that was about the average size, maybe bigger now that I think about it.

I say “want” rather than “need” because the largest varying factor is the weather. If you’re expecting rain on day two, you’ll need room in your pack for rain gear. For cooler temps you’ll have more layers. Sometimes you’ll have both. If it’s never raining or cold, you can get away with a smaller pack, but that seriously limits when you can go. Sometimes the weekend looks great except for a brief period with a 40% chance of rain. Good thing you opted for the larger pack and can fit rain gear, right?

That’s also what determines what you bring on longer trips. Food obviously, but extra layers for that one day where the temps dip a little low takes up a ton of space. And bad weather is more likely over a longer period of time.

Less expensive gear (particularly sleeping bags) don’t compress nearly as much as expensive down bags. And bags for cold weather are much larger.

>>2002524
I think I posted earlier in this thread, but I’m not sure.

How you put your pack on is critical. Start with every strap loose. With the pack hanging from your shoulders, bend at the waist, hoist your pack up so the hip belt rides at your hips, and buckle then tighten it. Straighten up and tighten the shoulder straps. You want them snug; just tight enough to wear they take a minimal amount of weight. Most of the weight will be on the hip belt. Then tighten the sternum strap and load lifters (if you have them).

There are YouTube videos on this.

>>2005313
It's a really basic question, too. Sleeping bags are responsible for the bulk of space taken up inside a bag. the only other thing I can think of that eats that much space is a tent. Attaching a sleeping bag to the outside of the bag allows for more to be carried without throwing off your balance too much, assuming it's a light bag weight-wise, and allows you to carry it without scrunching it down which improves on the life span of it because down eventually goes bad(from what I've learned from here, at least, it goes bad from being compressed so it's better to hang it or store it in a large net bag).

>neon
Most ultralight bags in that price range are white or a sort of muted olive green, light grey, or brown.
>durability
Dynema fabric, specifically the DCH50 that most packs are made from, has a higher strength-to-weight ratio than steel (some claim 15x’s), and it has higher tear resistance than 1000d nylon.
>size
They make 72 liter packs out of DCF.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1980831
>i don't know where to start
>download stellarium on your phone
>go on night walks.
Learn the Big Dipper. It's part of the constellation Ursa Major . The lip of the bowl points to the north star.

Learn the North Star. It's in the constellation Ursa Minor.

Learn Cassiopeia. She is roughly on the other side of ursa minor from ursa major. She makes a clear M or W in the sky. The central point of which, points, roughly, to the north star.

Now that you know those 3. You can orient yourself with the night sky and branch out from there to learn the other constellations around it. I use them and Orion to find most everything. You know Orion's belt right? And that he has a dong? That helps you orient off of that constellation. So you can learn what's above it, below it, etc.

You should also look up meteor shower dates and plan on viewing them if you can.
https://www.amsmeteors.org/meteor-showers/meteor-shower-calendar/
And by then you'll know the basic constellations and where to look.

And you didn't have to spend a dime.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1991096
Scopes are like rocking horse shit at the moment. Everything's made in China and its all just sitting in storage because of the container crisis.

You really need to have a think about your application. Dobsonians and altazimuth mounts are quicker to set up but you need to use 2 axis to follow what you are tracking.

An equatorial mount needs a bit of setting up but can track across 1 axis. Its not hard to do, just needs to be done so is better suited for longer sessions of stargazing.

Do you think you will be dabbling in photography, like attaching a DSLR to the scope? If so then you may want to consider going straight for doublet or triplet refractor.

That's not to say you can't do all that with a reflector either, just that a refractor is the "pros choice" for photography.

Do you want a motorised mount? Do you want goto tracking? What about WiFi and smart phone connections that are available now?

Honestly, I thinknthe best option is to go for a tabletop dobsonian like the Sky Watcher 150p Flexi-tube. It's nowhere near as expensive as your budget allows for but it is portable, fast to set up and will give you a really good idea of what you can do and what you might like. After that you can think about something bigger and better but everyone who has a tabletop always raves about them due to their portability and super fast and easy set up time.

com:
Thank you, I'm quite happy with them, especially considering I only started in summer last year. Thing is, you don't really need a lot of equipment to start with astrophotography. If you buy used you can find a tracker and an already modified camera with an okayish lens for less than a thousand dollars. Spending more money will mostly get you clear images faster because noise in images will get less with dedicated astro cameras and with better tracking/guiding you wont have to rule out many of the subframes because of star trailing.
Atm I use an iOptron CEM25P, with a high quality 250mm lens at F/4.9 and a modified Sony a6000, so no dedicated camera yet. All that with a small autoguiding setup. For the nebula images I usually use a Ha-filter.
Because 250mm is not a very long focal length I ordered a new telescope at 600mm because I realized I like capturing details more than those widefield images. Next thing will be a dedicated, cooled astro camera, but they are extremely expensive, so I have to save up for a decent one.
The camera itself didn't cost me anything. Got it as a gift from my dad a while ago. When I started with this hobby, I modified it myself, so I only had to pay like 60 bucks for a new UV-IR block filter. You can get that done by someone else if you're too afraid to kill your camera but I found a decent tutorial online so I did it on my own.

>>1996148
Thank you for your kind words anon. For me it's an extremely rewarding hobby, its really incredible what you can capture from your backyard. Some people will say you could just look at the same images in better quality online, which is true, but taking them yourself is a totally different feeling. Also it's very challenging so being rewarded with a finished picture after 20+ hours of work is absolutely fantastic. I can understand how astronomy might seem expensive and the photography part truly is, but visual is quite affordable.

>>1996285
No worries, was quite a wall of text I wrote. Unfortunately not, to capture good pictures of planets you need a totally different setup than for capturing deep sky objects. You need a really high focal length to capture planets, somewhere in the 2000+mm range and a camera that can record with a high framerate. To make good planetary images you record a video of the planet and a software will take the best frames of that video and produce a clear and detailed picture. Thats done to eliminate the blurines caused by air turbulence.
My setup is for a very wide field of the sky the full moon would actually fit in the frame a few dozen times, so planets would pretty much look like stars aswell.
But have a picture of the moon I took with my phone and my 8" dobsonian I use for visual astronomy. But desu it's not great, you can see it even better if you're looking at it directly, the human eye does a great job at filtering out the air wobbling, cameras not so much.

>Tl;dr
>don't have the right equipment for planetary photography, but have a bad pic of the moon

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2000089
Unfortunately you'll never be able to see the milky way like you can in pictures. Cameras are way more sensitive and can capture light for multiple seconds or even minutes, your eye can't. When doing visual astronomy you'll almost never see any colour, except for some stars, the part of your eye responsible for seeing in the dark can only see black and white. If you went to a spot with actually zero light pollution, you should be able to see the milky way quite well, with some dust bands clearly visible. But there are multiple things that can impact how good you can see it. Did your eyes fully dark adapt, so no looking at any kind of light for 20 minutes. Did you go during summer when the bright core of the milky way rises to its highest spot? Are there any cities in the south from your viewing spot, that create a light dome? Also remember, you're in the northern hemispere and the brightest part of the milky way never goes up near zenith, so to get the best views you need to be in the southern hemisphere

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1980831
I just recently got into the hobby. Here's what I would've suggested to myself:

First, accumulate a library of books and charts. If you're excited to just be able find all the different constellations and objects of special interest with the naked eye, then that's a sign that you'll enjoy astronomy.

Second, use binoculars you already own or purchase some. I truly believe that you will buy binoculars eventually whether or not you buy a telescope. The whole point of the binoculars is not to see higher magnification, it is to boost the brightness of the stars. I recommend getting something 8x40, small and light. Using the binoculars in conjunction with your planisphere and atlases will help you figure out the sky and where everything is better.

I personally use my Pentax 6.5x21 binos I already had laying around. You might be thinking to yourself, ain't those too small? No! They boost my eye's ability to see faint stars by 3~4x. Think about it this way, your pupils probably dilate to about 5mm wide and if you're young and perfectly dark-adapted, you'll get 7mm max. Well these tiny binos of mine have a 21mm aperture. Imagine if your pupil dilated to 21mm, that's how good your night vision would be. So yes, don't knock small binos for serious star gazing.

My first day of using my telescope, I was like what the fuck is all this shit. I didn't even know what to point my telescope at. My first session I spent looking at the sky with the naked eye, having FUN just figuring out which constellation was which. I didn't even need my telescope. The telescope magnification is just too much and trying to center an object in the sky was difficult because mine didn't come with a finder scope. (had to use the built-in peep sights)

So that's my last piece of advice, make sure your telescope comes with a decent, wide field finder scope.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2008017
My post was too long, so here's some other stuff/

My book recommendations:
- Binocular Astronomy by Craig Crossen and Wil Tirion
- The Photographic Atlas of the Stars by H. J. P. Arnold and Patrick Moore (this books is particularly awesome because the dude literally took 35mm color positive film photographs of the sky with a 35mm nikon lens, just goes to show you that high magnification is not the true pursuit of astronomy. not only that, the star maps are literally black-and-white exposures of the positives and are therefore, perfectly aligned and to scale)

The telescope I personally purchased was a Starbase 80 with 80mm aperture and 880mm focal length for about $600. This is kinda overkill, but if you have the cash to spend and you want something that isn't cheap plastic (the entire telescope and mount and tripod are fully metal), I'd recommend this one. It's Made in Japan, so you know it's good :^)

My personal recommendation for telescopes in general, apart from my aforementioned luxury purchase, is to get something that isn't under $200. From my research, no entry level scope that's actually good is sold for less than $200 unless it's just the tube and it's on special or something. At the bare minimum range, I would highly consider the Orion StarBlast 4.5, comes in both tabletop and EQ mount options (for the same price).

I would likewise recommend binoculars from reputable optics manufacturers such as Pentax, Nikon, or Canon. Based on my research, other lesser bino manufacturers fudge their binoc numbers. Oberwerk, despite being a highly rated brand among astronomer community, is particularly egregious. Their 8x52 is actually 8x40 and their 8x40 is actually 8x32.

And finally, the best reason to start with the binocs first is that ALL the good telescopes on online stores are SOLD OUT. They probably won't start coming back in stock until March or April at worst.

That's very true. I do believe there was troops that were better organized or equipped or led than mine.
Maybe I was too harsh in my evaluation. I have mixed feelings about it. We did some pretty advanced backpacking in the Sierra Nevada. And the camraderie with boys my own age was good. Some fun stories.
But I just feel like it could have been so much more. I would see pics of scouts building things out of wood and rope lashing, or making primitive shelters or whatever and we didn't really do that. We didn't really help out much in the community apart from Eagle Scout projects.

From what I can tell, the whole organization is going down the tubes now maybe something better will take it's place.

name: Anonymous
com: The way my dad taught me was to keep your knife at a low angle. Imagine stacking a couple of coins under the blade. Then, while making little circles, pull your knife across the stone. You're gonna want some lubrication on there as well. I've always used water, but even spit will work in a pinch. But if you want to be really fancy they make oils and stuff as well. Make sure you sharpen both sides of the knife the same number of times. I do twenty times for each side on the coarse side of the stone, then repeat on the fine side. I know people like to get fancy and get a 600 dollar stone and 40 dollar lubricants, But my dads 20 dollar whetstone from Menards and regular tap water has always worked for me and it always passes the paper test when I'm done. I've cleaned many deer over the years with this method and it always gets the job done. Sweet knife btw

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2005261
If you want something that will last and be loved forever, restore and rehandle an axe head from craigslist/garage sales. This is always the best option if you have the time and resources. Bonus points if you can make your own handle. Sucks that garage sales died this year but always worth a shot looking.

>Truper
Makes dirt cheap axes but you do get what you pay for. Could probably power through a weekend trip but if you camp frequently it will quickly fall behind the competition. Assume around $15-25.
>Fiskars
Also makes cheap hatchets/axes. Can't say I've used them myself but I've seen decent reviews for them. Could be worth looking into, especially if you prefer fiberglass handles.
>Council tools
Another decent brand with good reviews. They have axes that fall right around that $50 mark and their website has a decent enough variety. Always do your own research, but this might be your best bet for something that's quality enough at the budget you gave. Then again I could be wrong and quality could have nosedived at some point.
>Husqvarna
If you're willing to stretch your budget a bit more I'd also look towards Husqvarna (specifically wood handled selections). They come pretty close to the "high-end" axes for around half the price. A nice middle ground option if you can afford the extra $30-50.
>Estwing
Uncomfortable and clunky. I do not understand how having a single piece of steel could benefit anybody but the manufacturer. This stupid decision destroys the handling, comfort, and durability of their products. There is no reason to buy estmeme when there are any other options available. I'm sure other anons may disagree with me in some way or another, but I cannot in good faith recommend them to anybody However they fit within your budget, so they should be acknowledged.

name: Jhenry922
com:
When we moved into this house in 2011, this backyard was practically empty except for the area where the observatory stands. That was a big fan Circle the previous owner replaced to have an outdoor inflated pool. I built a half octagonal ring of raised garden bed around it after digging in my rhubarb on the left near the fence took me 3 hours with all the rock and soil here.


On the very left is a columnar Apple that I had to replace his previous one died. Up the fence line is rhubarb raspberry and espalier Apple and then hops in the very far end bed

Or in that back corner is a for variety pear tree that is grafted, and then there are blueberry bushes a gooseberry plant and red currants in behind the observatory in behind the paved concrete area

Right of that is a plum tree, by the woodpile on the right is a Montmorency cherry tree as I love sour cooking cherries, a gift of a thornless blackberry bush which produces decent berries would frequently get damaged by the birds and rendered inedible. In the little cubby hole between the fence the house and the property boundary, is a peach tree that's nestled in there buy a warm spot in the house. Last year I only got one peach off of it in 2019 I got 11, but in 2018 I got 30 peaches off of it. Not sure what's going on with that damn Peachtree. I think it has to do when the Bloom's come out and if there's any pollinating insects around or not.

name: Anonymous

I've roughed out some holes that I'm going to soak so I can dig them easier... but I'm up in the air on waiting to dig the holes until right before the trees come or have the holes done ahead of time, I'm hesitant to do the second option because of fucking with the microbiology, but I dont want to risk leaving the trees out of the ground as they're bare rooted and need to go in the ground asap.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1985439
Cast iron will destroy the rest of them for cooking quality but is in a completely different league in terms of weight obvs. If cooking is your passion I'm not going to waste my time explaining why when you already know.

Because titanium is so strong for its density, less of it is needed for the cookware and thus titanium cookware is often thinner than aluminium or steel; meaning the heat conducts through it much more quickly. This obvs then leads to you having to stir *very* often to prevent food sticking or burning when contacting the metal. Aluminium and steel are pretty much the same, though a tiny amount of aluminium can leach out and change the taste of your food if you go with non-adonised aluminium.

>How does everyone cook while /out/?
Dinners are simple things that only need boiling water, so I’m not really cooking. Breakfast and lunches require non prep at all.

>What sorta pots, stoves, and other equipment?
See pic.
Super Cat stove w/ priming pan,
12cm/1.2qt Imusa mug w/insulated handle,
Batchstovez lid,
soda can wind screen
bic
Two ounce fuel bottle
Totals titanium spork

>Beat /out/ foods?
Skurka’s beans and rice. It’s instant rice, instant refried beans, taco seasoning, cheese, and Fritos.
Peanut sauce pairs well with ramen. Add a few crushed peanuts for texture.
Little powdered donuts and shelf stable bacon are fantastic breakfast options that no one mentions.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1985375
My fuel of choice is alcohol. I like the principle (burn a liquid to get heat), I like that it's available literally everywhere, I like not having to deal with pressurized containers or gaseous substances.

I have a small Trangia set, for when I feel I need something sturdy, and a fancy feast cat food can stove (Google them) with a soda can windscreen and an MSR trail duo cookset for when I want to go light.

Do you plan on cooking?
Do you plan on cooking on an open fire?
Do you plan on cooking with a pan?
For all we know you might be planning on taking some food from home pre-cooked and a loaf of bread. Thus making any cooking utensils unnecessary.

So, anon, think about what your plans are and what you need and take it.

I’ve got a lot of stainless cookware: two sets of Coleman Peak 1, an MSR set and two of the Stanley Adventure series (nesting 2 cup set and AIO - 2 bowl set). All of these in my experience are well made, durable, quality products. I’m not a big fan of plastic, so the cups, bowls and utensils included in the Stanley sets don’t get much use (although they’re actually pretty ok) If you’re looking to upgrade from non stick aluminum, any of these brands should fill the bill. I’ve also got an MSR non stick aluminum set and while it’s a great piece of lightweight kit, it just feels weak compared to my SS and I end up babying it cuz I’m always worried that I’m going to fuck around and scratch the non stick coating.

As I said above, I’m not a big fan of plastic. It tends to be hard to clean greasy foodstuffs off of it without a lot of hot water and dish soap plus it doesn’t have the “comfy” feeling you get from eating off enamelware. If you are looking to buy enamelware, check out REI. I purchased my enamel plates, bowls and mugs from REI several years ago and I’m quite happy with them.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1996435

This type of stove was extremely popular and THE design of choice for serious outdoorsmen at one time. Gasoline has quite a bit more btu’s per pound than alcohol fuels and it’s heat output is roughly equivalent to propane & butane. In rural areas, availability of fuel can be a concern when using an alcohol or butane stove but gasoline is ubiquitous. Also with it’s burner being low to the ground and having wide legs, this stove is much less prone to tipping over. The design does have some disadvantages compared to those using disposable butane / propane canisters. It is larger, and heavier plus having a separate burner & pump connected by a hose can make storage in a backpack more awkward.

There’s nothing wrong with this stove design. Like any stove, it has it’s own advantages and disadvantages. If you are thinking of getting one, I would recommend paying more for an MSR due to their proven quality and performance.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1997452
I do this supe easy “no knead” recipe, basically flour and salt in a ziplock bag, and another little bag with years and sugar.
Try it out home first if you’d like to build up confidence and get out there baking, it’s a game changer.
3 1/2 cups of flour
1 1/2 tea spoon salt
1/2 tea spoon yeast
1 3/4 cup cold water
Follow that manufacturer’s recommendation to active the yeast (usually a bit of sugar and warm water), once that’s ready, add it to the flower mix, pour in the water and stir until everything is doughy. You’re basically done. Let it rest until it doubled in volume, fold it and let it rest again. Bake for 50-60 min in a dutch oven at 450f and let it rest for just as long before slicing it.
They say to let the dough initially rise for 8-12 hours at room temp, so if it gets cold at night outdoors, maybe you should mix it in the morning and bake in the eve instead of letting it rise overnight like you would normally do indoors. I like to put a damp rag on top of the bowl while it’s rising to keep shit from getting in the dough and the moisture content high, otherwise a dry skin can form at the surface. That’s no biggie and you can always fold it back in but i’d rather avoid it altogether if I can. Obviously, it’s going to bake much faster over coals in a lidded pot than in a dutch oven at home, so I half the recipe and make smaller buns when I’m out. Keep an eye on it, don’t let it burn, adapt to the circumstances and trust your experience or instinct if you have none. It’s really rewarding

Unsure if you’re just a troll or actually that fucking stupid. I’m leaning towards the latter. First of all I’m not the anon you were blathering to previously. Secondly if you’re going to make claims, at least do a couple minutes of research, instead of coming across as some kind of Canuck version of Donald Trump. After reading your previous comments I’m not sure you’re intelligent enough to actually understand anything you read so I’ll spell it out for you. Yes, the burn bans in Canada are put in place regionally due to local conditions and the availability of firefighters. (This is the way it works in the USA as well as Europe. ) In Canada, a burn ban is referred to as a Restricted Fire Zone. If you violate these bans you can be fined, jailed and required to pay any costs incurred if your fire causes damages. The reason you can be fined or jailed is because violating a ban by building a campfire in an RFZ is illegal you fucking moron.

Liquid fuel stoves also work in winter. A lot of butane stove struggle below freezing

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2004177
>butane stove struggle below freezing

Actually butane stoves don’t work at all below freezing unless you’re using a canister with a butane / propane mix. Coleman brand fuel canisters have the highest ratio of propane to butane (40/60) but even these begin to fail at temperatures below -10 F. You can purchase adapters to use canister stoves with propane cylinders which will allow them operate down to -40 F however I’m sure that not many anons on this board camp in conditions anywhere near that extreme.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2004686
What about stoves that also have a small preheater tube?
I'd say that would make somewhat of a difference.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2004978
The preheater tube wouldn’t make any difference because it’s the temperature of the fuel inside the canister that determines cold weather performance. At 32 degrees F and below, butane fuel remains liquid and has 0 pressure which means it will not exit the canister and produce a flame. Adding propane to the mix lowers the temperature at which this occurs because propane continues to outgas down to -44 degrees F.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2004978
These types can be run with the canister upside-down which improves winter performance. Despite what the other guy says, the canister is pressurized beyond simply the gas pressure of the fuel. When the canister is upside down liquid will still move through the fuel line, and be vaporized in the preheater tube you mention. Pressure can still be an issue depending on the fuel and how empty the tank is. This is where liquid fuel stoves are better because there's a pump to increase pressure in the fuel bottle.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2005221
>the canister is pressurized beyond simply the gas pressure of the fuel

You don’t know what you are talking about...

The only pressure in a canister is from the vapor pressure of the gas inside. When the ambient temp is lower than the boiling point of the gas, it will have 0 psi of pressure.

You *are* partially correct about turning the canister upside down to increase cold weather performance but the reason for this is due to the fact that gases cool as they expand and when a substance undergoes a phase change from a liquid to a gaseous state the expansion and resulting drop in temperature is massive. When the canister is upright, this phase change takes place inside the canister which causes the temperature of the liquid fuel to drop below the ambient air temp. If the ambient temp is close to the boiling point of the fuel, this expansive cooling can drop the fuel’s temp below it’s boiling point and it’s vapor pressure will fall to zero. When a canister is upside down, liquid fuel flows out and the phase change takes place just past the valve so the temp of the fuel inside the canister stays relatively the same.

Hope this clears up any misunderstanding.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2005003
If you put the canister valve down, the pressure of propane would push the liquid butane through the tube and the flame would heat it up. You'd probably need to burn off some of the propane to get the flame going in the first place.

Feel free to post tobaccos (no weed allowed), pipes, collections, pics of favorite combos for going /out/, pics of what you're doing with your pipe and any questions you might have.

Want to get into smoking pipes without spending too much cash?
Get a Missouri Meerschaum Legend corncob pipe and a pouch of either Prince Albert, Carter Hall or Half and Half tobacco, available at most drugstores.
What you'll need: pipe, tobacco, lighter or matches, pipe cleaners, and either a regular old nail or a pipe tool (combination tamper, scoop, and small pick).
All of these together should run you less than $20.

Having trouble keeping your pipe lit? Fill it with less tobacco and smoke it slower than you think you need to, lightly tamping as needed when the smoke starts thinning out.
If you're still having trouble, try filling your pipe this way:

It's the same lighter Sean Connery used in the James Bond movies. Very reliable (other than being slightly finicky with refueling), you can adjust the flame from barely existing to a six inch flamethrower, and they're just classy.

That said, you're better off with a Zippo, Ronson, or Bic for camping. I just carry it when I want to feel fancy.

name: Anonymous
com:
Seriously how do you keep your pipe lit?

I've watched the video in OP as well as others, but I can't get the damned thing to stay lit for more than a minute, if I can even get it lit to begin with. Why is it so hard to get dried plant matter to catch and stay on fire?

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1981523
I haven't watched any videos on it, but here's what I do:
Pack the bowl in three layers, each time filling it to the top and tamping it down. Should have some resistance but still good airflow when you test it.
Light it and give it a few puffs, let it go out. This is the charring burn. Tamp it down and light it fully.
You shouldn't need to tamp it down more than every 10 puffs or so, or when the smoke gets thin.

It could also just be the humidity of your tobacco, or the frequency of your puffs, which of course only you know. I will say that I find the tobacco from a fresh tin to often be too wet, works better for me a little dryer.

Hope that helps (and there's no shame in relighting your pipe from time to time, everyone does it)

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1981523
>>1981544
I feel it's way too easy to over pack your pipe when using the three step method. Too tight of a pack is a common reason for a pipe going out because tobacco expands when lit. Instead try packing using the German/Frank method. It's a gravity fill followed by a pinch of tobacco to create a plug in the top part of the pipe while keeping the bottom part loose. For humidity, do the pinch test. Pinch a bit of tobacco between your index and thumb. If it crackles and crumbles it's too dry, if it sticks together it's too wet. You want it to crackle slightly and puff back up after pinching. Don't underestimate the importance of a false light and getting a good cherry going. Aromatics and flake cut blends often burn worse by the way, try a non aromatic ribbon cut for the best chances of good and even burn.

name: Anonymous
com: Wheres a good place I can get actual tyrolean/bavarian pipes that aren't chinkshit?

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1981523
You're packing too hard or your tobacco is too wet.
Dry it until it's almost crunchy, kind of like how fall leaves feel, then just drop tobacco into your bowl until it's full, and press down a little with your thumb to get it just below the rim. It'll probably take time and a lot of bad smokes until you start getting it right, though.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1988887
Cherrywood is safe to smoke out of, so you lucked out there.
Don’t need a filter. Your pipe will smoke better without one, and it’s 20x simpler to make.
To do the stem, you could do what a lot of home pipe makers do-get a piece of river reed, dry it out and use that for your stem. It’s naturally hollow and widely available.
The biggest thing to worry about when making your pipe is drilling the draw hole in your pipe bowl properly. Ideally, you want the hole to just touch the bottom corner of the bowl.

Bears are attracted to strong FOOD odors. Meat, cheese, honey, etc. If it smells delicious to you, it smells delicious to a bear. The only time 'smoke' would attract a bear is when you're cooking, and then it's attracted to the smell of the food, not the smoke.

name: Anonymous
com: Is there a big difference between filtered and unfiltered for a beginner?

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1991583
Not really. I just recommend brushing when you practicably can after, and at least rinsing your mouth. Acidity -- most sodas, some lemon water, etc -- will also help clear your mouth after.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1991583
>>1991605
I'm going to disagree, I think it can make a big difference. There's several different types of filters such as paper, balsa wood and activated charcoal. A filter can restrict draw, reduce smoke harshness, regulate moisture and prevent ash/bits of tobacco from getting in your mouth. The degree to which it does any of these things depend on the type of filter and its quality. A really bad filter can the restrict draw too much and even change the taste of the tobacco. For instance, I have these White Elephant charcoal filters that clog up my entire pipe. On the other hand, a good filter can reduce the harshness so that the flavor comes through, cool down the smoke and reduce moisture if you're prone to pipe gurgling because you're a drooling retard like myself. I'd recommend trying all three types and see what you like. Personally, I use balsa wood filters for the cob and activated charcoal filters for the briar pipe.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1991583
I've never bothered with filters myself, and for a beginner, they can restrict air flow and have something else that can cause hassle. I also always remove the stingers (little condensor things) from pipes when I get them.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1991725
achruallly

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1991725
That's definitely fair. I really never use a filter. The only filtered pipes I have, even, are Missouri Meerschaum and I think a Dr. Grabow.

That said, sometimes the gurgle isn't because you're drooling into the pipe, but because the tobacco is a bit moist. Water vapor is part of the "smoke" produced, and can also collect in the tobacco itself, ending up pooling in the bottom of the bowl. Sending a pipe cleaner down to mop it up can help, as can slowing down a little to give the moisture more time to evaporate.

Do you want budget tobaccos?
Half and Half and Prince Albert are two drug store classics. The Prince Albert smells a bit like raisins when it's fresh, and they both smoke well.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1999807
This is a problem of slang and dialect more than of tobacco.
You’re referring to two completely different tobacco products: dipping tobacco (skoal, copenhagen, grizzly) and chewing tobacco (red man, levi garrett, cannonball, etc.).
Dipping tobacco is genetically related to Swedish snus, and was originally called snus in America - or chewing snuff, or moist snuff. The correct name for this product really is just moist snuff, but the translation from “snus” to English was unsophisticated and varied from brand to brand. In certain places in America, any smokeless oral tobacco was called “chew”, but this is incorrect.
Chewing tobacco is just tobacco that you chew. In America, this is usually scraps of sweetened leaf that you gnaw on to moisten it up, and then stick it in your cheek. Dip is used more or less like snus, put into the divot of the upper or lower lip. In Europe, chewing tobacco also exists, but usually as twisted rope (sold as-is in certain parts of England, and sold as small cuts of rope in a tin or pouch in continental Europe).
Chew used to be FAR more popular than dip, but USST (United States Smokeless Tobacco, the manufacturer of Copenhagen and Skoal) made a huge advertising push starting in the 70’s, and the market has since shifted. In its current form, it’s one of the newest ways of using tobacco.

Here’s an example of USST’s marketing push, exemplified by a free sample offering at a mall https://youtu.be/N9T83iPWuO8

Source: I make videos exclusively about making your own smokeless tobacco and its history

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2004520
This and basically only this. Small mason jars are a pipe smoker's best friend. Hell, mason jars in general are. I've got several pounds of tobacco packed into several jars, which I've been aging for well over a decade. I packed some smaller jars with the same tobaccos, and I go through those first, then re-fill them from the larger jars so they have as little oxygen exposure and as little chance to lose moisture as possible.

That same tobacco I spent under $250 for back in 2007 or so would run a lot more than that now when priced per-ounce, and it wouldn't be mellowed from aging.

It also means I can take my time and enjoy a wider variety, without worrying any of it will necessarily dry out before long.

I only used to smoke roll your own cigarettes. But I want to start smoking a pipe during outings any recommendations?

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2004960
That's pretty difficult to answer, really. There are a lot of "what beginners should use" kinds of advice which all have their share of bullshit and their share of good information.

I like more natural tobacco blends to aromatics, though I do also like aromatics sometimes.

If you want to start cheap, a Missouri Meerschaum corn cob pipe can serve you well for years, and if you burn it out or poke through the bottom (hey, it's a fucking corn cob lol) you're only out a few bucks. It's also something you can scorch the rim of without too much worry about ruining a nice briar pipe. That said, get what you like.

As for tobaccos, there are some classic "drug store" blends which are still very much enjoyed by people who enjoy premium tobaccos. Some can be found above in OP's post and a couple others (Sir Walter Raleigh, Carter Hall, Prince Albert, Captain Black, etc).

But do some reading. I much prefer Gawith Hoggarth & Co. Top Black Cherry and American Dream to a lot of other cherry tobaccos, for example.

Do some reading. Watch some videos. If you get a "shag" cut or similar, it's easier to pack, but searching "how to smoke [name or style] of tobacco will get you a long way for plug, rope, flake, and cube cuts.

Having recovered from surgery, I'd say to get some premium tobacco to try out, and some drug store classics for more regular use. But that's just me.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1991189

Incidentally, I made mushroom ketchup a few months ago, following the recipe from Townsend and Son. I used oyster, shiitake, porcini, portabello, and a couple other types of mushroom while making it, then bottled it all in a pair of whiskey bottles and stuck them in the fridge.

One bottle is unopened, and has developed sediment at the bottom. The other was only ever half full, I used a good amount of it while cooking, and now... there's fucking mushrooms growing inside the bottle. I boiled that shit, added a ton of salt and vinegar, and it's been inside my fridge ever since, and some spores survived and have been growing inside the bottle, feeding off the mushroom ketchup itself.

It's cool as hell. Mushrooms are some tenacious bastards.

name: Anonymous

>>1992359
>no deadly boletes in north America afaik
I believe this is true, and I've yet to get sick off of any boletes I've found in the INW despite never bothering a positive identification past "yup, bolete!" and peeling any slippery ones. I would cook them up separately and taste them before adding them to any dishes, just because some are bitter and/or unpalatable, but otherwise, my personal opinion is that the risk is exceedingly minimal. You're probably more likely to be allergic than you are to find one that's universally unsafe. That said, you know... never eat any mushroom you can't positively identify as edible, and only if you're qualified to do so, blah, blah, blah.

com: Here in Iowa, Morel mushrooms pop up when the dandelions first bloom in spring. Check near rivers for the sand type. They love old poplar trees and fruit trees. Then 2 weeks in the ones in the hills start to bloom. They grow much larger then the sand type. Beware of any near power plants and rail lines. Fungi love to convert toxins into energy, they will grow extremely large and carry all the poisons in their flesh.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1998874
When you cure them, you have to make sure they will break apart rather than bend.
>or the local variety is just shit
That's a possibility, however, these can be very unpredictable, and the level of muscimol in them can vary greatly between each individual mushroom, even those picked in the same area.

Another point would be to avoid carbonated drinks for an hour or two after ingesting them. The curing process basically removes one carboxyl group from the ibotenic acid molecules, which converts them into muscimol, and the theory is that the CO2 present in carbonated drinks will reconvert it back into ibotenic acid. I don't know how scientifically sound this is, but taking that precaution certainly doesn't hurt.

For me, a dose of 5-10g provides a type of "chillax and play some Animal Crossing" effect, if that makes any sense.

Again, these are very unpredictable, and the effects can vary from person to person. Some may get delirious, while others only experience Cannabis or ethanol-like buzzes. I don't know how new you are to this, but what I did, was to start with very small doses (1g), and then just increased it over time, just to get to know how I react to it.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1998981
I haven't tried this with A. muscaria, but it works very well with other species like C. cibarius and C. tubaeformis:
When you'll be drying them, cut them into smaller pieces. Doesn't need to be pulverized, but they have to be in pieces, basically.

Then, what you do, is throw them in the oven at 50 degrees centigrade or less. I find that 45-50 works very well. Make sure that the fan is running, if your oven has one, and leave door slightly open. I usually jam the door open with a ladle or a spatula, or other such kitchen cutlery.

Then, when you've done all that, let it sit in there for three hours. When the three hours are up, turn the oven off and let it sit there over night.

The next day, turn the oven back on and give it three more hours, and they should be done.

The success of this process depends very much on the size of the chunks. The smaller the better, basically.

name: Anonymous
com:
Learn how to find north with an analogue watch. Note that this is different depending on if you're in the northern or southern hemisphere. Start wearing an analogue watch if you don't already.

Learn about common edible plants in your area. Don't just watch youtube videos - you need to actually get a reference book and spend time in your area learning how to identify plants. And for fuck sake, absolutely do not eat anything until you know what you're actually doing.

Get some first aid training and take a stop the bleed course. Learn how to deal with snakebites.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2005946
If you want to have a book in your hiking pack, get a tiny survival manual like this. It weights nothing and has lots of info.
Aside from this, you only want to bring bring a book with you if you're trying to learn something specific. What I mean is, you should get a book on local edibles and take it with you to learn to identiy plants while on a casual hike so that you have that knowledge when you need it.
Keep the information in your brain rather than having to carry a tiny library with you because you don't actually know shit.

name: Anonymous
com: learn how to whistle with your hands. carrying a "survival whistle" is handy, but if you lose it or forget to bring it then you're fucked. but you can use your hands to whistle loudly to attract attention. if you shout "HELP HELP HELP" like a retard then you will lose your voice quickly, but you can whistle all day

>>1996270
"Why didn’t the peoples of ancient Mesoamerica have wheeled transport? They had a vibrant commercial economy, with lots of long-distance trade, periodic marketplaces, and professional merchants. They had two types of money. But they didn’t use wheeled carts.

The surprising thing is that the Mesoamericans DID invent the wheel. They made wheeled toys – mostly small clay animals with holes in the legs for an axle and wheels. These were most abundant in sites of the Toltec period (AD 900-1100), including Tula in central Mexico.


When the Spanish arrived from Europe in the sixteenth century they were astounded at the remarkable skills exhibited by the architects, builders and craftsmen of the ‘New World’. The calendar developed by the ancient Maya was more accurate than the calendar in use throughout Europe and the medical system in place among the residents of Mesoamerica was superior to that of the Spanish.

Yet, for all the advanced thinking, there was no utilitarian wheel; no carts, no wagons, no potter’s wheel. Still the concept of the wheel was known throughout Mesoamerica.

Archeologists have recovered numerous wheeled toys, very much like those still made today for children. These toys were what we would call “pull toys” and they were generally made of fired clay in the form of an animal (real or imagined) standing on a platform supported by four ceramic wheels. A loop for the pull string was usually made around the neck or head of the creature.

And yet, while the idea of the wheel was in place there were no wheeled vehicles."

Try studying it, for starters.
The point with geographic determinism isn't that it's wrong, but Diamond is wrong. He puts literally everything on hard-core geo determinism, ignoring entirely every other factor imaginable. And everything that doesn't fit his "perfect" vision is instantly discarded.
Last time this style of geo determinism was done, it was 1820s, with people writing sincere works in tune of "there is coal in Wales, because God willed the rise of British mining industry".

Nalgene bottles are best. I bring one to soak beans in while I walk during the day. I bring a plastic canteen for 100% larp XP. Also a few brands of water bladders I'm testing out.

Personally, I do a MSR pocket rocket with that cheap Walmart Stanley set. You can fit a smaller gas canister inside the Stanley. It is very compact and lightweight overall (chuck the plastic cups, useless). Bring a titanium spork and a pocketknife. I also bring a small cutting board.

People don’t backpack across America like they Backpack across Europe. The former was built around the idea of everyone having a car or cities that are semi-autonomous, while the latter was built thousands of years ago and towns are mostly walking distance from one another. Even discounting crime, backpacking across the US was never viable.

Hitchhiking totally is, though it takes much longer as there’s a stigma that everyone is a psycho killer. There was actually a disinformation campaign in the 60’s spread by the government and media to keep people off of the interstates. They hyped up some isolated incidences of hitchhikers being killed and destroyed that part of our culture. The myth still persists.

name: Anonymous
com:
Freight train hopping.

Don't bother with riding the cars. Get a train with a locomotive in the middle or rear. They're not locked, at least the union pacific ones aren't. They will have seats, toilets, heat, AC, and sometimes bottled water.

There are cameras inside the cab. But they won't be checked unless the train is in an incident. So just keep the lights off, don't touch anything but climate controls, and duck when you see another train

>>2000454
They’ve reached popular status because they appeal to people who don’t hike often, and therefore can role the dice on something that might be ok or might be a complete failure. It also takes out any need for durability.

There’s also the factor of the California influence. It’s been around for decades. California is the most populous state by far, and when it comes to hiking opportunities it’s miles beyond the next few populous states. Like, it’s not even close. So you have millions of people who hike all concentrated in a place that goes through a binary rain cycle; it’s very wet in the winter then a virtual drought the rest of the year. In a place like that, sure, you can get away with a tent that might not even be waterproof. It’s the same reason everyone carries a ccf pad without a way to cover it if it starts raining.

name: Necromancer
com:
>>2006996
Your sleeping bag will be compressed where you're laying on top of it, providing very little insulation. A pad or quilt is pretty necessary. Pads are cheap, quilts are comfortable and consistently warmer (you can roll off a pad relatively easily, unless you're sleeping diagonally which is usually recommended.. but imo pads are even more uncomfortable in this state).

I'm in the process of making a top quilt which will replace my sleeping bag. It's kind of a preference thing really, though the main objective benefits of sleeping bags over quilts are more applicable to extremely cold temperatures. Of course there are subjective differences which can make your mind up either way. Imo top quilts make the most sense in a hammock with a full length underquilt.

On a traditional tent setup, your pad covers 1 of your 4 sides (front, back, left, right), so your bag/quilt has to cover the other 3. One of the downsides of a quilt is that it lets drafts in from the sides. With a hammock, the underquilt is covering 3 of your 4 sides and you only really need something to cover the top of you, so a topquilt really shines here. Of course, this assumes you're using an underquilt.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2007013

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2006996
top quilt:
depending on how cold you'll take the hammock, an actual blanket vs a quilt with a foot box will be fine for most slightly cooler temps. The footbox just keeps things tidy and aligned for getting in and if you move around. You can even get a cheap down or synthetic down camping quilt and just add some velcro or some snap closures if you're feeling snazzy. For hammock camping, I normally just unzip my sleeping bag, the zipper and hood aren't annoying enough and I only do like 1 or 2 trips cold enough with the hammock to worry about that. The only reason to go away from the current bag is if it's inadequate for other uses or reasons.

bottom
i really don't like pads in the hammock, they slide around, they get wet from condensation when i use them. Sub-optimal in my opinion, but fine for me since i use them only for 1-2 trips. Most of the time i just tie a synthetic blanket onto my ridgeline so it wraps underneath and rests just below me with me in the hammock. not even a really underquilt set-up, but it's good to about 60F. If I want to push the hammock colder, i'll get an underquilt.

Do you plan on hammocking primarily or is this a 'sometimes' thing? The underquilt is by far the only sort of item that can't be used excepted with the hammock.

A down quilt, shock cord, and a dream <100usd
