name: Necromancer
com:
>>2007023
It just depends what you want. You can get an alright underquilt for $300AU, though the really nice quilts are like $350US+ and you pretty much need to buy from a cottage company or DIY if you want something really nice. If you DIY it, $300AU will get you a really nice ultralight underquilt, though you will need a sewing machine.

If you want to buy a tent, consider you'll also need a sleeping pad (which you may already have) and you might be wanting something not inexpensive, like a Thermarest, if you want to trim the weight down and remain comfortable. Though you can get a CCF mat for like $20. I have no idea what kind of tent you can get with that money. My knowledge of tents is pretty much "Vango are okay but not amazing and you'll spend £80-120, or there's fancy as shit Hillebergs if you're megabucks". I've been using hammocks for about 9 years now. By my reckoning, hammock setups are lighter than tent setups*, but you invest a lot into your quilts; fancy as shit hammocks can be really cheap, or you can make them yourself really easily (They're literally just a rectangle with a cord channel in either end, and then some bugnet over the top... Even buying fancy Ripstop By The Roll printed ultralight fabric is going to put your costs under $100US). Tent setups seem to be more about investment into the tent itself, and then you just get a "good" sleeping bag and pad.. though take that with a huge pinch of salt, I really don't know shit about tents.

* my hammock, cordage, bugnet and tarp weigh in at ~1kg and they pack down really small. They cost me £140, together. When I did look into buying a tent about 6 years ago, buying a comfortable tent for this weight wasn't possible in this price range (though I could be wrong). Even a £660 hilleberg 3-season tent comes in at 1.2kg (their lightest 3-season tent).

The quilts come to about 1.2kg, which is comparable to a pad+top quilt setup used with a tent.

name: Necromancer
com:
I actually read >>2007042 before posting >>2007045, but ran out of characters. It's worth pointing out that my knowledge of this stuff is based on British weather. Also, I made my own underquilt years ago and all the research I've done is in getting a quilt that gives more coverage for the same, or lower, weight and then making it myself. I'm not familiar with a lot of the more recent, more entry level, hammocking quilts. I know that DD Hammocks make a synthetic underquilt.

This guy seems to know about that stuff though, and it's useful advice. Though I will point out that it's $300 australian, not US, and that the superwarm down quilts are like $400US. Just worth keeping in mind.

>>2007032
>an actual blanket
I have used a fleece blanket in the south of England in May and it was absolutely miserable. The only reason I might consider doing it again is if I have a really warm full-length underquilt. Top quilts give you more flexibility for ventilation, which is worth keeping in mind if you want a year-round setup.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2000794
I lived in AZ for two years and hike around a lot. In my opinion most of the best hiking is on the Arizona Trail. It is just so well maintained. It is difficult to really get way out there in the wilderness and still be on a decent trail. I recommend doing some sections in the Catalina mountains near Tucson, Four Peaks Wilderness and The Mazatzals. There is also very good and reliable water resources on the AZT. Download the AZT trail on Guthooks and you can read where water caches are and the status of collection tanks.

Other great options off the AZT are in the San Francisco peaks (hike up Humphrey's Peak, the Kachina trail is very nice), Sedona area (Sycamore Canyon is nice and very remote, but no well maintained trails), then of course there is the Grand Canyon (be sure to research permits regarding the National Park before going, it is nearly impossible to camp in the canyon without applying a year in advance).

Good day hikes around Phoenix are Weavers Needle, South Mountain, Camelback Mountain and Piestewa Peak. I have hiked up and down Piestewa and Camelback to many times to count, such amazing exercise right in the city.

Also, Flagstaff is going to be probably the best place to park your van. Lots of likeminded people up there and amazing weather.

name: Anonymous
com:
Not even American, but WV is awesome. I came pretty close to moving there. I still sometimes regret not doing it.

Good memories of spending summers messing around walking, kayaking and climbing around Coopers Rock, hiking parts of the Allegheny, hunting around for abandoned coal mine heads and drinking at innawoods hillbilly concerts. It has its fair share of rough points for sure, the old mining towns are almost tragic, but there's a lot of life, energy and community there that I haven't seen in other states I've visited.

com: So I have been raising and breeding chickens specifically suited to colder climates post SHTF for 15 years now hoping to produce a fairly large fowl with moderate growth and fair egg production. I've gotten fairly close, my main focus at the moment is cleaning up some color irregularities that pop up and trying to improve combs on the birds (I am breeding for rose combs but have been getting off combs in maybe 10% of birds yet). However with the covid panic I've been thinking maybe I'm misguided (I'm still going to keep working on the project because it's a great way to separate fools from their money) it seems to me that the real solution is bantams following along the same lines as my large fowl. Something that can produce some degree of meat and egg but doesn't have the same feed and space costs as large fowl. What are your thoughts on this? Would it behoove me to start obtaining bantam stock and working towards a larger but still bantam class birds that will have above average musculature while maintaining a fair rate of lay? For reference my current birds are cocks averaging 8 pounds at 16 weeks finishing at around 15 pounds at 18 months and hens weighing 12 pounds laying at about 190 eggs a year and go broody at the drop of a hat if left to set eggs.

I suppose I misrepresented the question, I breed and show a large number of breeds both banty and standard in addition to my "prepper chicken" project. My question specifically on this isn't a bantam for bantam breeders or regular chicken enthusiasts but a larger "bantam" breed specifically marketed as a SHTF breed due to it being
>lower feed consumption
>good sized carcass for one meal (goal would be 3.5 pound bird dressing around 65%)
>less space intensive
I should note that the idea of a "SHTF breed" is ridiculous as there are dozens of breeds that would fill the role quite nicely, this was just a side project to see about making a strain with certain traits because I could until a few years ago when my buddy commented that those were the birds he wanted for the end of the world and I decided to focus on making them true breeding so I could market them as a breed. As it stands now there is a lot of debate as to what the best breed is for SHTF, but there is no one breed that is yet to be declared the winner. I aim to market these birds as the winner and make a decent amount of money off paranoid fools. Realistically very similar birds could be obtained by running any larger breed of cock (I originally started with langshans) over some dark cornish hens, but the kind of person who is buying a SHTF chicken wouldn't know that.

com:
>>2004848
you can't really but it depends what exactly you have. some lay eggs sooner but the ones my family had was always about a year after hatching. food, environment and stress all play big roles. they start laying slow and their first eggs will often be deformed then you get a good year of eggs before they start slowing which brings backs the occasional deformed egg then they stop.

we always had to buy a fresh batch every year to keep egg production fairly steady. i believe it was year 3 or 4 when they wouldn't lay enough to justify their food costs and would be culled. honestly always thought having chickens small scale was a bit pointless but a lot of people seem to like doing it.

what are you feeding them? you can feed some some household stuff like vegetable scraps as treats but their regular diet should be laying specific which is generally high protein and calcium. you also have to make sure they have plenty of water and places to actually lay the eggs

name: Anonymous

>>2005761
Not him but it depends on the LED tube
They come in three versions but you'll probably only encounter two of them
Most LED tube lights that go into a fluorescent fixture are just drop in, they don't need a special ballast or anything done to the fixture.
Another type is "ballast bypass" where the fixture needs to have the ballast bypassed, don't worry to much about these, just be aware of them and don't get them.
3rd type is whole fixtures designed to imitate a flourescent fixture in from factor, you can usually find these at a Walmart or any hardware store and you can do quite a few seedlings under just one. They are not usually expensive

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2006513
You should learn the general principles of gardening , through some trial and error.

Your specific area and geological history will be pretty idiosyncratic and what works for others won’t work for you.

As for filling the beds, you want to till in or top dress the soil with compost. Plant cold season plants in March/April and warm season stuff in may.

Thin any seedlings that are super close together and then as needed when plants are too crowded.

Grow what you like to eat, to preserve stuff make pickling juice or a fermenting brine and jar them with it.

If you don’t know what to grow, grab 5-10 packets of random seeds, mix em up and throw them all over your bed and wait.

Water when the soil feels dry to the touch, you’ll get the rhythm down quickly.

You can use a compost tea (compost left to rot in water) to fertilize any wimpy looking plants.

If you're a NEET then you should try to get a job with one of the Conservation Corps in your area. You'll get to work on a crew of young people with similar interests and do projects in beautiful places like national parks and forests.
The pay is shit, if they even pay you at all (often it's just a stipend plus money for education) but it's worth doing a season or two because government-run maintenance/conservation jobs will take your application seriously if they see you've worked for the Corps. It's how most people who do trail work for the NPS or forest service start, for example.
And if you have your heart set on private landscaping (shitty job but pays more), it's also a good foot up the ladder for that.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1990429
I went from being on a computer all day to landscape labourer, now I own my own hardscape and construction company.
Pretty fun work because there's so many different trades bundled together and there's lots to learn. Lots of money too and never a shortage of work.

If you're talking softscape, it's boring in my opinion so get a set of bluetooth ear protection and some good podcasts.

If you're doing hardscape:
At first you'll be pretty broken. Sleep a lot and eat nutritious food, you'll get muscle quick.
Work hard, show up on time, and don't be afraid to get dirty.
Bring lots of water, sunscreen, and snacks/food.
Use proper form when you're shoveling, lifting, etc. I fucked up my back pretty good over the years because I thought I was unstoppable when I was younger.
See if the company will give you PPE, most should. If they don't, buy your own. Safety glasses, ear protection, and gloves while you have baby hands.
Also don't cheap out on workboots, good ones make a big difference.
If you have a Costco around you, they have those fucking great wool blend socks... Use those every day, even in the summer. It'll keep your feet comfy and dry.
Get a good facemask with bayonet filters if you're cutting. Silica dust fucks you up, don't be like those lunatics with the bandana on. Get the 3M 6502QL, it's cheap, comfy, and easy to put on. P100 filters like 2091/2096/2097 or 2291/2296/2297. If you're using muriatic/hydrochloric acid to etch or clean get the 60926.

Show interest in learning and trying new things, be decent at it and use that to negotiate higher wages early on. I don't know where ya are but around here it's tough to find good help, so if you're sober, show up every day and learn quick you'll do well.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>1996562
>my lower back still hurts badly but hopefully it will toughen up in the near future.

Lower back doesn't "toughen", if you're hurting it's because you're herniating discs or grinding cartilage out from between them. You're probably used to letting your spine bear weight completely unsupported, which is no bueno when you are lifting heavy things.
Remember to maintain good posture at all times, keep your back straight.
Brace your abs (tense them like you're going to get punched in the gut, but not in a way that restricts your breath)
Clench your butt cheeks
Lift with your legs, not your back
Avoid any twisting movement while you're carrying things, turn your whole body.
Seriously, look up some instructional videos on how to squat or deadlift and pay particular attention to posture and bracing.

You should also consider some sort of yoga or mobility routine to keep yourself limber and help recover after a hard day of lugging soil and sod around.

t. ex-NEET and blew my back out twice as a rookie landscaper.

What you will learn for sure is attention to detail, punctuality, working alone and with others, all the good transferable stuff. And you're getting experience being outdoors in the elements, which is attractive for many trades.
Besides, any work experience at all is infinitely more experience than NEETdom.

name: Anonymous
com:
I'm going to throw you a bone bro. Started landscaping at 23 after 4 years doing fuck all as full time student - daughter on the way, needed to support my family. It was the only job I could get, through friends of friends. Zero experience.

First month or two was hell. Started in the peak of Aussie summer, was 45 degrees my first day. Busted ass and nearly died my first week - feet blistered to shit and lost 4 toe nails wearing shitty boots that didn't fit. I remember the boss calling and asking if I'd be back for more work next week - I really truly thought I couldn't fucking do it. I felt so weak and looking around at the boys around me who did this shit day in day out, I felt like a bitch. Sure enough I hunkered down, made that return the week after. And sure enough, over time it got easier. Work stayed hard for first year, I just got tougher, more resilient. Knew I had to toughen the fuck up for my family. Man did I do some shit jobs - weeding snake ridden sumps, mowing main roads verges, swamps, dumps, whipping firebreaks all by myself in the middle of the bush, hardscapes in the pouring rain, days working with the boss who never stopped work for smoko or lunch (old fucker truly was made of steel).

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2002766
One day the company lined up the biggest project we'd ever landed - over a thousand cubic meters of mulch down the median strip of a main road, along with planting 120 huge trees. I did that shit through a heatwave, with nothing but a rake, pitchfork, shovel and a wheelbarrow. They had to pickup labour hire through an employment agency as we where too short staffed to help - 6 fucking guys (experienced landscapers) came in and quit during that project alone, none of them could handle it. I'd go home black head to fucking toe covered in mulch dust every afternoon. I remember picking up 150-200l trees by hand, 6 at a time because thats all our shitty little truck with 500k kilometers on the clock and no windows could handle. We threw those trees in, 30 per day, dug the holes by hand through old limestome and roadbase. One day it was 47 degrees, I remember drinking 8 litres of water and 3 gatorades and I didn't piss a drop. All sweat. Project took 6 weeks in total, but I didn't crack. Didn't whinge. And sure enough it finished amazing, the bosses where stoked. The client was so happy we did it all again on another road a week later. But I'd earned my stripes, and things got better. I got some great cruisey jobs after that, working maintenance at a beach, doing grounds for the state university. There's plenty of good work out there, but best believe you earn that shit in a company.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2002766
Needless to say its a fucking shitty existence. You are just slave labour 90% of the time. If you're a halfwit you can start your own ventures and make easy $ that way - most the boys I worked with did that. It's the only way to make a real living. But one or two good clients can net you big bucks, cash in hand, for fuck all work. I'm personally out the game. Nearly lost a finger at work and decided fuck it, time to move onto bigger things. But I don't regret doing any of it. Brutal manual labour teaches you a lot about yourself. It gives you strength and resolve most faggot NEETs never get a handle on. It's worth doing for that alone, irrespective of any career goals you have. Learn from it and move on, my final advice.

Trust me bro, you will look back at this moment in 2 years time, like I am today, and realise it's significance. Will you fold, or endure? My life was plagued with endless encounters where I chose the 'easy route'. It made me mentally weak and soft. To chose the difficult, to chose to bare that burden, is worth every bit of suffering for the strength of character you get out of it. You just need to find you're own personal reason to bare it. Having my first child certainly gave me mine.

Believe me going from NEET to Landscaper is a huge shift. It's going to take a toll on your body. But it does get better. You will shock yourself 6 months from now with your bodies capacity for output. When I started I thought I'd never be able to work out again, but sure enough I only got stronger and fitter than I was before. The feeling you get when you finish a 10 hour shift in the blistering heat, then head straight to the gym to smash some PR's is unspeakable. Better than any drug I've tried. Pure masculine invigoration manifest. You where born for this shit man.

>>1990429
It depends on the type of gig you land. Private work for homeowners is where it's at, they provide you with anything you need and always pay well, and will be lenient with breaks and such as long as you get shit done. The big projects like water features are a lot more fun this way too.
Real landscaping companies are usually shit. Long days, no breaks except lunch, usually back breaking work with lots of repetitive motion, like weeding, hauling, pruning, etc. If you are going for this try and be one of the guys who mows, it's the cushiest thing in these companies. You just ride around the property listening to music or a podcast.
If you don't care about landscaping itself and just wanted to work with plants, I recommend green house.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>2000624
First think to know is that only boring people get bored. You might not like it but it’s still true. What you should do it be curious. What’s around, under, and above you? Learn about clouds and weather, try to identify those you see and make predictions. Learn about stars, try to identify constellations and to orient yourself. Teach yourself some commonly used knots and try out some pioneering and woodcraft to make your camp a bit more comfortable. What about the soil under your feet? Do you know it’s composition or about the rock formations in your area? Digg around for cool looking rocks and identify those too. Maybe you’ll come across some tracks while you’re doing that. Are those animal or insect tracks? Well learn about that too, sketch them, maybe even make some plaster casts if you can. You seem to imply you already know about plants and mushrooms, so you could start sketching specimens just to see if you can identify them later in books from your drawings. Another fun thing I’ve started to get into is making maps of my campsites and surroundings. I’ve come across a book about animal tracking that recommended doing one to have a better understanding of the animals around you. Start from the centre, using some landmark like a big boulder or a tree, and walk 100 paces in each direction to make a circular map. take notes of vegetation, topography, trails and tracks, streams, marshes, lakes, etc.
If none of that seems to tickle your fancy, just learn to cook and bake on coals and make delicious snacks. Good luck my man

name: Anonymous
com:
I had a few close calls while /out/ and /trv/
It's easy to shit on people but there really are forces at play that are nor reasonably foreseeable or that can be mitigated.
Oftentimes there is a strong element of bad resources, while the information is clear in one place, in many other places it's absent, deliberately misrepresented, outdated or inaccurate- when you get four conflicting sources you start to see how someone could get into a lot of trouble.

Other elements like international inconsistencies that lead people thinking they are in for a good time when they are in fact in for a bad time.
A classic example is that there is a black diamond ski run in Australia down on Mount Bulla- you see 8 year old euro kids skiing down them backwards most days. If an Australian tried a black diamond in the French alps they would perhaps reasonably assume they would be a similar difficulty because that is explicitly what the system claims to do.

Sometimes there are threats from unexpected places, like terrorism- or more commonly sexual assault.
It's common overseas for there to be a total lack of confidentiality and in many cases private information is sold for cash between commercial operators- someone knowing which trail a woman may take before she even starts is likely, because her expected arrival will have been sent to guest houses ahead of her for cash so their peddlers are ready to offer her lodging.
In this kind of environment it's often simply impossible to safeguard venerable individuals.

I will tell you some stories /out/

name: Anonymous
com:
The tiny, narrow country of Panama runs in an East-West direction, almost doubling back on itself, serpent-like. Owing to a peculiar optical illusion, the sun here appears to rise in the West, not the East. If the women were not aware of this peculiarity, they would be pulled in the wrong direction, away from town, further into the jungle. This alone is a powerful, potentially tragic story element." A Boquete native called Patrick also wrote in this respect: "It's possible that the girls got disoriented somewhere on the trail and without a compass weren't able to establish the direction that they started from. If they followed common logic and thought that the Sun sets in the West and headed in that direction then they would actually be heading East. towards Boca del Toro. I know it seems strange to someone not living here but because Panama runs East to West and not North to South this strange illusion takes place. I often watch the Sun rise in the West (South Sea - Pacific) and set behind Volcan Baru (Boca del Toro) in the East. I cannot think of any other logical (non-criminal) reason for them to continue to the Boca del Toro region."

What the fuck this makes no sense whatsoever

this

make sure to download offline maps for the broad area you are visiting before setting out

I like exploring the countryside, the key is to find backroads that are not too crowded but also not like crap dirt roads.

In general many roads with three number designations (like 666) will be narrow 2 lane backroads, paved but through rural areas.

You can usually string a route avoiding highways with these three digit secondary roads.

Turn on airplane mode to load the offline downloaded maps when you are not getting cell/data reception in the app.
